Tectonic Summary

The November 14, 2019, M 7.1 earthquake northwest of Kota Ternate, Indonesia, occurred at a depth of ~45 km on or near the interface between the subducted Halmahera slab and the overlying Sunda plate, in the complex plate boundary region of eastern Indonesia, about 300 km to the west of the major plate boundary between the Sunda and Pacific plates. Faulting mechanism solutions for the event indicate that it activated a reverse faulting structure, with a moderate dip towards either the northwest or the southeast, in line with the general trend of earthquakes in the region. Though the earthquake occurred near the boundary between the Halmahera slab and the Sunda plate, this earthquake is not a traditional plate interface event such as those experienced in other subduction zones, since the Halmahera slab is completely subducted and has no surface expression. Slip on a fault aligned with either nodal plane is thus consistent with the tectonic setting of this event.

Tectonics in eastern Indonesia are extremely complex and are dominated by the mostly convergent interactions of the Pacific, Australia, Philippine Sea, and Sunda plates, with some authors labeling the most proximate edge of the Pacific plate here as a separate tectonic block called the Caroline plate. The edges of the Sunda and Australia plates are also often subdivided into smaller tectonic blocks, including the Molucca Sea and Birds Head microplates immediately to the south and east of the November 2019 earthquake, respectively. In this context, the November 2019 event most closely aligns with the boundary between the broader Sunda plate and the Birds Head microplate. At depth beneath this earthquake and the Molucca Sea in general, the inverted-U-shaped Halmahera plate, which has no surface expression, also plays a role in regional tectonics. At the location of the November 14th earthquake, the Sunda and Philippine Sea plates are converging in an east-west direction at a rate of approximately 109 mm/yr.

This area of the Molucca Sea frequently hosts moderate to large earthquakes; nearly 110 M 6+ events have occurred within 250 km of the November 14, 2019, earthquake over the past half century, seven of which were M 7+. The largest, a M 7.5 event in August 1986, struck along the same microplate boundary structure just 25 km to the northeast of the 2019 event. Another M 7.5 event in January 2007 occurred 60 km to the southwest of today's event. Despite the large number of events in the region, few have been damaging because of their oceanic setting, though the 2007 event previously mentioned did result in 3 shaking related fatalities and minor damage on the nearby island of Sulawesi.

Along the Xiaojlang River from Biguba in the south to Tangdanchang in the southwest cliffs collapsed, hills displaced, and roads along the foot of mountains were blocked up. The Yinghe River was also dammed by earth and stones. At Mushulang, landslides occurred and dammed the river for 3 days. Several houses at Xiaoying, Awang were pushed ahead 500 m or more. Field banks and paths were seriously distorted. From Ziniupo to the Willow River of Xundian, the ground fissured from south to north, 0.4-1.5 m wide and unfathomable in depth with a total length of about 100 km. Intermittent, crisscross fissures extended in the fields. (According to an investigation, garben-and horst-type earthquake remains can still be seen).

Dozens of people were killed and all survivors stayed in the open. As the earthquake occurred in daytime, casualties were not heavy, but few workers in mines came out.

Qiaojia: All government offices were destroyed, military and civilian houses all collapsed. Cliffs collapsed. 16 people were crushed to death on narrow paths. At Chele, the ground cracked and water gushed out.

Xundian: The four city gates were destroyed in the prefecture city.

The shock also struck Zhanyi.

After the quake, the ground frequently sounded as thundering or roaring waves until several months later. On the day before the shock, the sky was murky misleading people into suspecting a coming rain instead of an earthquake. Since then, earthquake happened in every month until 1735.

(above from reference #3939)

A lot of battlements on brick city, walls, gate towers, schools, government offices and civilian houses collapsed. 37 people were killed.

Jiangchuan: A small number of city walls and civilian houses collapsed. The shock also struck Kunming, Yuxi, Lunan, Jianshui and Jinning.

(above from reference #3939)

December 17, 1750. Disastrous tremor a Fiume; three quarters of the the city was ruined and it remained uninhabitable during a certain time. Many deaths. Tidal wave submerged a small island. In the surroundings: church of Klana was ruined. Intensity 10.5. (reference #1093)

June 3, 1773. The capital of Guatemala, situated in the same place where Antigua is now located, experienced terrible earthquakes ten times between 1565 and 1773. The sea encroached inland on June 3, 1773.

Two volcanoes near the city appeared to boil. Flows of hot water issued from one and flows of burning hot lava issued from the other. Cracks and gaps formed everywhere on the surface. The ground was in continuous motion.

This terrible state lasted five days. Finally, on the 7th, a chasm opened up and almost the entire city disappeared together with 5000 families (Berghaus, 1844, ref #4116).

These data, including those about the flood, are doubtful. Essentially, as is directly stated in Mallet's catalogue (1854, ref #496), the matter concerns the issue of water from a caldron lake. Putte's (1924, ref #4117) book about seismic events gives the following account. In 1773, the capital of Guatemala was completely destroyed by a series of earthquakes, the first of which occurred on June 10. On July 29, a "fatal" earthquake completed the destruction o the city. One hundred and twenty persons were killed and 300 injured, even though the population lived in tents because of the continual shocks. The shocks continued for several more months, since the church and the monastery, which remained standing, although greatly damaged on July 29, finally collapsed only on December 13. The pleistoseismic zone was apparently very limited, since the residents who fled from the capital settled at the settlements of San Lucas [14 km west of Guatemala], Micsco [8 km west of Guatemala], Amatitlan, Petapa [15 km south of Guatemala], Pinula [eastern suburb of Guatemala], Tecpan, Escuintla, Villa Nueva [13 km south west of Guatemala], and Chimaltenango [35 km west of Guatemala], which were very close to the former capital.

(above from reference #415)

Within the limits of our seismic chronicle, that is, for six centuries or more, no disastrous earthquake ever visited the plain of Calabria until shortly after noon on Feb. 5 [1783]. Then, within two minutes, nearly very town or village within it was reduced to a shapeless heap of ruins. Considering that no town in the central area contained so many as six thousand inhabitants, the numbers of deaths in some are unusually great, for example, 3,331 in Bagnara, 2,261 in Polistena, and 2,017 in Casalnuovo. Vivenzio estimates the total loss of life from the earthquakes alone at 29,451 in Calabria ulteriore (or 67% of the total population) and 5 in Calabria citeriore, but to this number he adds 5,709 who perished from the epidemics that followed. The more recent statistics of A. Grimaldit increase these figures. He gives the numbers killed in Calabria as 9,515 and in the province of Messina as 630, or altogether 30,145, and of those who died afterwards from the epidemics as 18,876. He estimates that the material damage in Calabria alone amounted to 132,812,500 lire. (reference #516)

All the towns and villages of Calabria were shaken with tremendous violence. Those built on loose detrital foundations were leveled with the ground, while those situated on solid rock, though greatly shaken, for the most part remained standing. On the 28th of March, however, the contrary seemed to be the case. Those on the east of the Apennines suffered less than those on the west. The devastation throughout the "Plain" of Calabria and Sicily was awful. In both regions a subterranean murmuring noise was heard from the shock; in Calabria it seemed to come from the SW. At Scylla (Straits of Messina) a portion of a mountain fell in to the sea (on the night of the 5th), when great damage was done in Sicily by the great sea wave resulting from its fall. Tremendous effects were produced over the surface of Calabria, hills were overthrown and leveled with the plain, chasms opened in the ground and swallowed up people in the moment of their flight, springs dried up, the course of rivers was stopped for a moment, to be renewed immediately after with such violence as to tear away every obstruction. Stromboli, which under ordinary circumstances constantly emits smoke, ceased almost, if not altogether, to do so on this day. Etna and Vesuvius were also perfectly still. The water was unnaturally still and gloomy, like that which often precedes great thunderstorms, and immediately before the shock a heavy, whistling blast of wind was observed. (reference #496)

1783 Feb. 5. Italy, Straits of Messina. Sea violently agitated, rising more than 20 feet and advancing and retiring suddenly. Thirty thousand killed. It is unknown if the 30,000 killed are by the earthquake and/or tsunami. (reference #132)

1783-1786, Calabrian earthquakes, 60,000 deaths.

Reference #1003 lists February 5, 1783, Calabria, Italy, 30,000 deaths. (reference #1002)

February 4, 1783, Calabria, Italy, 29,000 deaths. (reference #1051)

February-March 1783, Calabria and Messina, Italy and felt throughout Sicily and eastwards to Gallipoli in the Apulia region, extreme damage. (reference #1055)

March 27, 1783, 7 p.m. The sixth and last of the principal earthquakes occurred at about 7 p.m. on Mar. 27. With the exception of the first great earthquake of Feb. 5, it was the strongest of the series, though some of the early investigators (Grimaldi, Sarconi and Dolomieu) regarded it as the most violent of all. The number of persons killed by this earthquake, according to Grimaldi, was 1,141, of whom 331 died at Borgia, 184 at Girifalco and 75 at Maida. The total no doubt would have been much higher if the inhabitants had not abandoned their houses and lived in tents and other shelters.

During the earthquakes of Feb. 5-7, no serious damage occurred to the north of the isthmus of Catanzaro, nor was there any loss of life. On Mar. 27, however, the epicentre lay within the isthmus. The three towns already referred to were completely destroyed, while, in many other towns and villages (such as S. Floro, Filadelfia, Cortale, etc.), few houses were left fit to live in. The very disastrous area, enclosed within the innermost isoseismal was only 17 miles long, nearly 7 miles wide, and contained about 90 sq. miles; while the areas included within the disastrous and ruinous isoseismals did not exceed 400 and 2,000 sq. miles, respectively. The area included within the sixth isoseismal, in which the shock was moderate or slight, covered about 86,000 sq. miles, or approximately the same as that for the first great earthquake. Both Mercalli and Baratta, however, as well as Sarconi among the earlier writers, state that the earthquake of Mar. 27 disturbed an area notably greater than that of Feb. 5, for, while it was sensible all over Sicily, it was felt, towards the north, in the Basilicata and in the provinces of Otranto, Bari and Terra di Lavoro.

At Monteleone, according to Pignataro, the shock lasted for 2 min. and consisted of undulatory, vertical and vorticose movements combined. Near the river Arnato, as Grirnaldi states, the earth was shaken for two minutes with a movement so violent that people were unable to keep on their feet. At Catanzaro, according to De Leone, the vertical blows were so violent that people were jerked from the ground.

1804, Aug 25, beginning at 8h30m a.m. Almeria in Granada, and the surrounding district. Also at Madrid, Malaga, and Carthagena. The region shaken was parallel to the line of the Sierra-Nevada, and consequently to the axis of the Mediterranean basin. Within 3/4 of an hour, three terrible shocks and many slighter ones were felt at Almeria. At Albugnol five very violent shocks. The Salinas of the Bay of Rochetta were submerged, and much salt destroyed. Near Albugnol the sea remained quite calm. Commenced with a low subterranean noise. Houses fell or were much injured. Rochetta was for the most part ruined. Castel del Popolo, Bella Villa dell Palma, and Eniz were also destroyed. In Dalias men were buried beneath the ruins and in Feliz a bell fell from the church tower. At Albugnol the heavens were obscured by a dark mist, which resolved itself into a cloud, whence, in 10 minutes, five terrible flashes of fire (lightning?) issued, and after each flash a shock took place. A strong wind dispersed the clouds, and intense heat set in, which lasted until the 28th, as did also the shock. A mountain in the neighbourhood was cleft, and from the opening a stream of water poured out upon the lower parts of the town. Springs disappeared in some places, and new ones burst forth in others. Rivers were dammed up and changed their course.

1812, December 21, 10:30 (local time). There was a strong earthquake in the south of California, accompanied by an "enormous" tsunami in the Santa Barbara Strait (according to other sources, the tsunami was caused not by the first, but by a second, more powerful earthquake at 10:45 local time).

The following is known about the earthquake of the 21st. The church of San Fernando was seriously damaged. At Ventura, the church was so heavily damaged that the facade and dome had to be reset. At Santa Barbara, the buildings of the mission and the fort were damaged; recurrent shocks lasted several months; the residents left the settlement and lived in the open air for two or three months. At Santa Inez, the roofs on all structures collapsed; the corner of the church building collapsed. At Purisma, the earthquake lasted 4 minutes and was so strong, that one could only remain standing with difficulty. Fifteen minutes to 30 minutes after the first shock, a second shock occurred. The church collapsed and all one hundred Indian homes and the public kitchen, made of adobe and covered with tiles, crumbled or cracked; several residents were injured. The mission was later rebuilt in another place. In the focal zone (possibly near Santa Barbara), the alluvial ground cracked; new mud volcanoes and asphalt springs appeared.

This major earthquake caused damage in Santa Barbara, Ventura, and northern Los Angeles Counties. One fatality was reported, but many lives were probably saved by a strong foreshock about 15 minutes earlier that sent alarmed residents fleeing from buildings (Ref #542). Trask (Ref #2541) reports that this earthquake occurred in September -- the event has apparently been attributed to September, October, or December (Ref #79). Trask reports that the number of deaths is "variously estimated from thirty to forty-five" and gives a long account of the event.

locationName: IRAN:  KASHAN, QAMSAR, KAMU, KUSHIAN, CHUKA
comments:
May 12, 1844, 18:00 [local time], 33.6 N, 51.4 E, Quhrud-Kashan, magnitude 6.4. Preceded by a foreshock in the afternoon of 12 May 1844, a destructive earthquake occurred in the dihistans of Jaushaqan and Quhrud, particularly affecting the region between Chaqadeh, Kamu, Kuskan and Chugan. Chaqadeh was totally destroyed and only 3 out of its 103 inhabitants survived. In Qamsar and Quhrud all houses were destroyed or damaged and even garden walls were levelled with the ground. The old Caravanserai at Quhrud collapsed killing a number of people. Despite the warning of the foreshock, the total loss of life was estimated at 1500. The shock triggered landslides but caused no damage to the two masonry dams downstream of Qamsar and Quhrud, nor did it cause serious damage to Kashan where the minaret of the masjid-i jami was made to lean 2.1 metres between top and base. The earthquake was also felt in Isfahan, without causing any damage except to a small part of the masjid-i jami. Strong aftershocks continued for two weeks. (reference #1117)

May 12, 1844, 17:00 [local time], Kashan, Qohrud, 33.52 N, 51.36 E, magnitude 6.4, intensity VIII, 1500 killed. (reference #3437)

May 10-19, 1844 = 1260 A.H.L. Rabi'al-akhir 20-29; Abd al-Rahim Kalantar Zarrabi gives an approximate date of A.H.L. 1260, two hours before sunset, as time of occurrence of a destructive earthquake in Kashan region. Many houses were destroyed but only 1,500 persons were killed in the city and in the villages. Many people were fortunate in living out doors at the time. There was also a warning by a slight foreshock. Adib Sheibani a contemporary writer and poet of Kashan described in verse the destructive extent of this earthquake which occurred in 1260 A.H.L. Rabi'al-akkir 30, and affected surrounding towns and villages south-west of Kashan-Zahrud, Qamser, Kamu, Kushian and Chuka. The last named had only 3 survivors from a population of 103. Aftershocks continued for longer than two weeks (Naraqi 1967, p. 254). The foregoing descriptions by 'Abd al-Rahim and Sheibani seem to be in agreement of an earthquake of considerable magnitude at Kashan and are essentially complementary in outlining its effects. There seems good reason then to surmise a severe quake with epicentre at Chuka that extended in its effects to distant areas. (reference #1217)

May 12, 1844, Persia, Ispahan, Julpha, Azerbaijan and Irak, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

May 12, 1844-An earthquake shock was felt in Isfahan on 12 May 1844 which originated from a damaging earthquake 120 km to the north of the city that ruined the region of Kuhrud (Naraqi, 1966: 254-5; 1969: 20). In Isfahan, the shock caused no damage except to a small part of the Masjid-i Djuma. This monument, already structurally unsound and in need of strengthening well before the earthquake, was cracked by the shock and its two minarets were detached from the main body of the edifice. An inscription on the upper frieze of its south iwan gives the year 1261 hijri (1845) in which superficial repairs of the damage were carried out. Perrey confuses the effects of the Kuhrud earthquake with those of the earthquake that happened the following day in the Khalkhal district, 550 km from Isfahan and he says that the earthquake overturned numerous buildings in the city including the famous mosque of 'Joomah' (Perrey, 1845: 1448). This exaggerated description of the damage is repeated by Wilson, (Wilson, 1930: 119). There is absolutely no evidence that Isfahan suffered any damage from the 1844 earthquake except from the cracking of the walls of the Masjid-i Djuma. (reference #1130)

February 1845, Zhanghua, Taiwan Province, 24.1 N, 120.5 E, magnitude 6, intensity VIII. Houses of more than 4,000 families collapsed, over 380 inhabitants were killed and even more injured. The earthquake also struck Lugang southwest of Zhanghua destroying civilian houses. (reference #3939)
1847, March 8, 15:00 UTC. 32.450S, 71.270W, intensity X, casualties. (reference #1206)

December 3, 1848, Zhanghua, Taiwan Province, 24.1 N, 120,5 E, magnitude 6.75, intensity IX.

Civil and military officebuildings, prisons, storehouses, temples, mansions, military training centers in the town and in Lugang were all wiped out. City walls bulged and battlements fell down. 60-70% of the shops and civilian houses were devastated, the remainder tilted or partly collapsed. In total, more than 13,000 rooms in tile-roofed houses and 7,300 in thatched cottages in town and villages collapsed. There were fissures in the farmland, from which water gushed out. Over a thousand people (13 soldiers in Lugang) were killed, innumerable persons were injured.

Jiayi: A part of government office buildings, city walls and civilian houses in the city toppled down, more than 200 m long city walls and over 250 battlements were destroyed. Over 970 rooms in tile-roofed houses and 1,300 in thatched cottages collapsed, killing 21 inhabitants.

Yunlin and Tuku: More than 100 houses collapsed, killing more than 1,000 people.

Nantou: Some office buildings and civilian houses collapsed.

Tainan: A few houses collapsed in town and villages.

The earthquake also struck Gaoxiong, Danshui, Yuan and Penghu in Taiwan Province; Quanzhou and Fuzhou in Fujian Province.

Afterwards, quakes occurred from time to time. Many civilian houses (more tile structures than thatched cottages) collapsed now and then.

(above from reference #3939)
1850, Wushan, Gansu Province, 34.7 N, 104.9 E, magnitude 5, intensity VI. Houses collapsed and some people were killed. (reference #3939)

Major disaster caused by an earthquake with its maximum intensities in a 1 km wide northwest striking zone; the greatest intensity was near Cerro San Jacinto. The capital was transferred to Santa Tecla (but returned to the original location in 1895). (Reference #1554). Reference #1554 lists the date as April 16, 1854.

1862 July 10, 08h 15m, Ghana; MF 6.5. The earthquake of 10 July 1862 was a major event. It was preceded by 17 distinct foreshocks during a period of 6 weeks, and almost totally ruined much of the coastal area of Ghana and Togo, as well as the inland areas of Akwapim and south Ashanti.

In Accra the African part of the town sustained the greatest amount of damage, but because of the lightweight type of construction only three people were killed. In the European quarters even strongly built stone masonary houses were almost totally destroyed and public buildings were rendered uninhabitable. The forts of St James, Ussher and Christiansborg were shattered and being no longer habitable, they were evacuated. Near Accra the ground opened up in places, particularly near the Fort of St James where a large crack was formed in the rocks. Damage extended along the coast to the east for more than 260 km, from Winneba in the west to Anecho in Togo in the east. At Gounkovhe, Kewe and Tove Mission the shock was strong enough to uproot and overturn trees and to cause water to slosh out of tanks. Near Agome-Sewe the shock was very violent; the water in the nearby Mono river temporarily fell far below its normal level, presumably from slides that blocked its course further upstream. At Agotime and Botoe the shock was equally strong and at Gounkovhe the sea retired a distance of 80 m from the beach compared with the normal daily tidal change of 20 m. To the west of Accra the shock was strongly felt at the Fort of St George, Elmina and Cape Coast but without any damage.

Contemporary sources make it clear that contrary to some recent reports, there was considerable damage further inland. Damage seems to have been particularly severe in the regions of Akwapim, Asante and in Dahomey where there was considerable concern among the natives of Abomey who responded to the phenomenon with human sacrifices. The earthquake appears to have been comparatively strong further inland in the region of Si, 750 km north-northwest of Accra in the district of Dedugu where a number of adobe houses were cracked. The shock was widely felt in the Upper Volta and Mali, notably in the regions of Ira of the district of Dedugu, in the region of Molobala in the district of Segu and at Sokolo, a distance of 1200 km from Accra along the Niger. Indeed, if we trust contemporary reports, the shock was perceptible at Dakar in Senegal, 2100 km northwest of Accra, and throughout Sierra Leone.

Closely spaced aftershocks continued till 15 h, some of them being felt more to the west of Accra, causing additional damage. The strongest later shocks occurred on 11,12,19 and 28 July and also on 10 October. Minor shocks continued well into 1863. The earthquake paralysed commerce in Accra and trading stopped for many months. The town was gradually rebuilt and the Fort of Christiansborg was repaired and modernized into what is known today as Christiansborg Castle.

In general, the lack of details for all areas outside Accra make it difficult to determine the extent of the epicentral area. However, the information we have of this event for the coastal region from European sources and the fact that the earthquake was reported from inland areas as far north as Mali and the Upper Volta, indicate a major earthquake, as confirmed by our value MF, which is at least 6.5.

(above from reference #1214)

Over half of the Shilin streets in Taibei were damaged. Mountains collapsed and ground cracked along the coast of Jinbaoli, Jilong; the waves suddenly surged high, drowning several hundred people (It was also said that Jinbaoli shook, with ejection of water, the whole Jilong city collapsed).

2. Jinbaoli lay to the southwest of the present day Jilong.

Reference #414:

1867, December 18, morning local time. A strong earthquake, lasting about 15 seconds, occurred in the north of Taiwan Island. Chilung (Keelung) was completely destroyed. Many buildings collapsed and there were many victims at T'aipei. In all, it appears that several hundred inhabitants died. Large landslides occurred between Chilung and T'aipei, and several villages were destroyed. Cracks opened and closed in the ground. The mountain side split, and a large gorge was formed, into which flowed a stream from a volcanic cavern, saturated with sulphur springs and geysers. The earthquake was felt all over the island. Fifteen shocks were felt during the day at Chilung. Another strong earthquake occurred on the 20th.

Reference #11499:

There is evidence which shows that the 1867 Keelung, earthquake and tsunami killed more than 580 people. The coastal area from Jinshan to Keelung Harbor was the main affected area.

The results show that the 1867 Keelung earthquake was highly correlated with the parts of the Shanchiao Fault extending into the sea to the north-east. When the strike, dip and rake of the possible plane are N60E, 62, and -90 respectively, it can be inferred that the epicenter is 25.34°N, 121.91°E, the depth was 10 km, the moment magnitude (MW) was 7.0, and the local magnitude (ML) was 6.8.

1872, March 14, [17:20 local time]. There was a strong earthquake in Shimane Prefecture, where Nada district suffered especially. Light damage was recorded in Nima, Ochi, Ano and Mino districts. At Hamada, which was in the pleistoseismic zone, there were 543 homes damaged, 210 homes half destroyed and 168 homes completely destroyed; 92 homes burned down; 97 people were killed and 200 people were injured. In the Kanoashi district, the tremors were rather strong, but there was no destruction. In all 552 people died in the earthquake; about 5,000 homes collapsed.

The earthquake was preceded by foreshocks. An underground rumbling was heard four or five days before the main shock. On March 14, a rather strong foreshock was felt at about 11:00 [Local time] and was also accompanied by a rumble. A second strong foreshock occurred at 16:00, another one of less force occurred an hour later, and the main earthquake struck 10 minutes later. It was associated with large changes in the relief of the earth's surface. The main fault apparently crossed Hamada, in a northeast direction. The southeastern flank, made up of Tertiary formations, rose, while the northwestern flank, made up of pre-Tertiary formations, subsided. Corresponding vertical displacements were traced for 20 km on the coast.

There are reports that the visible changes in relief and the associated changes in sea level began not long before the main earthquake. After the earthquake, a tsunami was observed on the coast of three districts: Nima, Naka and Mino. It frightened the residents considerably, but did no damage.

July 11, 1890, 07:55 UTC, 36.5 N, 54.9 E, depth 10 km, magnitude 6.5, intensity 9-10, described below:

From the account of the Russian consul in Astrabad, it is known that the earthquake began with three successive tremors, the first of which was the strongest. In Astrabad (now Gorgan) ...all the buildings were damaged so much that the residents found it necessary to abandon them. In spite of the fact that 11 underground tremors occurred the first 3 days, ...not a single building in Astrabad was totally ruined.

According to the information received by the consulate, ...the village of Tash was destroyed by the earthquake; it lies 48 km from Astrabad along the road to Shakhrud. Only one building was left untouched; 150 people died.

In the village of Shaku-i-Bal, several homes were destroyed and 14 people died; 7 died in the village of Mudzhin.

The villages of Siyakh-Mergu of the Astrabad province and Khurnan Shakhrud were also leveled, but none of the residents there died. Many buildings in Kalay-Nou-Kharagan, Kelate-Khan, Kalay-Nou-Pain, and others in the cities of Bastam and Shakhrud were damaged.

The earthquake was accompanied by a large number of aftershocks: 60 tremors were noted through August 31, including one earthquake of intensity 6-7, nine of intensity 6, one of intensity 5-6, ten of intensity 5, nine of intensity 4, and 22 of intensity 3; all of these occurred in the first 20 days.

In Shakhrud, Bestam, Tash, Kalenou, Khuran, and Siyakh-Mergu (12-15 km from the epicenter), the intensity of the earthquake reached 9 on the MSK-64 scale; in the villages of Mudzhin, Kelate-Khan (25 km), Shaku-i-Bal, Shakhkukh-Pain and others, the intensity was 8; in Astrabad (Gorgan) it was 7 (50 km). The epicenter of the earthquake was located between the villages of Tash, Bestam, and Shakhrud at 36.50o N, 54.85o. The intensity at the epicenter according to these reports is rated at 9-10.

1895, January 17, 11:00 local time (08:30 UTC), Quchan, which was destroyed by an earthquake 14 months ago (November 17, 1893) and immediately rebuilt, was again destroyed on January 17 (37.1 N, 58.4 E, magnitude 6.8). Many lives were lost, 100 women being crushed in one bath. Extreme weather prevailed causing terrible suffering. At least four slight, but distinct, shocks of earthquakes had been felt in Mashhad during 3 days, but no damage had been done, (The Times, January 21, 1895, p.59). The first shock of an earthquake occurred at Quchan on January 17 and was felt at noon, and in three minutes time the place was in complete ruins. A very great number of persons are said to have perished. In many instances the unfortunate people were burnt to death, but most of them were crushed. Six hundred persons were entombed in the Mosque while engaged in prayer, and another 600 perished in the various baths. The suffering of the survivors, most of whom perished from exposure to intense cold, was terrible. The after spectacle that presented itself was simply one mass of earth and bricks. Not a single building remained; all without exception were leveled to the ground.

A correspondent writes under date of Nashhad January 30: "The journey of 92 miles was as severe as I have ever experienced; the cold was awful, and sleeping in these caravanserais is by no means pleasant...Quchan was reached at 8:15 A.M. on January 23. The spectacle presented was simply one mass of bricks and mortar; without exception every building was leveled to the ground .... The telegraph instruments were smashed and the wires were thrown down for several miles. At the time of the catastrophe great numbers had crowded in from the neighboring villages to sell their wares and many of them have perished. It is difficult to arrive at a correct estimate as to the amount of mortality - but from my interviews with those of the survivors whom I could rely on I am inclined to think that as many as 11,000 have perished, though I feel bound to add that one of the consular authorities puts it at a much lower figure .... The shocks still take place occasionally" (The Times, March 15, 1895 p.15b).

Jan 17, 08:30 GMT. 37.l N. 58.5 E. (Savarenskii et al 1962). The center of the earthquake appears to have been near Kuchan, a town which has been damaged or destroyed by earthquake several times during the present century, the last occasion being in 1893, when it was completely reduced to ruins. After this the town was rebuilt on the old site, but the houses were made very largely of wood.

1895, Jan 17. An earthquake occurred shortly before noon on Jan 17, 1895, in Quchan. The earthquake totally destroyed Quchan and a number of villages in the upper Atrak valley, killing about 1000 people. The earthquake, which was followed by incessant shocks until the next morning, utterly ruined the Imamzadeh of Sultan Ibrahim (which had been repaired after the earthquake of 1893), killing one of its inmates. Public baths, the bazaar, the Customs House, the Governor's residence, and the post and telegraph offices were destroyed with casualties. With the exception of a few small shanties, almost all the houses, even those rebuilt after 1893 with timber and light roofs, were ruined. Because of the lightness of the building materials, however, and probably because of the foreshock that warned people, the loss of life in Quchan was much less than it would otherwise have been. In all, about 770 people perished, including many from neighbouring villages who happened to be in town. (ref #1117)

February 15.--The first shock of the earthquake which caused so much damage and loss of life in the province of Esmeraldas was felt at 10 o'clock on Jan. 31st, the disturbance continuing at short intervals until Feb. 6th. In the neighborhood of Port Limon four small islands disappeared. These islands were inhabited by fishermen, who escaped in small boats, which they were at sea for three days, until the water became sufficiently calm to enable them to reach the mainland. 1913 (mistakenly 1914), Mar 14, 16:45 [local time]. There was an earthquake sourced near Sangihe Is. A number of studies... mention it was accompanied by tsunami waves. This is mistaken. In fact, flooding of a different nature was taken for a tsunami. The original accounts mention the following.

The earthquake was felt most strongly on the southeast of Sangihe I. It lasted 4 + 2 min and was accompanied by a loud rumble. At Menalu, situated on swampy ground, piles of homes were ripped out of the ground and homes sank to one side or collapsed altogether. People were thrown to the ground. Various structures collapsed at Enemawira, Peta and Tabukan.

At Tamako, the school and some homes and shops were destroyed. The same occurred at Manganitu, but there was no serious destruction at Kandhar. 20 people died. Numerous collapses and rock falls occurred along the entire rocky coast of the island, including the Kandhar region. In Menalu Bay, a chunk 1000 m3 in volume collapsed into the water from a height of 80 m. To the west of Menalu, a mud flow, which traveled 1 km along the plain, came down from the 80m Endongo hill. 29 homes with 117 residents were buried under a mass of earth 1000m long, 700m wide and 6m thick. The loose soil covers on the island were dissected by numerous cracks; water gushed forth from some of them; some areas of the ground subsided. In particular, the Menalu plain subsided; some areas of beach disappeared; here and there the sea wedged into the land in narrow winding branches. As a result of the subsidence of the ground, ground water came to the surface. All this led to the swamping of the plain and the residents of Menalu were obliged to move elsewhere. In Peta Bay, a strip of the south shore 200m long subsided 2m; the top of the bay was also swamped. The coast at Tamako subsided by 1/2m, and an area of coast 180m long subsided 1m at Tabukan. The relief of the sea bottom apparently was unchanged, as all the anchorages continued to function.

The Endongo mud flow backed up a small river. It overflowed.

After the earthquake, pouring rain began. The water breached the blockage and flooded the underlying locality. The river at Manganitu overflowed catastrophically, washing out all the bridges.

The earthquake was less strong on the small islands between the islands of Sulawesi and Mindanao. Nevertheless, on Siau I, people couldn't remain standing; at many places the ground cracked, avalanches and rockfalls occurred, various brick structures were damaged and some huts sank to one side; one person died and several were injured. There were no reports on the subsidence of sections of the coast.

On the Talaud I as well, cracks appeared in the ground and water issued from them; public buildings (the kirk, the school, etc.) cracked substantially, there were no victims. One local captain stated that at the same time as the roar, he saw a large elevation form at sea several km to the west of the island.

The earthquake lasted 1/2 min on the Sarangani Islands, south of Mindanao I; pillars and large trees fell. At Davao, very strong oscillations lasted, according to different estimates, from 2 to 5 min. The cracks which formed in the ground ejected water and sand. People were thrown to the ground. Several stone walls collapsed. Huts made of palm leaves sank to one side.

Strong tremors, with almost no damage, were recorded at Baganga, Talakogon, Kotabato, and Butuan [Philippines]. The water in the Agusan River began to move markedly in an east-west direction; boats rocked strongly. Seamen in boats, sailing near Surigao, felt the earthquake; waves appeared on the surface of the water

1923, September 1, at 02:58:49. 35.25 N, 139.5 E, magnitude 8.2. There was a catastrophic earthquake in the Kanto region. The source of the earthquake, and the moderate tsunami which it generated, included Sagami Gulf and the Boso Peninsula, as well as adjacent areas of the sea and land, and apparently was oriented latitudinally. The assumed length of the source was 150-200 km.

In the pleistoseismic zone, the earthquake was preceded by an underground roar, like peals of distant thunder. Then began abrupt vertical shocks, which became horizontal oscillations, lasting 6 minutes. People could not remain standing, trees broke or were uprooted. A cloud of smoke was ejected from the Mihara volcano on Oshima Island.

The area of destruction included the prefectures of Kanagawa, Tokyo, Chiba, Shizouka and part of Saitama, Yamanashi, and Ibaraki. Homes caught fire at 134 places in Tokyo after the shocks. The enormous conflagration which broke out raged for three days and destroyed three quarters of the city. Fire storms also developed, in one of which, 38,000 people assembled in the city square died. Petroleum storage tanks burst at Yokohama and Yokosuka; the oil spreading on the ground and water took fire; some of the residents who were taking refuge from the earthquake on ships and boats were burned.

According to official data, 695,000 homes in Japan suffered damage: 55% of these were burned, 12% collapsed completely, 13% collapsed partly, about 20% suffered seriously from the tremors, and 0.2% were washed away by the tsunami waves. Of the total number of structures, the number of damaged homes was: 86.5% Kanagawa Prefecture, including 96% at Yokohama, and 81% at other places; 48% in Tokyo Prefecture, including 6.3% each in Saitama and Shizouka Prefectures; 3.5% in Yamanashi Prefecture; 0.2% in Ibaraki Prefecture. Brick and stone homes suffered especially, mainly in the foreign quarters. Almost 100,000 people died, and at least 47,000 injured; 2,144 people and 166 were injured in washed away homes. There were many residents of Tokyo who were holidaying on the Pacific Coast among the drowned. The losses amounted to more than 5 billion yen. Many artistic, historical and scientific valuables were lost.

The earthquake was accompanied by numerous aftershocks. Forty-four perceptible shocks were felt in the first 12 hours, 88 in the next 12 hours, and 60 and 47 in the next two 12-hour periods. The low-sensitivity seismographs at Tokyo registered 1700 shocks in the first three days.

1927, March 7, at 18:30 [local time]. There was a catastrophic earthquake in Kyoto Prefecture on Tango Peninsula. This earthquake was a result of the displacement of the Tango peninsula block to the northeast and the tilting of the block. The faults, bounding the block on the southwest and the southeast, revived. Along the first of these, the Gomura fault, the relative horizontal displacements of the blocks were 250 cm and the vertical ones were 70 cm; along the second, Yamada fault, the vertical displacements were 470 cm and the horizontal ones were 80 cm. The length of the fresh Yamada fault which was traced on land was 7.5 km, that of the Gomura fault (which represents a series of linked smaller faults) was 18 km. However, the latter, as follows from the results of the echo sounding of coastal waters and the distribution of the focuses of the aftershocks of the earthquakes, undoubtedly continued along the sea floor for another 35 km from shore. The displacements of the flanks of the fault were apparently greater on the bottom than on land. Ships off the coast felt a strong seaquake. The passengers on a small boat at Shioe felt like they were being tossed up in the air. The Gomura fault was apparently the main fault of the earthquake, and eyewitnesses related that the Yamada fault was formed after the strong tremors had begun in this locality.

The earthquake did great damage in the epicenter zone, which is one of the centers of the silk weaving industry of the country; about 3,000 people died. It seems that Mineyama suffered especially. Here, 988 out of 998 homes completely collapsed or burned down; 1,122 people died. Sixteen fires broke out in the city in the first 10 minutes after the earthquake.

According to fishermen, at Mizu (6.5 km northeast of the Gomura fault), 2.5 hours before the earthquake, the sea level dropped 1.2-1.5 m and the bottom of the harbor was partly exposed. This situation lasted until the earthquake. At Shioe (4.5 km southwest of the fault), fishermen noted a small rise of water, about 15 cm, less than 30 minutes before the earthquake. At Tsuiyama, according to a tide gauge record, the sea level was 4-6 cm higher than usual on the day of the earthquake, possibly, however because of a strong northeastern wind.

After the earthquake, different parts of the coast rose and fell in accordance with the general nature of the tectonic movements. West of the Gomura fault, the shore rose 80 to 20 cm on a 9 km stretch while it rose only 10-15 cm east of the fault. At Tsuiyarna, the tide gauge record showed that the shore rose 5 cm immediately after the start of the earthquake.

The earthquake apparently caused a small tsunami, which was observed in the region of the Gomura Fault.

The earthquake destroyed a number of houses southeast of Smyrne, in the Guma valley and in the plain Koutsouc Menteres, from Gazemir in the north up to CelIat in the south. The village Torbali was completely destroyed. In the country of Smyrne tens of houses were destroyed and hundreds suffered damages. Magnesia, Alasehir (Philadelfia) and Ousac (Temenothyres) were seriously damaged. 30 people were killed. Phenomena of liquefaction and cracks in the ground were observed. It was strongly felt in Chios, moderately in Ikaria and Samos and lightly in Naxos. It was also felt up to the sea of Marmara, Athens and Cythera (AOA, 1932; Sieberg, 1932b; Ambraseys, 1988b). It was followed by aftershocks the largest of which occurred in the same day with the main shock. (reference #4408)

NOTE: The total effects are listed with the earthquake on 1928 April 14.

1928, April 14 and 18. On April 14 and 18, 1928, earthquakes of magnitude 6.75 originated in southern Bulgaria, resulting in what has been called the most serious earthquake calamity in the history of that country. The epicenter of the earlier shock was near Chirpan, where there was great destruction; that of the latter was somewhat farther west near Popovitsa (Papazli). Faults were produced with maximum throw of 3 to 4 meters. (ref #1006)

1928, April 14 to 18 [effects listed with April 14 event]. Intensity XI. Destruction of the towns of Plovdiv, Borisovgrad and Tchirpan and 240 villages. 105 killed, 74,750 houses destroyed, 264000 inhabitants without shelter (of a population of 488,000). Cracks in the ground, rails twisted. According to G. Bontcheff, the earthquake was local; its main cause lies in the instability of the masses which are at the base of the valley. (refe #1093)

1928, April 18, 19:22:48 UTC. 42.1 N, 25 E, magnitude 7.0, S. Bulgaria, intensity X (Philippoupole). The earthquake was preceded by foreshocks the largest of which occurred on 14 April (09:30, 42.15° N, 25.28° E, M = 6.8) and it was also destructive. It was followed by many aftershocks the largest of which occurred on 25 April (09:25:, M = 5.7). These earthquakes caused large destructions in Philippoupole, Tsipran and Papasli. In Philippoupole 8,000 houses collapsed. Totally 74,570 houses were overturned in 240 cities and villages. 127 people were killed and 1,735 were injured. During the generation of the earthquake of 14 April (M =6.8), two parallel normal faults were created in the ground with an east-west direction, a distance between them equal to about 15 km and a fall to the south side of the north fault and to the north side of the south fault by about 50 cm. The length of the north fault was equal to 38 km and of the south equal to 42 km. During the generation of the main shock (M = 7.0), the ground rupture was extended more to the west and turned to the northwest. The total length of the rupture which was caused by the main shock was about 60 km while the northeast side of the fault was sunk by more than 3m near the village Popovitsa. In Komotine the earthquake caused the collapse of a house and fissures in walls. In Thessaloniki, it caused panic and fissures in the walls of some houses and of some building in the beach. In the area of Kapoutzidi two houses collapsed. The inhabitants got out of the houses and many of them spent the night in the open air. In Eleutheroupole, the police station collapsed. It was felt in several places of Greece. Some days before the earthquake the mineral springs around Philippoupole overflowed and the water that came out was very warm (Newspaper of Balkans, 19.4.1928; AOA, 1932; Sieberg, 1932b; Montandon, 1953; Richter, 1958). Isoseismals for the largest foreshock, for the main shock and for its largest aftershock are cited in the atlas of UNESCO (Shebalin et al., 1974b) and by Papazachos et al. (1997b). (ref #4408)

Reference #414:

1928, December 19 (mistakenly 28), 19:37 [local time]. There was a strong earthquake which affected all Mindanao Island. Many homes collapsed at Cotabato. Zamboanga and Davao did not suffer, although the tremors were very strong. A tsunami was observed in Ilana Bay. A wave rose up the Mindanao River to Cotabato, where it did damage. Four people died and 102 were injured. Gutenberg, Richter (1954): 19.XII; llh37mlOs; 7 N., 124 E, magnitude 7.3.

Reference #1187:

1928, December 19, 7:39 p.m. [local time]. SW. Cotabato: Cotabato - earthquake of Intensity vII. Surrounding area within a radius of about 80 kms - Intensity VI... The town of Cotabato suffered most in its buildings; it was certainly the nearest town to the E of the epicentre but the main cause responsible for the numerous ruins was the poor condition of the buildings, most of them badly constructed and the rest old and in bad repair. These conditions were aggravated by the soft and swampy nature of the soil along the river bank. Cotabato was once upon a time a swamp. Only a few sections are solid ground and the rest filled with sand and other light materials. Most of the houses are built over this filling, that is why so many houses fell down; whilst, in nearby places where there is firmer ground, light structures withstood the shocks. Up the river, ruins occurred on its banks and in small islets in the swamps and lakes. Its epicentre was located in the NE part of the Celebes Sea. The quake hit Cotabato killing 93 persons; hundreds rendered homeless. The greatest sufferer from the quake was Cotabato where all the old buildings were razed to the ground. Those that remained standing were considered dangerous to live in and people for a time put up temporary shelters in the open.

April 1, 1936, Northeast of Lingshan, Guangxi Autonomous Region, 22.5 N, 109.4 E, depth 7 km, magnitude 6.75, intensity IX.

The first, second, third and ninth regions stretching along Lingshan County and the villages in the northern part of Hepu County, especially the northwestern foot of Mt. Luoyangshan were most violently hit. In Liue, Gaotang and other villages along the foothill, more than 50% of the houses collapsed and some villages were even entirely destroyed. Landslides, ground fissures and subsidences occurred at many places. 10% of the people were killed.

In Lingshan County, 5,181 rooms of civilian houses and schools collapsed. 1,082 rooms were destroyed, 58 people were killed and 187 injured. In the northern part of Hepuxian, 679 rooms collapsed, 34 people were killed and 76 injured.

Rengxian: An old mud house was destroyed with, a person killed.

Xingye (northwest of the present-day Yulin): The ground subsided at three places.

Guixian: The ground subsided and houses collapsed.

Lianjiang: Six shabby mud houses collapsed.

Bobai : Some rooms fell, the enclosing walls on the south street collapsed and a girl was killed.

Pingnan: A section (more than 6 m long) of an enclosing wall collapsed.

Xinyi: Roof-tiles fell and walls of shabby houses cracked.

Guilin: More than 6 m of the city wall was damaged.

Liuzhou: Windows and tiles rattled, plaster fell, walls of the office building of Beitangxiang cracked for some 30 cm long.

Luchuan, Beiliu: Ground fissured in farmland at the adjacent region between the two counties.

Hepu: Old shabby houses were destroyed and ordinary houses were slightly damaged.

(above from reference #3939)

August 1, 1936, 14:24:30 local time, South of Tianshui, Gansu Province, 34.2 N, 105.7 E, magnitude 6, intensity VIII.

Church enclosures and other walls collapsed. Most forts on hills were destroyed. 4,459 rooms collapsed in towns and villages. An earth mound split and collapsed near Maping, Xingshan. The ground warped. 115 people were killed, 31 injured and more than 600 domestic animals were crushed to death. The range of destruction was about 80 km.

Qin'an: Some house walls near the city gate fell and some cliffs collapsed.

Lixian : Some dozens of rooms collapsed, more than 10 people were killed or injured in the city. Ground fissures and landslides occurred in the western region.

Qingshui: A room of the county government office and a watchtower collapsed. The 3rd and the 4th district suffered heavy losses.

Xihe: Houses in the city were slightly damaged. In Yan'guan Town more than 1,500 rooms collapsed (there was also a heavy rain). 16 people were killed, 5 seriously wounded and 22 slightly injured. Jingchuan: A cave dwelling collapsed in Hujiazhuang (1.5 10m from the city). 3 people were killed.

Haiyuan : Trees were broken and many houses collapsed.

Tongwei : Houses collapsed, people and domestic animals were wounded.

Fengxian: A civilian house and other dilapidated houses outside the eastern city gate collapsed.

In addition, the shock was felt in Longde, Wudu, Pingliang, Huixian, Lanzhou, Zhangxian, Longxi and Chengxian in Gansu Province; and Xi'an, Lintong in Shaanxi Province.

(above from reference #3939)

February 1, 1942, 01:30:47 Beijing time, Simao, Yunnan Province, 23.1 N, 100.3 E, magnitude 6.75, intensity VIII.

Macroseismic epicenter 22.8 N, 101.0 E

Simao: Hundreds of buildings collapsed or split in the county's offices, warehouses, granaries, schools, temples as well as civilian dwellings without a single one left intact. The city walls collapsed for more than 100 m in length, the north and east gate towers completely collapsed. All watch towers inside or outside the city were destroyed. The same fate befell Yixiang Village 10 km from the city. More than 90 persons were killed and innumerable people injured. Hundreds of domestic animals were killed.

More than 20 shocks occurred from Dec. 26 to 31, 1941 (among them the Lancang Earthquake magnitude = 7), houses suffered slight damage. At mid-night of Jan 19, 1942, two shocks occurred followed by another strong rock in the next morning, bringing down a dozen public and private buildings in and outside the city. More than 10 shocks occurred up to the 22nd of the month. In all, more than 280 aftershocks took place spanning a period of more than 40 days since the Feb. 1 violent earthquake.

(above from reference #3939)

locationName: JAPAN:  OFF SOUTHEAST COAST KII PENINSULA
comments:
Reference #414:

On December 7, 1944, at 13:35 [local time] there was an earthquake in the south of Japan in the Tonankai area, with source off the southeastern coast of the Kii Peninsula, at Kumano-Yada. The earthquake and resulting tsunami caused great destruction and loss of life. Some 998 people died and 2,135 were seriously injured; 26,135 homes were totally destroyed and 46,950 homes were half destroyed; 3,059 homes were washed away and 11 burned down.

The force of the earthquake diminished comparatively quickly with distance from the source. Thus, there was much destruction at Shingu, Temma and vicinity, on the eastern coast of the Kii Peninsula. On the south of the Kii Peninsula, west of Kushimnto, only stone barriers and clay walls were destroyed; the roofs fell from some homes. No cases of even partial destruction of homes were recorded on the western coast of the peninsula at Tanabe.

The southeastern coast of the Kii Peninsula dropped several tens of centimeters during the earthquake.

The tsunami was strongest on this same coast, which is closest to the source.

Reference #150:

(Iida, 1984) lists total 1,223 deaths, 17,347 houses collapsed, 3,129 houses washed away.

Reference #414:

On January 13, 1945, at 3:38 [local time] there was an earthquake with source on the south of Aichi Prefecture. In Atsumi Bay, 5,539 homes were completely destroyed and 11,706 were partly destroyed as the result of the earthquake; 6,603 non-residential structures were completely destroyed and 9,976 were half destroyed. Some 1,961 people died and 896 were injured. The large number of victims is explained by the fact that during the war, the workers in the military plants lived in crowded conditions, in hostels. The earthquake caused a weak tsunami.

May 25, 1948, 15:11:21 local time, Litang, Sichuan Province, 29.5 N, 100.5 E, depth 18 km, magnitude 7.3, intensity X.

Three temples in and around Xungba, Zangba, Mola and Dewolabo collapsed. Xiduo Temple toppled down partly. 92-93% of the civilian houses collapsed. Most villages were destroyed completely. In all, more than 600 houses collapsed, and over 1000 houses were damaged. From Reshuitang northwest of Litang in the north to south of Dewu in the southeast, en echelon fissures trending NW-SE extended about 70 km. A huge amount of water and sand gushed out from the fractures in Litang, Zangba, Xungba and Dewu basins. The banks of Wuliang River near Xiewu southeast of Dewu collapsed, blocking the river for 5 days. Hot springs dried up. More than 800 persons were killed, and several hundred persons were wounded. More than 800 domestic animals were killed or wounded.

Litang: Civilian houses collapsed seriously. Temples partially collapsed. Landslides and ground fissures occurred near the city.

Daocheng: 31 houses collapsed and 46 houses were damaged. A landslide occurred for a length of 40m. The ground fissured with water gushing out. A few persons and domestic animals were killed or wounded.

Yajiang: Individual old walls collapsed or cracked. Houses fell partly in Xi'eluo. Cliffs fell down.

Mianning: A brick memorial archway in front of the county goverment cracked. Fissures occurred in the upper part, crevices occurred in brick walls. Roof tiles fell down in Shilong.

Shocks were also felt in Batang, Xinlong, Kangding and Daofu.

More than 180 shocks occurred from May 25 to August 20, during this period those on July 17 and 21 and August 1l were more violent. More houses collapsed In villages.

(above from reference #3939)

1000 deaths and severe damage. (reference #45)

1948 Oct 5, 20:12:07 UTC. 37.95N, 58.32E, depth 18 km, 7.3 MS, intensity IX-X.
"...The Ashkhabad earthquake of 1948 was one of the major seismic events of recent years.... Buildings made of raw brick were destroyed, and almost all collapsed. There was also major damage to the ferro-concrete support framework of the buildings. In the area of Ashkhabad, horizontal deformations in the ground appeared in the form of fissures and gaps... Their width was measured as 1 or several centimeters... In the northern end of Komsomol Street...the width of the cracks reached 0.1 m. Water pipes ruptured in this area.

Tens of thousands of people were killed and injured in this earthquake. All the private and public buildings in many of the villages around the city were destroyed, and most of them collapsed. The intensity of the earthquake in the villages of Kara-Tokmak, Kuru-Gaudan, Annau, Kurtli, and others is estimated not less than 9.

In Kuru-Gaudan, 25 km southeast of Ashkhabad, ..."more than 10 new springs appeared. ... The water level in the wells increased 2 m. A spring to the west of the village quintupled its output.... In the eastern part of the village the water pipes burst; pipes swelled in several places owing to the compression of the ground... Displacements of 90 cm in depth occurred on the tops of hills, on watersheds, and on the peak areas of slopes. Fissures measured up to 60 cm in width". "The fissures extended hundreds of meters in length."

Ye. M. Butovskaya writes about the destruction in Kuru-Gaudan: "The rupture and thrust of one part of a pipeline onto another over a length of 3 m were not uncommon. Waterlines swelled to a height of 1 m; roofs here flung farm cattle sheds to a distance of several meters in a northeast-southwest direction; ... monolith brick columns were sheared in 70 x 80 cm sections."

Many reports describe the falling of heavy commodity trains, which were thrown from the railroad tracks in the Ashkhabad region and the Annau station, and some give a detailed engineering analysis of the falling of monuments and brick columns, and the tilting of a large iron-concrete elevator.

Sump volcanoes formed 4-5 km north-northwest of Ashkhabad and in the Kuru-Gaudan region.

Surface fissures also formed in the opposite direction of Kuru-Gaudan, 27 km northwest of Ashkhabad. Therefore the surface of the rupture, partially seen on the surface extended no less than 70 km.

Much destruction occurred in the region of the Iranian cities of Deregez, Khakester, and Kelat. More than 30 villages in this region were reduced to piles of debris under which many people lost their lives. There was a multitude of surface fissures of diverse direction and width. The force of the earthquake at its epicenter is rated at intensity 9-10.

On January 19, 1958, at 9:09 [local time] there was a strong magnitude 7.6 earthquake in the coastal regions of Ecuador and Colombia. Approximately 30% of Esmeraldas (Ecuador) was destroyed, including the children's department of the hospital, where three children died. In all, 11 persons died and 45 were injured as a result of the earthquake. Water mains were broken and power transmission lines were damaged. The Esmeraldas-Quito highway collapsed at many places. Many other roads of the country were made impassable by cracks and fallen trees. According to press reports, a landslide from the slopes of the Andes at Panado village buried a hundred people. The earthquake was destructive in the cities on the northern coast of the country and was strong from Latacunga to Quito, Ibarra and Tulcan. It was felt at Guayaquil.

In Colombia, Tumaco suffered most of all. Several old residences and a wooden home for railway workers collapsed. The large brick ovens used for drying pulp collapsed at the sawmills. The brick wall of the new church cracked. The walls of a number of other buildings cracked. The rafters of the roof of the tide gauge box set up at the end of the breakwater (on Del Morro Island) came out of their grooves, the roof collapsed and carried the instrument and the box with it into the water. Pile wooden homes rocked so strongly in a north-south direction, that 8 cm gaps appeared in the ground at the foundations. The corrugated roof of the lower shed was bent in by the collision of two adjacent sheds. The embankments connecting Tumaco Island with adjacent islands crumbled and cracked. Bottles, vases, dishes, cameras, typewriters, etc. fell and broke. Water splashed out of tubs. The telegraph link between Tumaco and La Espriella was out of commission for twenty four hours because of fallen posts. A resident of the city was injured. Eyewitnesses between Tumaco and Esmeraldas found it difficult to remain standing. Water gushed out of cracks in the ground on Manglares Cape, and trees fell.

The earthquake was strong at Pasto, Ipyales, Imuesa, Tuquerres and Sapuyas; it lasted about 40 minutes, but did not cause material damage. At Cali and Pereira, the population was frightened. At Bogota, the pendulums stopped on the clocks at the seismic station.

Many recurrent shocks were felt at the epicentral zone; the two strongest occurred on January 19 at 9:45 and on February 1. According to geodesic data, the breakwater at Tumaco was shifted 1 cm along the vertical by the earthquake.

The earthquake gave rise to a tsunami. A launch almost sank at Esmeraldas; four customs officers died. The waves damaged Tumaco and Guayaquil.

(above from reference #415)

February 21, 1960, 08:13:31 UTC, 36 N 4.1 E, magnitude 5.6. In the Djebel Choukott, which forms one of the southern secondary ranges of the Tell Atlas, between Mounts Hodna and Titteri. Local damage to the village of Melouza and the douar of Beni-Ilman; many of the gourbis were destroyed; there were 47 dead and 88 injured; most of the victims were old people, women and children (of whom 15 were killed in a school). In Algeria, the coastal ranges, the mountains of the inner Tell region and the Saharan Atlas are known to be periodically the scene of movements whose epicentres occur at various points along the active chain. (reference #1040)

February 26, 1961, 18:10:48.7 UTC, near coast of Kyushu Japan, 31.6 N, 131.2 E, magnitude 7-7.25, depth about 74 km. Two killed, 7 injured, and over 170 homes destroyed at Miyazaki. 3-foot tsunami observed in southwest Shikoku Island. (reference #45)

February 27, 1961, 3:11 [local time]. There was an earthquake with a source 80 km long off the eastern coast of Kyushu Island, at Hyuga-Nada. It was felt with an intensity of 6 degrees (IV JMA) in Miyazaki Prefecture and in the eastern parts of Kumamoto and Kagoshima Prefectures. It caused a tsunami, which was registered by tide gauges from the Ryukyu Islands to the Boso Peninsula and Hachijo Island. (reference #414)

A long seismic crisis began in Ethiopia at the end of May 1961 and continued till September; in four months, over 3,500 shocks occurred; the two major ones caused serious damage, particularly at Karakore (10 deg 32 min N., 39 deg 56 min E.) and at Majit6 (10 deg 44 min N., 39 deg 50 min E.). There were some 30 victims, most of whom were crushed beneath rock avalanches; mud houses built on eucalyptus wood frames stood up better than houses built of stone. Major landslides occurred, damaging roads and bridges; a deep fissure, in places 25 ft deep by 3 ft wide with a throw of 6 to 7 ft, formed over a distance of 30 to 40 km along the road from Addis Ababa to Asmara. The epicentral region (between Dessye and Ankober) is situated at the junction of the Ethiopian rift and the main NNW.-SSE. tectonic feature which forms the western limit of the triangular Afar depression. The seismicity of this region, which is considerable, may be related to the many faults and graben found to exist in the eastern part of Ethiopia. (reference #1040)

June 1, 1961, 23:29:21.2 UTC, 10.4 N, 39.9 E, depth 33 km, magnitude 6.5. 5 killed, many injured, and village of Kara-Kore destroyed. Felt at Addis Ababa. (reference #45)

June 1961, Ethiopia, major destruction. (reference #1250)

July 30, 1962, 20:18:52.3 UTC, 5.2 N, 76.4 W, depth 69 km, magnitude 6.75. 47 killed, 300 injured in Caldas Province; property damage over 400,000 square mile area. Felt at Balboa Height, C.Z. (reference #45)

July 30, 1962, 20:18:43.3 UTC, 5 N, 76.3 W, depth 45 km, magnitude 6.9. The earthquake of 30 July 1962 was the most violent felt in Colombia for 10 years; it caused over 40 deaths and injured over 300; at Manizales, capital of the state of Caldas, one of the cathedral towers fell in, crushing several people, including the poet Guillermo Gonzales Ospina and his wife; the aqueduct supplying the town with water was destroyed. At Pereira, about 500 km south-west of Manizales, a factory employing 200 women fell on the workers. At Cali, in the upper valley of the Rio Cauca, the Church of Perpetual Aid collapsed, killing at least 5 people. Damage and victims were reported in towns often quite far from the epicentre; even in Bogota, cracks appeared in buildings. The nature of the damage was carefully studied, in particular that suffered by the church in Cali, the Don Felix factory at Pereira, the San Jose Church at Pereira, Manizales cathedral, and the churches and houses of Sonson. (reference #1040)

September 1, 1962, 35.6 N, 49.8 E, magnitude 7.2, 100 km fault, 12,200 deaths, in Buiyn-Zara. (reference #1138)

On September 1, 1962, at about 19h.20m. (GMT) Northwest Iran was shaken by a major earthquake. Preliminary instrumental data indicates the following characteristics:

B.C.I.S.: H = 19h.20m.39.9s +1.4; h = 27 km + 9 km; 35.63 N + 0.03, 49.87 E + 0.02

U.S.C.G.S.: H = 19h.20m.38.5s; h = 21 km; 35.6 N, 50.0

The Buyin-Zara earthquake of 1 September 1962 originated on the Ipak fault and it was felt over most of Northern Iran. This newly named fault and its branches run for 64 miles, from Ipak, about W-O5 deg N, across the mountains south of Buyin, to Takhrijin, 4 miles west of Ab-i-Garm. During the earthquake of September 1, 1962 and its aftershocks, at least 64 miles of surface rupture occurred progressively along this line, and at least two stages of progressive faulting were involved. Most probably, one from Rudak from where the fracture progressed east to Ipak, and a deeper fracture, with very weak surface evidence from Indrejin progressing east to Tofak.

The earthquake killed 12,225 and injured 2,776 persons. It damaged beyond repair 21,310 houses and killed 35% of the livestock in the area. The maximum intensity of the shock did not exceed IX MM. Small landslides and rock falls occurred on steep slopes and temporary springs were formed.

(above from reference #3745)

September 1, 1962, 12,000 killed, 3,000 injured, $30 million damage. (reference #1250)

On 1 September 1962 an earthquake shook a rural area of Western Iran. It caused damage in 324 villages, killing 12,225 people and injuring 2,776. (reference #3689)

April 5, 1965, 03:12:54.2 UTC, 37.7 N, 21.8 E, Southern Greece, magnitude 6, depth 34 km. Central Peloponnesus sustained 32 deaths, 200 injuries, and major property damage. Many villages were extensively damaged. (reference #45)

April 5,1965, 03:12:54 UTC, 37.7 N, 21.8 E, magnitude 6.2, depth 34 km. Destructive earthquake in the central Peloponnese, in the mountainous region west of Megalopolis; 1,900 houses destroyed, 3,834 made uninhabitable, 6,256 badly damaged; 18 persons killed, 155 injured; emotion was all the greater as the earthquake of 5 April was the fourth destructive shock in Greece since 9 March. The following intensities were recorded: X in Arkadia at Apiditsa, Khoremi, Kiparissia, Kalivia and Karyon; in Ilia at Krounoe; in Messinia at Staximon; IX in Arkadia at Troknis and Marathousa, in Ilia at Makrisia, in Messinia at Oechalia; macroseismic area: 530,000 square kilometres; the shock was felt as far away as Crete. (reference #1040)

March 8, 1966, 05:29:14 (local time), East of Longyao, Hebei Province, 37 deg 21 min N, 114 deg 55 min E, depth 8 km, magnitude 6.8, intensity IX.

The meizoseismal region was from Shijiazhui of Xujiazhuang, Ningjing County in the north, to Lianzhi Town, Longyao County in the south, from Beihakou, Julu County in the east, to Guanzhuang and Liutongzhuang in the west it includes an area of 300 kms. The region in and around Malan and Rencun were destroyed most seriously. Most of the adobe houses and houses with bricks on the surface collapsed or almost razed. Most masonry houses were destroyed or collapsed. The arrangement of ground fissures were zonary in shape. Many fissures, 8-30 cm in width, with a relative vertical displacement of the two flanks from ten to some dozens of centimeters, occurred on both banks of the section of the Fuyang River from Gengzhuangqiao to Baijiazhai, with general emission of sand and water. Well water upsurged or overflowed. Bridges on the Fuyang River were destroyed seriously. The Houxinlizhuang Bridge collapsed as a result of the failure of the piers.

(above from reference #3939)

March 7, 1966, 21:29:17 UTC, 37.2 N, 114.8 E,depth 33 km, magntidue 6.75. Thirty communes were damaged by the first shock, indicating that about 300,000 Chinese were affected in the densely populated city of Singtai. A report released by the New China News Agency stated that great numbers of medical personnel had been rushed to Singtai to care for the victims, indicating a probable high casualty figure. After the occurrence of the stronger shock in the same area on 22 March, a report was released stating that loss of was lighter in the 7 March shock, indicating some fatalities in the earlier tremor. Considerable property damage was sustained on 22 March, principally to buildings already weakened by the first earthquake. (reference #45)

March 7, 1966, 21.29 UTC, 37.3 N, 114.9 E, magnitude 5.8 mb, 7.1 MS. Little detailed information is available on the series of violent shocks which occurred in Hopeh province, north-eastern China, in March 1966. The earthquake of March 7, whose epicentre was located in the region of Hsing-t'ai, about 400 km south-west of Pekin, probably caused extensive damage since the magnitude was 7 and the focus shallow. The New China agency reported 'various degrees of damage' in about thirty communes. The shock of March 22 was even more violent; its epicentre was near that of the previous shock, and it was felt over a wide area, including Pekin, 300 km away. The New China agency reported that numerous buildings and houses collapsed but that the number of casualties was less than on 8 March, when people had been caught in their sleep. The worst damage was done at Hsing-t'ai, Heng-shui and Shih-chia-chuang; numerous aftershocks were felt in the same region up to 29 March. (reference #1039)

March 7, 1966, 21:29:17 UTC, Hopeh, China, 37.2 N, 114.8 E, depth 33 km, magnitude 6.4 mb, 7.4 MS. (reference #1229)

Reference #414:

1968, Aug 2, 4:20 [local time], 16.5 N, 122.2 E, depth 36 km, magnitude 7.7. There was a destructive earthquake with source off the east coast of Luzon Island. It was preceded by at least four shocks which were felt at Casiguran during the 24 hours before the earthquake.

The radius of perceptibility was more than 600 km. At Casiguran, loose ground settled 1-2 m. The channel which connects the Casiguran and Casalogan Rivers dried up. Numerous cracks 10-500 m long and 0.3-1.0 m wide appeared in the ground, here and there ejecting water, sand and mud. In the city, several buildings made of wood and concrete suffered damage. A bridge shifted. The people ran from their homes in panic. Posts and various subjects fell.

Near Dinadyavan, numerous avalanches and landslides occurred along the coast of Casiguran Sound and in the valley of the Jagdauan River. At Baler, the damage was slight: a bridge shifted out of place near the city. In the middle reaches of the Casiguran River, near Manglad and Maddela, large mudflows and landslides descended. In the upper reaches of the Manglad River, a part of the river bed 2.5 m wide and 0.5 m deep dried up. At Quezon City, according to the accelerograph record, the acceleration of the ground was estimated at 50 +- gal.

At Manila, homes situated at the mouth of the Pasig River on young alluvium more than 20 m thick suffered heavy damage. The "Ruby," a six-story reinforced concrete building, completely collapsed, as a result of which 268 people died and 260 people were injured. Up to another 10 such buildings almost collapsed and had to be demolished. Non-structural damage to buildings occurred in many, though hardly all, regions of the city.

In addition to the above-mentioned victims, another two dead and one injured were registered in the country. The material losses have been estimated at at least 8 million dollars. Many recurrent shocks were registered. Their epicenters approximately outline the source of the main earthquake.

The earthquake caused a tsunami.

Reference #45:

1968, Aug 1, 20:19:21.9 UTC, 16.5 N, 122.2 E, depth 36 km, magnitude 7.3. An estimated 207 residents were killed, many were injured, and widespread property damage occurred. The greatest loss of life was sustained in Manila when a six-story apartment building collapsed into a pile of rubble. A river was blocked at Maddela in the province of Nueva Vizcaya. Ground fissures were noted between Casiguran and Baker; some were reported to be 7 or more km long. Damage to private buildings in Manila was extensive with six structures of six to eight floors severely damaged. Fire ignited by the shock caused an estimated $7.5 million damage in the harbor area.

1968, Aug 2, 04:19 [local time], 16.5 N, 122.2 E, depth 36 km, magnitude 7 MS. Considerable damage, 207 more deaths, at Manila by quake.

1968, Aug 2. 271 deaths, 261 injured, $5 million damage.

An earthquake on September 3, 1968 at 08:19:52.2 UTC (41.8 N, 32.3 E, depth 38 km), centered in the vicinity of Bartin, Turkey, caused 24 deaths, 200 injuries and destroyed over 2,000 houses. Several villages were completely razed. At Amasra, water in the Big Port first drew back 1.5 meters leaving fish jumping on dry land, and then rose 3 meters. Huge landslides and rockfalls were observed along a 9-mile stretch of the coast of Big Port. A lake was created by landslide action at Cakraz, where the sea receded about 12-15 meters and never returned entirely to its original level. (reference #45)

The earthquake killed two people in Trinidad and severely damaged Diego Martin and Port-of-Spain. It was felt at Tobago, Guyana, and throughout Grenada, and Colombia.

Two earthquakes on Oct 2, 1969 at 0456 and 0619 UTC caused one fatality and left severe property damage in Santa Rosa: several old brick and wood-frame buildings were damaged beyond repair; chimneys were destroyed; sidewalks buckled; and underground pipes ruptured. Total damage was estimated at $8.35 million. (reference #542)

Total casualties were 14 killed and some hundreds injured. The deaths all resulted from the main shock on April 7, 1970, 05:34:06.2 UTC, 15.78 N, 121.71 E, magnitude 6.5 mb, depth 40 km. Some dozens of injuries occurred during the most severe aftershock at 12:02 p.m. [local time] on April 12, and a few injuries occurred during other aftershocks. The earthquake generated a tsunami. At least 5,000 people killed, 9,000 injured and extensive damage in the El Asnam area. Felt throughout northwestern Algeria and in southeastern Spain. Approximately 42 kilometers of surface rupture observed. (Reference #1053)

On October 10th, 1980, the region of El Asnam, in the Algerian Atlas, experienced an earthquake of Ms = 7.3, which was the largest ever instrumentally recorded in North-West Africa. The earthquake destroyed at least 25,000 houses and killed about 2,500 people. The shock, which was felt within an area of a radius of about 360 kilometres, as far as Spain, was followed by a damaging aftershock of Ms = 6.1. The earthquake occurred on a previously unrecognised reverse fault and it was associated with a 35 kilometre long rupture on which the observed overall movement was up dip by about 280 centimetres. Ground motions in the epicentral area were significantly in excess of those anticipated by engineers, particularly in the vertical direction in which ground accelerations were very large. Slight damage also occurred in southern Azerbaijan. Felt (VII) at Astra and Lenkoran; (VI) at Dzhibrail, Lerik, Mossony and Yardyshny; (III) at Baku. (reference #1053)

In the early hours of June 21, 1990, an earthQuake measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale devastated the two Iranian provinces of Gilan and Zanjan, north and northwest of Tehran. About 40,000 people were killed and 60,000 injured. Half a million people were left homeless. The epicenter of the quake was about 200 km northwest of Tehran in the region of the Sefid Rud Dam, which is located between the two completely destroyed towns of Manjil and Rudbar in Gilan province. Several hours after the main shock, two strong aftershocks occurred, having magnitudes of 6.2 and 6.5. In the subsequent weeks more than 400 aftershocks with magnitudes of up to 5.9 were reported by the Geophysics Center of Tehran University. Sefid Rud Dam was subjected to intensive ground shaking and suffered several types of damage including severe cracking in the upper parts of the central buttresses. Close observation showed that most of the damage in the dam was concentrated in the central part and in the upper quarter of the buttresses. (reference #4650)

Mw 7.3, The Rudbar earthquake of 1990 June 20, the first large-magnitude earthquake with 80 km left-lateral strike-slip motion in the western "High-Albor"' fold-thrust mountain belt, was one of the largest, and most destructive, earthquakes to have occurred in Iran during the instrumental period[...]It affected both urban and rural regions, killed 13000-40000 people, and made a further 500000 homeless[...]Direct economic loss was estimated to be US$7.2 billion (original values), approximately 2.5 per cent of GPD.(reference #12414)
