A fire was caused in the powder-store house of Kastro from where live objects were hurled and completed the destructions of people and animals. The earth opened in many places. At the monastery of Strofades, the tower and some parts of the walls fell down. A captain of a ship observed an intense sea wave out of Cephalonia. The aftershocks continued up to the spring of 1637 (Perrey, 1848; Mallet, 1854; Schmidt, 1867a; Partsch 1890; Romas, 1975). (reference #4408)

1636, Sept 20. 38 N, 29.5 E, intensity X. Libatho-Argostoli (Kephallenia). Earth and rockslides; casualties. A. Siegerg (1932a), E Tsitselis (1960). (reference #3719)

1636, Sept 30. Kefalonia. An earthquake caused extensive damage in the southern part of Kefalonia and Zante. It occurred at about 6pm on Friday 30 September (O.S.) and lasted for about 30 seconds. The earthquake destroyed or ruined all the houses and taller buildings in Kefalonia, not only in Kastro (Argostoli) and its suburbs, but also in the rest of the island, killing about 520 people. The districts of Argostoli, Livatho, Ikosima, Elios, Valta, Koroni, Irakli, and Pirgi, in the southern part of the island, were totally destroyed. The ground motion was very strong, making it impossible to walk. Maximum damage occurred in the southern part of the island... The effects on Zakynthos were as bad, if not worse. Houses and monasteries are reported to have collapsed all over the island, resulting in the deaths of several hundred people... The shock was felt at sea, but contrary to what modern writers report, the earthquake was not associated with a seismic sea wave. (reference #9116)

A strong earthquake on March 15 (20:00 Local time) occurred in Chile between the provinces of Maule and Kautin, approximately between 37 deg and 39 deg S. This quake affected an area to the south all the way to Chillan, where the only remaining church of that region was destroyed. Reports of destruction in Santiago apparently were erroneous, for if the earthquake was felt there, it was very weak.

By this time, only Concepcion (all of modern Penco), with a population 20 thousand, remained in Spanish hands, and it was besieged by insurrecting Indians. The earthquake was accompanied by a frightful rumbling sound, almost as if it were rolling through mountain canyons. People could not stand on their feet. Although the earthquake was weaker than some earlier quakes, most of the buildings were completely destroyed (it is not clear whether from the earthquake or the tsunami), and only one cathedral remained standing. A fire ball is said to have appeared in the sky "bounding about the clouds like a wagon wheel". After the earthquake, the sea level rose and exceeded its normal high mark "with ruthless fury." The tsunami, which may have started with an ebb, affected a considerable section of the shore. In fact, there were at least three large waves. Magnitude 7 1/4.

(above from reference #415)

March 15, 1657, 3p.m. Second Concepcion earthquake... More people died by drowning than from the effects of the earthquake proper... The size of the tsunami was comparable to that of 1570 and of 1835 but the earthquake itself seems to have been slightly less severe. At any rate, it did not leave as deep an impression on contemporary writers. There is no mention of fissures in the ground or of craterlets, and the aftershock sequence cannot have been as alarming as in 1570. Combining these data with the late arrival of the tsunami lends to the assumption of an offshore epicenter located about 100 km. from Concepcion. The magnitude of the earthquake may have been in the neighborhood of 8. (reference #252)

March 15, 1657, 23:30 UTC, 36.83 S, 73.030 W, magnitude 8 MS, intensity XI, tsunami, casualties. (reference #1206)
March 1660. Great earthquake at Galaxidi. Collapse of the church, 2 killed. The inhabitants to the countryside. (reference #1093)

1673, July 30. Mashhad. On 15 Rabi' 11, 1084 a destructive earthquake occurred in Khurasan. Two-thirds of Mashhad were ruined, including the dome over the tomb of Imam Riza, the cupola of the Masjid-i Gauhar Shad and many public buildings. 4000 people were killed. Nishapur was also severely damaged and half the town collapsed with the loss of 1600 lives. Another small town is also said to have been overthrown. (reference #1117)

1673, July 30. Mashad. 36.35 N, 49.27 E, intensity VIII, magnitude 6.6, 5600 people killed. (reference #3437)

1673, June 16 - July 15. In 1084 A.H.L., rabi' al-avval, a destructive earthquake took place in Khorasan. In Mashhad 4,000 people were killed and the Tomb of Imam-Rez, a very important monument, collapsed. 1,600 people were also killed in Nishabur. This earthquake extended as far as Torbat (Sani'ud Dovlah 1880) August 1673, Khorasan, Mashad and Nishabur, III (Milne 1011 and Wilson 1930, 103: Mallet). August 1673, a severe earthquake in Khorasan, destruction in Mashhad, Nishabur and surroundings (Sieberg 1932, p. 814). (reference #1217)

1673, August. 35.3 N, 59 E, magnitude 6.2, intensity IX. Destruction in Meshked, Nishapur and south of Torbet. (reference #223)

1688, July 10. Several strong underground shocks, which contributed to the outbreak of fire, occurred in Izmir at about midday. As a result the city was damaged very badly, material losses were very serious and 15,000 to 16,000 people were killed. The ground level was reduced by more than 1 foot, and fissures appeared in it. Some water sources disappeared, but a new one appeared. Repeated underground shocks resumed almost every day until the end of July. A weak tsunami was noted in Izmir. (reference #2130).

1688, July 10. 15,000 to 20,000 killed. (reference #1055) 1688, July 5. Izmir, Aegean coast. 15000 dead. (reference #1002)

1688, July 10. Izmir, Turkey. This was a locally destructive earthquake, albeit of relatively small magnitude that caused disproportionate damage to Smyrna, which was at that time a thriving commercial centre of the Levant... (reference #9910)

1693, Jan 9, at 5 pm. There were extremely violent shocks. The first lasted two minutes, the direction in Calabria was SW to NE. Followed by other shocks on the 10th and 11th. In Sicily the earth opened in many places. Catania was ruined by the first shock. Forty-nine towns, numerous villages, and 972 churches or convents were ruined in Calabria and Sicily and 93,000 persons lost their lives. The earthquake was also felt at Malta and several places in Switzerland, France, Germany, Flanders, Holland and England for a space of 2600 sq miles. It does not seem certain that the shocks were simultaneous in Italy and in the other parts of Europe mentioned. There was an eruption of Etna at the same time. (Reference #521)

1693, Jan 9. Sicily, Italy, 60000 deaths. (Reference #1003)

1693, Jan 9. Sicily, Italy. (Reference #1002)

1703, January 14 - February 2. Italy, Norcia in (Perugia), Aquila in (Abruzzi), other towns in these departments in the (Marches). Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

1703, February 2, 18th hour. Rome and all the country affected on the 14th January; especially Aquila. Several shocks. Direction N. to S. At the mouth of the Tiber the sea retired. Aquila was completely ruined, and 5,000 people perished there. The earth opened in several places, and threw out stones, water. Noises like the reports of a pistol were heard. (reference #521)

1703, February 2. Aquila. 42o21' N, 13o24' E. (reference #1075)

1703, February 2. Aquila, in Italy ruined; 5,000 perished. (reference #1073)

1703, February 2. Lazio coast (mouth of the Tiber). 42.27 N, 43.20 E, intensity 10.5. (reference #3470).

1703, February 2, 11:05 UTC. Latium, 42o28' N 13o12' E, earthquake magnitude 6.7, intensity X. Tsunami reliability 0, intensity 2. Strong earthquake in central Italy, with epicenter about 100 km far from the sea. Wide area affected north of L' Aquila. About 10,000 victims. Small withdrawal of the sea at the mouth of Tiber, Latium. (reference #4139)

Reference #150:

Note: Reference #150 lists two earthquakes and tsunamis on October 28, 1707:

  • 12-13h [local time] at 34.1N, 137.8E
  • 13-15h [local time] at 33.2N, 134.8E

Reference #414:

Note: Reference #414 lists one earthquake and tsunami on Oct 28, 1707 between 14:00 and 14:30 [local time] at 33.2N, 135.9E

There was a catastrophic earthquake, one of the strongest in Japan, in terms of the size of the area on which it was felt and the extent of destruction. The earthquake affected the western part of Yamanashi Prefecture, the central and eastern part of Shizouka Prefecture, the territory to the south of Nagano Prefecture, as far as the areas of Tokai and Kinki. The earthquake was also felt all over Shikoku Island on the eastern part of Kyushu Island. At Kyoto, the earthquake lasted rather long (10-15 minutes). Recurrent shocks were registered for 7-8 months after the main earthquake.

The Tokai locality, the coast of Ise Gulf, and the Kii Peninsula, suffered especially badly. The southeastern part of the coast of Totomi-Nada, the southern part of the Kii Peninsula, and the Muroto Peninsula rose. This elevation was 1-2 m on Cape Owase, 1.2 m at Kushimoto and 1.5 m on Cape Muroto. A section of area about 20 km2 subsided 2 m in the eastern part of Kochi Prefecture.

Reference #1068:

Lists 29,000 houses destroyed and 4,900 deaths.

Reference #3785:

Damages are difficult to access, as literature vary on their assessment. About 59,000 houses were destroyed. About 18,000 were washed out. Death toll about 5,000. Lost ships are about 3,900. Considering its heavy earthquake and tsunami affected region. This earthquake/tsunami is similar to the 1854 Ansei earthquake/tsunami, it might be considered the following two earthquakes: Enshunada bay and Kishu Penisula bay.

October 14, 1709, S of Zhongwei, Ningxia Autonomous Region, 37.4, 105.3 E, magnitude 7.5, intensity IX-X.

Zhongwei: Enclosing walls (The Great Wall) and 70-80% of city walls collapsed, walls of buildings were devastated. Half of the pagoda in the Anqing temple (located in the present-day Zhongning County) collapsed. Government buildings, civilian houses, the county offices, the Confucian Temple and schools were destroyed. In all the villages south of the river, the flood was thigh-deep on the flat ground. Huge stones were pushed up to the surface, the largest measurable only with arms outstretched.

Well water was agitated to shoot up to 2 meters high. More than 2,000 people were killed, and those survived had to sleep in the open.

Jingyuan: More than 2,000 rooms of civilian houses and 20 mound platforms collapsed. The Great Wall fell some 5,000 meters long. 32 inhabitants were killed.

Jingning: Most city walls were destroyed.

Qingyang: Many walls collapsed.

Yinchuan: The top four stories of the Haibao Pagoda collapsed, its red paint peeled off. The Wenchang pavilion was damaged.

Jingtai: Temples fell in.

Wuwei: The top ornament of Guxi Pagoda fell off.

Mingqin: Some walls collapsed.

Yongdeng: The earthquake occurring at Aba Ridge caused some people to be injured.

Zhengyuan: Some peasant houses were damaged. People and domestic animals were injured.

Haiyuan: In Xi'an Prefecture, springs were blocked up.

Baode: Houses shook, and most weak walls collapsed. The quake also struck Liangzhou, Xining, Jingning, Guyuan and Ningxia, some people were injured.

The recorded affected area included: Zhengning, Gulang, Yongchangin Gansu Province; Ledu in Qinghai Province; Xixiang, Yongshou, Pucheng, Liquan, Qianxian, Weinan, Wugong, Huxian, Zhouzhi, Ningshan and Chenggu in Shaanxi Province; Yonghe in Shanxi Province; Julu, Xingtai and Qiuxian in Hebei Province; Yuanyang, Yingyang and Zhongmou in Henan Province and Pucheng in Shandong Province. The earth quaked violently during 7 to 11 a.m. Thereafter, earthquakes continued for more than 50 days, more than 10 times or 2 to 3 times per day, and did not die out until a year later.

Note: In the same year, an earthquake occurred at Anxi with casualties. It was probably a separate one.

(above from reference #3939)

April 26, 1721, 07 local time, Southeast Tabriz. Early in the morning of Sunday 28 Jumada II, 1133, a major earthquake (37.9N, 46.7E, magnitude 7.7) shook the region of Tabriz, killing at least 40000 people. In Tabriz itself the shock ruined about three quarters of the houses and caused substantial damage to most of the larger buildings which did not, however, collapse. Detailed information about the extent of the affected region outside Tabriz is lacking, but internal evidence suggests that the heaviest destruction, accounting for the large number of casualties, occurred within a zone that extended from near Tabriz to the southeast, through Shibli and beyond Qareh Baba. The shock triggered many rockfalls and was associated with a fault break that extended for at least fifty kilometres, from Takmeh Dash to near Tabriz. The break through Shibli was still visible in 1809, and parts of the fault trace that seems to be connected with this earthquake can be seen today on the ground. The shock seems also to have been strongly felt in the Qazvin region and was followed by many strong aftershocks. (reference #1117)

April 26, 1721 = 1133 A.H.L. Jumada-al-ukhra 28, one and a half hours after sunrise a violent earthquake took place at Tabriz. This earthquake destroyed many buildings including mosques and schools, killing many people. The various authorities are in agreement that Tabriz end region experienced a severely destructive earthquake in 1721 A.D. There is a notable discrepancy in the mortality figures however, with Mallet giving 8,000 dead as a low figure and Sani'ud Dovlah reporting 250,000 killed. A more credible figure of 80,000 killed in this earthquake is given by a later writer, who derives his figure from a more original and reliable source. (reference #1217)

April 26, 1721, Persia, Tabriz, 8,000 lives lost, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

1721, Sebli-Tabriz, 40,000 casualties. (reference #3937)

April 26, 1721, Tabriz, 40,000 casualties. (reference #1051)

Ref #415:

The Valparaiso earthquake. A severe earthquake occurred between 01:00 and 02:00 [local time] in Santiago. The inhabitants dressed and hurried into the streets. Then followed three less severe tremors. But at 04:45 [local time] on July 8, 1730, the area was struck by a shock so severe that people found it difficult to remain standing. A large part of the city was completely destroyed and clouds of dust arose from the ruins. Since the people had time to flee into the streets, only two women perished. Between 12:00 and 13:00 [local time] there was another earthquake, almost equal in force to the previous one. Innumerable tremors continued during the next two days, and with diminished frequency over several months.

This was one of the most severe earthquakes in the history of Chile. Severe damage occurred approximately between 30o and 36o S., from La Serena to Chillan.

In La Serena, the parish church was destroyed. In Coquimbo, several houses and churches were slightly damaged. The destructive effects of the earthquake were more apparent in the area north of La Serena, but it is difficult to estimate the northern boundary of the effect of the earthquake because that section of the country was not settled at the time. In Chillan, the damage was less than in La Serena, although several buildings were destroyed and the earthquake greatly frightened the inhabitants. In Valparaiso, some houses were ruined, not only in the low areas, but also on the slopes - something that did not occur even during the earthquake of 1906. Only the house of the governor was saved, although it too was damaged, as well as the arsenal and one auxiliary building. Coquimbo and the mountain villages of Illapel, Petorca and Tiltil were seriously damaged. In the mines the machinery for crushing ore broke down. Strong shocks were also felt in Concepcion but they did not cause any destruction. In Rengo, the church was destroyed. The earthquake was strongly felt as well in three mountain provinces of Argentina, where it terrified the inhabitants of Cordoba. The source of the earthquake was probably located close to the mouth of the Aconcagua River.

A destructive tsunami, which enveloped the coast for a distance of over 1000 km, occurred almost simultaneously with the second earthquake.

Ref #11799:

The earthquake and tsunami that occurred in Metropolitan Chile on July 8th 1730 at 4:30 am local time, have been recognized as the largest to occur in this region since the beginning of written history [Montessus de Ballore, 1912]. The event was preceded by a strong foreshock, which although produced a tsunami that was observed in Concepción, its effects were not as large as those reported for the main shock [Urbina et al., 2016].

The shaking produced by the 1730 earthquake caused severe damage to buildings along >1000 km of the coast, from Copiapó (30°S) to Concepción (36.6°S) Severe damage to buildings was also reported on the other side of the Andes, in Mendoza, Argentina.

The historical observations at Valparaíso and Penco suggest that the magnitude for the 1730 earthquake was in the range of Mw 9.1-9.3. This estimate is in agreement with the tsunami heights observed in Japan in 1730, which indicate an overall tsunami size consistent with instrumentally recorded Chilean earthquakes of magnitudes of about Mw 9.3.

Origin times and magnitudes:

  • July 8 4:45 am [local time], mag. 8.75 (ref #252) July 8 4:45 am [local time] (ref #415) July 8 09:00 UTC (ref #79) July 8 08:45 UTC 32.5S, 71.5W, mag 8.25 (ref #150) July 8 10:00 UTC, 33.050S, 71.63W, mag 8.7 (ref #1206) July 8 13:00 UTC, 32.5S, 71.5W, mag. 8.7 (ref #552) July 8 13:00 UTC, mag. 8.75 (ref #164) Mw 9.1-9.3 (ref #11799) Mw 9.0 (ref #11800)

November 29, 1732, Naples, etc.; 1940 perished. (reference #1073)

November 29, 1732. Catastrophic earthquake, Lucanie, Ariano, Mirabella, Carife, Avellino Apice, Bonito, 1940 deaths. (reference #1093)

November 29, 1732, Italy, Ariano and other towns in (Avellino), intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

November 29, 1732, Arianese, 41 deg 05 min N, 15 deg 09 min E, intensity X, aftershocks. (reference #1075)

December 24, 1737, 43 S, 74 W. An earthquake destroyed Valdivia and a large part of the settlements on the archipelago (the island of Chiloe and others in the southern part of Chile). This earthquake was even more severe than that of 1633. (reference #415)

December 24, 1737. Second Valdivia Earthquake. This earthquake is known to have destroyed Valdivia and localities to the south, including most towns on the island of Chiloe. Few details are known, except that it must have been a great earthquake, Magnitude about 7 1/2-8. (reference #252)

December 24, 1737, 39.8 S, 73.2 W, magnitude 7.7 MS, intensity XI, tsunami, casualties. (reference #1206)

May 25, 1751, Jianchuan, Yunnan Province, 26.5 N, 99.9 E, magnitude 6.7, intensity IX.

All city walls, government offices, warehouses, small reservoirs, bridges, towers, the Confucian school, academies of classical learning, military and civilian houses were destroyed. In the city and the country, 15,566 rooms in tile-roofed houses and 146 in thatched house. collapsed. Stones flew off hills. All wells dried up. The water of West Lake flowed into East Lake. The Jianhu Lake inundated East Taiping and other villages in the northeast, and the fields along the lake were also inundated. People wove reeds into shacks to take shelter in. More than 900 people were killed and more than 250 injured.

Heqing: The prefecture brick city walls were destroyed, and more than half of government offices, warehouses and all temples collapsed. In the city and the country, more than 2,130 rooms collapsed, and more than 1,970 were damaged or tilted. More than 60 people were killed and more than 100 injured.

Eryuan: Bridges were destroyed. Tiles slid off' and walls cracked in some government offices and warehouses. Tombs caved in. In more than ten villages including Cunmuguan, Duzhuang, Haikou, etc., more than 400 rooms in tile-roofed houses and more than 50 of thatched cottages collapsed; 500600 destroyed, and many walls collapsed. More than 30 people were killed and more than 40 injured.

Lijiang: The prefecture city walls were destroyed. Many military and civilian houses collapsed or cracked. In the city and the country, more than 240 rooms collapsed. 18 people were killed.

Dengchuan: Titles fell off and walls collapsed in some government offices warehouses, military and civilian houses.

The shock also struck Dali, Weishan and Binchuan.

(above from reference #3939)

September, 1754, at Grand Cairo, half the houses and 40,000 persons swallowed up. (reference #1073)

September 2, 1754, Turkey, Constantinople, Nicomedia, also at Adrianople and Asia Minor, Djarbekir and Armenia, and at Alexandria and Cairo in Egypt intensity II, two earthquakes. (reference #1055)

October, 1754, Gulf of Suez. A locally destructive earthquake in Egypt affected Cairo, particularly the districts of Qarafa, Bulaq and part of new Cairo, where many houses were ruined with great loss of life. The shock was possibly felt in Alexandria, but there is no evidence that it caused damage elsewhere. This earthquake is sometimes associated erroneously with the destructive shock of 2 September that affected northwest Anatolia, too far away to have caused the damage reported in Caíro. There is some evidence that at about this time it became necessary to repair the walls of the monastery of St Catherine in Sinai. The reason for their downfall is not given, except that earthquakes had occurred prior to 1771. (reference #3845)

In September 1754 a strong earthquake occurred; the epicentre is believed to have been in the Tanta region in lower Egypt. Two-thirds of the buildings in Cairo were damaged and thousands of people were killed. The earthquake was felt over an area of 150,000 km2. In all allegedly 40,000 persons were killed. The high toll of lives and property loss is questioned by some sources but it must be realized that a shallow earthquake of about M 6 with its epicentre in a densely populated region with frail buildings founded on soft subsoil can cause enormous damage. (reference #1598)

April 15, 1757, A strong earthquake in Sale and on Cape Contain. (reference #1183)

April 15, 1757, Widespread damage in western Morocco from offshore earthquake, 3000 deaths. (reference #1180)

April or May 15, 1757, Sale, Morocco, on the coast, intensity I which corresponds to an earthquake of intensity sufficient to crack walls, break chimneys, to shatter old buildings or to produce cracks in the ground. (reference #1055)

1757, in Sale and Cape Cantin, many buildings were destroyed. (reference #1201)

Hindostan, 1762-The town of Chittagong, in Bengal, was violently shaken by an earthquake, on April 2, 1762, the earth opening in many places, and throwing up water and mud of a sulphureous smell. At a place called Bardavao, a large river was dried up; and at Bar Charra, near the sea, a tract of ground sank down, and 200 persons with all their cattle, were lost. It is said that 60 square miles of the Chittagong coast suddenly and permanently subsided during this earthquake, and that Ces-lung-Toom, one of the Mug mountains, entirely disappeared, and another sank so low, that its summit only remained visible. Towns which subsided several cubits were overflowed with water; among others Deep Gong, which was submerged to the depth of 7 cubits. Two volcanoes are said to have opened in the Becta Cunda hills. The shock was also felt at Calcutta. While the Chittagong coast was sinking, a corresponding rise of the ground took place at the island of Ramree, and at Cheduba. Lyell's source is McClelland's Report of Min. Resources of India, 1838, Calcutta. (reference #1503)

April 2, 1762,17:00 hr, Burma, 22 N, 92 E. A very destructive and violent earthquake felt all over Bengal, Arakan, etc., chiefly and most severely in the north part of the east coast of the Bay of Bengal. (reference #1185)

April 2, 1762, 22 N, 92 E, intensity XI. (reference #1276)

April 2, 1762, India, felt all over Bengal, Arracan, and Burmah, Pegu, northeast coast of Bay of Bengal elevated along a length of 100 miles, Brahmaputra to Calcutta, Dacaa, Ghirotty, Chittagong and Bakar Tschurak, intensity II which corresponds to buildings may be unroofed or shattered and some may fall, the ground may be badly cracked in places and small landslips occur. (reference #1055)

April 2, 1762, Felt all over Bengal, Arracan and Burma, intensity II which which corresponds to an earthquake which would uproot or shatter buildings, cause bad cracks in ground, or landslips. Acceleration of the ground will be roughly of the order of 5 feet per sec per sec. (reference #1216)

April 2, 1762, (Bengal and Burma) Felt most severely along the N-E coast of the Bay of Bengal. Chittagong suffered severely, fissures opening in the ground with fountains of water and sand. Probably the origin was in the sea off Chittagong. (reference #1100)

April 2, 1762, Chittagong, Bangladesh. (reference #1212)

April 12, 1762. Earthquake felt most severely along the north western coast of the Bay of Bengal. Waves as high as six feet were reported from the distributaries of the Ganges Delta. (references Oldham, reference #4110).

The most damaging earthquake reported in Bangladesh was the 2 April AD1762 event that occurred at 5 p.m. local time. The great earthquake of April 2, which raised the coast of Foul island by 2.74m and the northwest coast of Chedua island by 6.71m above sea level and also caused a permanent submergence of 155.40 sq km near Chittagong. The earthquake proved very violent in Dhaka and along the eastern bank of the meghna as far as Chittagong. In Dhaka 500 persons lost their lives, the rivers and jheels were agitated and rose high above their usual levels and when they receded their banks were strewn with dead fish. A large river dried up, a tract of land sank and 200 people with all their cattle were lost. Two volcanoes were said to have opened in the Sitakunda hills (Ali and Choudhury 1994,2001; BBS 2017).

This event occurred along the Arakan Subduction Zone that caused uplift of ~3-7 m along the coasts of Ramree, Cheduba, and Foul Islands, located offshore of the Arakan coast of Myanmar10, and also generated a tsunami. (reference #12708)

Reference #496 lists end of January, 1785, a violent and destructive earthquake occurred in Patras, also on the island of Zante. Vesuvius was in violent eruption during the greater part of the year.

Reference #1055 lists an earthquake on January 30, 1785, that caused severe damage in Patras, Greece.

Reference #1093 lists 38 deaths.

locationName: CHINA:  SICHUAN PROVINCE:  S OF KANGDING
comments:
June 1, 1786, S of Kangding, Sichuan Province, 29.8 N, 102.1 E, magnitude 7.5, intensity IX.

Kangding: The city walls totally toppled down. 169 rooms of governmental buildings, storehouses and military camps collapsed, 384 rooms were partly destructed, and only about 10-20% left intact. 727 rooms in shops and 54 rooms in mud civilian houses collapsed in the city. 177 rooms collapsed, killing 250 people in Minzheng Tusi.

Luding: Near the chain bridge, the walls of an imperial stele pavilion cracked and its ridge tiles fell off. A sheep pen alongside a cliff fell down for 40 m long. At Hualinping, more than 300 military camps collapsed, some walls of the governmental buildings and storehouses toppled down, and some frameworks inclined. In Lengbian Tuoi, Shenbian Tusi and Zanli Tusi, altogether 127 rooms in mud houses and 671 in blockhouses collapsed, killing 181 persons. Landslides occurred in Moximian, dammed the Dadu River for 10 day. Thereafter, the lower reaches were flooded.

Qingxi (near the present-day Hanyuan County): The city walls toppled down for more than 100 m long, the battlements and wall fell down for 650 m long. The county offices were inclined. The walls of civilian houses collapsed, killing and injuring people. Landslides occurred in Dashupu, damming the Dadu River.

Yuexi: The towers on city walls collapsed, and the north city gate fell. The city walls toppled down for 800 m long. In schools, office huildings, storehouses, prisons and military camps long in disrepair, 72 rooms collapsed and 19 were damaged. 39 tile-roofed houses and thatched cottages collapsed, killing 4 persons. In Ninyueying, 9 rooms in office buildings collapsed and 25 were damaged. 71 rooms in tile-roofed houses and thatched cottages collapsed, most of the other houses were damaged.

Tianquan: Roof ridges all toppled in the city and countrysides. Water splashed over the field banks.

Guanghan: Some governmental buildings and civilian houses collapsed.

Pengxian: The top of the Longxing Temple cracked.

Neijiang: Some houses collapsed. The earth quaked again the next day.

Zizhong and Ziyang: A lot of houses collapsed.

Leshan: City walls tilted down more than 650 m long. Houses inclined or collapsed. (maybe related to the flooding of the Dadu River).

The felt region was extensive, including: Lixian, Chengdu, Xichang, Shuangliu, Xinjin, Guanxian, Fuling, Chongqing, Jiangjin, Rongchang, Qijiang, Hechuan, Bishan, Xicheng, Yingshan, Linshui, Yuechi, Fushun, Mabian, Huili, Hongya, Qianwei, Suining, Anyue, Yanting, Zhongjiang, Yuezhi, Pingwu, Qwdan, Dazhu, Youyang, Xiushan, Hejiang, Pengshui, Pengshan, Qingshen, Luxian, Jiang'an, Xuyong, Guang'an and Qinjiang in Sichuan Province; Zhijiang in Hunan Province; Guanling, Chishui, Qinglong and Weining in Guizhou Province (The last two counties only recorded the year and month). The earth quaked for months.

At midday, the ground suddenly shook violently and lasted till evening. Several quakes occurred on the next day. Thereafter, slight shocks occurred daily, till June 13th.

(above from reference #3939)

Reference #1052 lists June 1, 1786, Szechwan Province, 29.9 N, 102.3 E, magnitude 7.5, intensity IX.

June 1, 1786, 29.7 N, 102.1 E, intensity VIII. (reference #1276)

July 13, 1787, 6:45 a.m. Panay Island Provinces of Iloilo and Antique, Buenavista: Tremendous earthquake felt in the whole island of Panay on the 13th instant (July) at 6:45 in the morning. (reference #1187)

July 13, 7 a.m., intensity X. Panay Island. A terrible earthquake which left the whole island strewn with ruins. Of 15 to 20 churches and convents in Iloflo Province only two or three remained standing; in the two other provinces, Capiz and Antique, the destruction was less universal. Even the thick walls of the fort at Iloilo were breached in many places. There were subsidences in the plains and landslides in the mountains and mighty fissures opened. It is stated that the victims were numerous: in one building 15 persons perished. (reference #1072)

1797, Dec 14, 23:30 UTC. 10.6 N, 64.1 W, intensity IX. (reference #1209)

1797, Dec 14, 19h. Major earthquake in Cumana, many houses and buildings damaged and numerous victims. It was witnessed by A. v. Humboldt. (reference #1502)

1797, Dec 14. Cumana, Venezuela. (reference #1002)

1797, Dec 4 and 14. Venezuela, Cumana, Cariaco and the surrounding country; 16,000 lives lost. Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

1797, Dec 14. Venezuela (IX). In Cumana many houses and other buildings were destroyed and many killed. (reference #364)

1797, Dec. Earthquake in Cumana with large underground noises. They suffered many houses and buildings and casualties. The eruption of the volcano of the isla of Guadalupe was the September 27, 1797. "In eastern Antilles eight months before the eruption of this volcano they felt a series of subterranean noises tremors. (reference #492)

1797, Dec 14. Cumana. (reference #410)

1797, Dec 14. The town of Cumana, S. America and the surrounding country. A violent earthquake. Preceded by a slight wave-like motion. Then came violent perpendicular shocks from beneath upwards. The town of Cumana was ruined, and terrible devastation produced in its neighborhood. The state of the surface of the ground was changed in some places. Half an hour before the violent shocks a smell of sulphur was observed. On the bank of the Manzanares and in the bay of Cariaco near Maraquitas flames came up from the earth, followed by a subterranean noise like bubbling, and then by the shocks. The latter were like the springing of a mine at a great depth, and laid four-fifths of the city in ruins. (reference #497)

1797, Dec 14, 19:00 local time. 10.6 N, 64.1 W. this earthquake occurred shortly before the arrival of Baron von Humboldt, German naturalist, to the coast of Venezuela. Humboldt (1842) refers to this earthquake and the September 10, 1794 which, according to Perrey (1858), was intense. According to Humboldt tremors were felt along the southern coast of the Gulf of Cariaco to the town of that name, while the peninsula of Araya, the ground did not participate in such vibrations. (reference #124)

February, 16, 1810, 35.5 N, 25 E, intensity X-XII. The town Iraklion was ruined and 2000 persons perished, many houses collapsed, 200 victims, large shaken area, felt strongly in Malta, at Napoli and in N. Africa, slightly in Cyprus. (reference #1099)

February 17, 1810, Saturday, Hellenic Arc. At the beginning of the seventh hour of the night, three strong shocks were felt in Cairo with a total duration of about four minutes. People were awakened from their sleep and thrown into turmoil. Many left their homes and fled into the alleys, seeking to escape into the open country. In the morning, everyone discussed what had happened. Some walls and old houses collapsed in the shock; other walls were fissured and the minaret of Basus fell, as well as half the minaret of Umm Akhnan (Umm Khunan) in Minufiyya. During the late afternoon, there was another earthquake, which though weaker than the first, still caused fear and agitation. Many rumours later circulated that there was going to be a further, more destructive shock, but such fears proved groundless. These effects were produced by a large, probably intermediate-depth event with an epicentre off Crete, where many places were destroyed and many people killed. All the other islands in the southern part of the Archipelago suffered some damage. In Malta, the shock caused panic, and widespread minor damage in Valletta, where ships in the harbour were violently shaken. The effects extended to Syria; in Lattakia, it is related that ancient buildings that had previously been swallowed up were seen at the bottom of a chasm, before it closed up again. The shock was also felt in central Italy, Turkey, Cyprus and various parts of North Africa. Minar damage was reported from Rashid (Rosetta) and Alexandria, where the earthquake set up waves in the harbour and in canals. The shock was probably also strongly felt in the Siwa oasis. (reference #3845)

June 25, 1824, 05:00 [local time], Northwest Shiraz, 29.8 N, 52.4 E. At dawn, on 27 Shawwal 1239, a destructive shock occurred in the district of Shiraz. In the city itself, all houses were damaged and a few collapsed. The eastern city walls and nearly all its towers fell down, and the rest of the fortifications were damaged. Of the public buildings, those constructed during the period of Karim Khan-i Zand, such as the bazaar and the Masjid-i Vakil, suffered minor damage. The dome and walls of the Imam zadeh Shah Chiragh, the Madraseh Khan, the Imamzadehs of Shah Mir Hamza and Sa'id Ahmad, as well as part of the palace, collapsed together with several minarets. There is no evidence that damage extended beyond Shiraz, except to the district of Guyum in the northwest where a number of villages, including Kilistan and Qalat-i Guyum, were ruined and a few hundred people were killed, some of the survivors removing to Shiraz. Damage extended as far as Shul. The shock was felt strongly at Bushire and Imamzadeh Isrna'il, and as far as Yazdikhwast, about 190 kilometres from the meizoseismal region. The earthquake caused a permanent rise in the underground water table in the region of Shiraz, and it was followed by aftershocks for six months. A shock on 28 August caused additional damage near Shiraz. (reference #1117)

June 25, 1824, 05:00 [local time], Shiraz, 29.8 N, 52.4 E, magnitude 6.4 MS, intensity VIII. (reference #3437)

Reference #1068:

Dec 18, 1828, 37.5 N, 139.5 E, 1,443 deaths, 11,750 houses destroyed.

Reference #1055:
\

Dec 18, 1828, in Echigo, Japan, sea waves at Kiushu, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts.

Reference #414:

1828, December 18, 8:00 local time. Milne's catalogue (1912) states that an earthquake occurred in Niigata Prefecture and at the same time a tsunami was observed on the coast of Kyushu Island. The data are apparently in error. The Japanese sources do not mention a tsunami, but report only that a strong earthquake was felt that day at Sanjo, Mitsuke, Nagaoka, Yoita and Wakino (Niigata Prefecture). It was preceded by foreshocks. The earthquake was local; nevertheless it left about 1500 victims.

Iida et al. (1967): 37.6 N., 138.9 E.; M=6.9.

January 1, 1837, 03h [local time], 33 N, 35.5 E, intensity X. Destructive earthquake with the epicentre near Safad where all houses on steep slopes fell, fissures in the ground, 5000 victims, destructive effects (IX-X) at El Jish, Er Reina, Ein Zeitun, Tiberias (city walls overthrown, the lakeswept the shores, 700 victims), Sejera IX?, Sidon VIII-IX, Sur VIII-IX, Hunin VIII?, Qaditta and Lubya severe, Nazareth VI-VII, Nablusstrong, Kafr, Kanna V, Tsippori (Saffuriya), Jerusalem, Bethlehem, Hebron moderate, many casualties. Devastation from Beirut (Beyrouth) to Safad, deep fissures in solid rocks, new hot springs. Epicentre probably in the Tiberias depression; Beirut not particularly heavy, Nazareth great cracks in Rouses, Jericho slight, Tiberias city ruined, Esh Sham (Damascus) city affected, Hauran and Gaulan considerable. Strong tsunami along Syrian - Israeli coasts of Tiberias. (reference #1099)

1837. Syria, Palestine and Jordan Valley, intensity VIII, 5000 deaths. (reference #1222)

January 1, 1837, Asia minor, Syria, from Beyrout, Damascus to Saphit, Jaffa, Acre, Tiberias, Rani near Cana, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

1837. Syria, Palestine, and the Jordan Valley: Safed, entire town destroyed, 5,000 victims; Beirut, Damascus, and Tiberius, also Acre and Jaffa suffered greatly; at Tripoli only a strong shock was felt; the Sea of Galilee was thrown into violent commotion. Mention is made of the destruction of Rani, a village near Cana, where little harm was done. Rani appears to be Reineh, which was destroyed in 1927, while neighboring towns escaped. (reference #4200)

January 1, 1837, 33 N, 35.5 E, maximum intensity IV, heavy damage in Safed, magnitude 6.4. (reference #1225)

February 7, 1839, Eryuan, Yunnan Province, 26.1 N, 99.9 E, magnitude 6, intensity VIII.

Liancheng Pagoda, Helin Temple, Fengyu College, government buildings and monasteries collapsed. A total of 500 to 600 rooms in civilian houses fell down. Landslides occurred in the Mt. Jingui (3 km southwest of the county). Black water gushed out in highland. More than 100 dwellers were killed.

Dengchuan: Houses were destroyed, killing people and domestric animals. The ground cracked at the about 100 m across at the foot of the Mt. Luoqi (5km northwest of the county). All inhabitants had to stay in the open.

(above from reference #3939)

Reference #414:

1840, March 22. In the morning there was an earthquake (magnitude 6.5) in Sorsogon Province on Luzon Island. The church at Sorsogon was destroyed, injuring many people. Many homes were also destroyed; 17 people died and about 200 were injured. Churches were destroyed at Legaspi (Albay) and Casiguran. There was destruction at Masbate. The shore of Sorsogon Bay subsided 1 1/2 m (5 feet).The sea inundated a large area of the coast and the homes nearest to the shore line. According to some sources, 35 people drowned [There is no direct information about a tsunami, but the possibility of a tsunami is not excluded.]

Reference #1072:

1840. Destructive earthquake in Sorsogon and Masbate. Ruined the masonry buildings. Intensity IX.

Reference #1058:

1840, March 22. Intensity IX. Sorsogon. Destructive, several victims.

Reference #3029:

1840, March 22. Morning. Province of Sorsogon, Luzon. Documents relating to this earthquake were preserved, before the war, in the archives of the Diocese of Naga. One is a petition from the Municipal President and eight leading citizens of the town of Sorsogon for the construction of a new church of light material. "As our church was destroyed by the earthquake of Sunday, March 22, 1840, during high mass, injuring many of those present, we desire to reconstruct it of wood and nipa because the earthquakes are still very frequent in this place." The second document is a report of the Provincial Governor of Albay, in which he mentions that the earthquakes had destroyed the church and, "as a result of the said earthquakes the bottom of the bay of Sorsogon seems to have undergone some change, because at the present time boats of deep draft anchor at places where formerly faluas grounded at low tide, and the sea has invaded a great part of the beach and the houses which were nearest the shore." MS2, No. 160, pp. 190-191.

Father Saderra Maso found copies of these documents in the archives of the Philippine Government, but gives the date of the Governor's letter as February 22, 1843. MSM, pp. 91-92. In March, 1938, these documents could not be located in the government archives because they had recently been moved and were not in order.

Further details: "In 1840 Sorsogon suffered severely from an earthquake, which lasted almost continuously for thirty-five days. It raged with greatest fury on the 21st [sic] of March. The churches, both of Sorsogon and Casiguran, as well as the smallest stone houses, were destroyed; seventeen persons lost their lives, and two hundred were injured; and the whole neighborhood sank five feet below its former level." FJ, p.112.

June 11, 1842, Barkol, Xinjiang Autonomous Region, 43.6 N, 93 E, magnitude 7, intensity IX.

Over half of the city walls in Manchu and Han cities toppled down, all battlements collapsed. Civil and military office buildings, barracks, civilian houses (totaling 5,460 rooms), storehouses, prisons and temples were demolished, with the exception of only one or two structures left in badly damaged state. Dozens of persons were killed or injured.

Hami: The earthquake devastated civilian houses and walls, causing many injuries.

(above from reference #3939)

The catastrophic earthquake devastated Pointe-a-Pitre, Guadeloupe, leaving it in ruins. One-third of the inhabitants of Pointe-a-Pitre perished, variously estimated at 4,000 to 6,000 and losses of 110,000,000 francs. The earthquake also affected Marie-Galante, Dominica, Montserrat, and Antigua.

1843, February 8. West Indies, Guadeloupe, pointe a Pitre, St. Lucia, St. Kitts, Antigua, Montserrat, Martinique. Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

locationName: INDONESIA:  N SULAWESI:  MENADO, TIKALA, TOMOHON
comments:
Reference #414:

1845, February 8, 15:30 [local time]. A strong earthquake (magnitude 7) occurred suddenly. It affected the eastern tip of Minahassa Peninsula (Sulawesi Island).

The tremors lasted 50-60 seconds at Manado and were so strong that it was impossible to stand. Gaping cracks formed in the walls of Fort Amsterdam. One home collapsed in the European quarter. Many homes collapsed in the Chinese quarter and in the settlements of Tikala, Lotn, Kakazkazen, Tondano, Tanawanko, Kawankoan, Romoon, Tombasian, and Zonder.

In the Tomoon district, settlements were more than half destroyed. At Amurang, the walls of an old fort collapsed, and a church and buildings suffered damage. At Wuwuh village, a church and 125 homes collapsed, and the remaining homes were left unsuitable for habitation. Many cracks occurred in the ground, and there were avalanches. Springs dried up.

Strong shocks were felt at Kema and Likupang. On the other hand, Tompazo, Ratahan, Pazan, and Belang suffered only slightly. A total of 118 people were killed or injured. Avalanches occurred in the mountains at Lokon, Kakazkazen and other places. Many subsequent shocks were registered.

On the roadstead at Kema, the water twice inundated the shore and three times retreated to the end of the breakwater, so that it was possible to collect the fish left on the dried bottom before the sea returned to its previous state.

Reference #1188:

1845, February 08. Menado: North Sulawesi - a strong earthquake was felt in north Sulawesi and caused the collapse of brick buildings and houses at Menado, Tikala, Tomohon, Tonsarongsong, Tondano and Tanawanko. MMI VIII-IX.

Reference #1055:

1845, February 08. Celebes, Menado. Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts.

On April 16, 1852, an earthquake of MMI VIII caused damage on Ribeira Grande - Sao Miguel Island. The death toll fell between 9 and 12. According to Nunes et al. (2001), the epicentre likely was located inland on Santana. The event caused severe damage not only in the parish of the north shore but also in Ponta Delgada city where some buildings collapsed. (reference #12490)

A violent earthquake occurred near Cumana, followed by tsunamis. Total death tolls from the event have been reported as 600, 800, 1,000, and as high as 4,000. Montadon (1962) reported more than 1,000 fatalities in the region. Centeno-Grau (1969) said that the earthquake, followed by tsunamis, had coincided with earthquakes occurring in the Antilles.

1853, July 15. Venezuela, Cumana, 800 or 4000 people perished. Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

1853, July 15. 12.1 N, 63.6 W, magnitude 6.7 MS, intensity IX. (reference #1209)

1853, July 15. Venezuela. Intensity IX. At 2:00 p.m. A violent earthquake in Cumana which caused considerable destruction in the city. One hundred and thirteen were killed. (reference #364)

1853, July 15 at at 14 h. 14 min. Cumana collapsed in a few minutes more than 1000 dead. (reference #1557)

1853, July 15. Earthquake of the 15th of July of 1853. Account made by an eyewitness: "Cracks opened parallel to the banks of the Manzanares river. The barracks of the infantry, artillery, cavalry, etc., everything fell like in a cavernous collapse, it was impossible to investigate the numbers of soldiers, horses, saddles, and weapons that were buried under the masonry and fell on top of each other. Still, Mr. José Jesús Martínez, Senior Assistant, asserts that the force never had less than 1000 men, that he had been saved because he left the command to communicate the order to march the troops in the direction of Cumanacoa. Mr. Diego Blanco Zerpa saw the sentinel impelled, without a doubt, by the motion of the earth, take two steps forward and kneel, rifle in hand. This sentinel was found dead in the same place where Blanco Zerpa saw him. He was saved because he jumped into the river, amazed to find its level had risen as a result of the earthquake. A masonry quadrangular prism was ripped from its base, rotating west to east, fell to the ground with the base upwards and the apex downwards. This prism has a (foot?) of base and three (feet?) of height".

"The sea withdrew from the bay of Puerto Sucre, leaving dry a quarter mile of the riverbed, and then rose to the height of 5 meters and surged onto the shore with a frightful roar, dragging the ships with smaller draw along its path along with the remains of ships lost in ancient times. The dock/pier was ruined."

"The sharp tip of the peninsula called the Dam at the mouth of the Manzaneres River, planted with coconuts, sank, leaving at water level the leaves. (One can calculate the sinking of this peninsula to have been in the order of 15 meters").

"The victims of this earthquake are more than 1000, as almost everyone who was quartered perished, buried in the rubble of the barracks. Among the civilians were:
At St. Agnes parish: 100 dead.
In the Parish Altagracia: 13 dead.
113 dead.
The injured were numerous".

(above from reference #492)

October 12, 1856, 00:45 UTC, 35.5 N, 26 E, intensity XI, magnitude 8.3. Hellenic Arc, Island of Crete, the northern shore [?]. The earthquake took place in Heracleon. A tsunami was generated. (reference #2130)

October 12, 1856, 00:45, 35.5 N, 26 E, intensity XI, Heraklion, Elevation of coast of Rhodes Island, casualties. (reference #1198)

October 12, 1856, 00h45m [local time], 35.5N, 26E, intensity = X-XI. An earthquake catastrophe in Kriti (Crete), at Iraklion (Heraklion), only 18 houses from the total of 3620 houses remained inhabitable, 538 victims, Sitia almost completely destroyed, heavy damage at Ierapetra (Hierapetra) and Gulf of Merabellou (Mirabello), at Khania all houses injured but only some of them collapsed, disaster in the island of Kasos, in Karpathos all houses damaged, in Rhodos 8 villages heavily injured, elevation of the coast, casualties, tsunami, slight damage observed in Thira (Santorin), Malta, Gozo, Karien, Cyprus, S. Syria, N. Palestina, delta of the Nile, very large shaken area extending up to Palermo, Napoli, Ancona, Zara, Athhai, Bursa? (SAM, PAT, BI), disaster at Iohnnina (Jannina) (a relais shock?), between Pentalidion and Kyparissia VI-VII, strongly felt in Cyprus. (reference #1099)

October 12, 1856, Widespread damage in northern Egypt from offshore large magnitude earthquake; sea-wave, 10 deaths. (reference #1180)

Seismic catastrophe in Crete, the city of Crystallized (Megalokastron) was entirely destroyed, except 40 houses. In the islands of Karpathos and Thassos 8,000 houses destroyed, 20 deaths. The devastations extended to the island of Rhodos. The shock was also felt in Syria, Palestine, Egypt, in Sicily, and Malta (several dwellings were destroyed). Probable epicentre: in the Mediterranean. Underwater intensity: probably XII; in Crete: XI. (reference #1093)

October 12, 1856. Hellenic Arc. A major earthquake in the Hellenic Are was felt in the Nile Delta. The earthquake occurred before dawn and lasted over 2 minutes. In Alexandria, a few old walls tumbled down; no substantial damage was done, but the people were thrown into a panic. Some old houses were damaged but only 2 lives were lost, from injuries. ...in other provincial towns of the Delta, such as Tanta and Damanhur, several minarets fell, killing some people. At Suez the shock was felt.

In Cairo the effects of the earthquake were more serious. Three successive shocks were felt, of 1, 1.5 and 2 minutes duration. The railway dock and all hotel clocks stopped and water in canals ran up the embankments; water from the Khalij canal was thrown over its sides and well-water rose to the surface. About 20 houses collapsed completely and about 200 were ruined, killing 4 people, but many houses of local construction were damaged. In the district of Bulaq, there was more debris than in Cairo. Here about 20 mosques were damaged, almost all through the collapse of their minarets, among them the mosque of Abu 'l-A'la which lost its top, with the loss of 4 lives. Panic was great throughout Cairo and a large proportion of the populace camped in open spaces for a day or two.

The earthquake had no effect on major engineering works and it was hardly felt south of Helwan. It was strongly felt by boats sailing off Egypt and as far as Central Italy. Almost the whole of the Adriatic Sea, Malta, Greece, western Anatolia, Cyprus and Palestine experienced the shock. Maximum damage was inflicted on Rhodes and Crete and neighbouring islands of Karpathos (Scarpantos) and Casos.

Aftershocks continued for a few days. Two shocks on 4 October were particularly strong, one of them at midnight causing the collapse of the minaret of the mosque of Da'ud Pasha in the district of al-Sayyida, and further damage to a few old houses in Bulaq.

(above from reference #3845)

March 22, 1859, at 8h30m , a frightful earthquake occurred , which left the capital ruined in 64 seconds; M. Cueva in Apuntamientos Historicos". This earthquake was the strongest of this century in the province of Pichincha; T. Wolf - Very long and amazing earthquake felt in all the country and it endured more than two minutes without exageration. Only due to the hour a few people were killed, because almost everybody could be safe. Albelardo G. Iturralde. (reference #1106)

March 22, 1859. At Quito, about 5000 persons killed and an immense amount of property destroyed. (reference #1073)

March 22, 1859, Ecuador, Quito, Machachi, Perucho, Pomasqui, Saint Antonio, Chillogallo; felt from Guayaquil to Magdolena and Popayan in Colombia, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

March 10 [20], 1861, 20:45 [local time]. Mendosa was destroyed by an earthquake. Fourteen thousand dead were reported. There was considerable damage at San Luiz. The damage was not so great south of Mendosa. Several homes were damaged at San Vicente and Lujan-de-Cuiga. Most of San Martin survived, but some homes were damaged. The rural environs of Mendosa suffered little damage. There were no signs of the earthquake at all at many farms, but everything was overturned at others. No subterranean rumble was heard during the earthquake (Perrey, 1864 b, ref #4118). The earthquake affected part of Chile and was felt at Santiago and Valparaiso as strong undulating oscillations lasting 50 seconds. "There was talk of a flood, which supposedly accompanied this earthquake, but I could discover absolutely no details, not even the date." (Perrey, 1864 b, ref #4118)

(above from reference #415)

March 20, 1861-At Mendozr, South America, about two-thirds of the city and 7,000 lives lost. (reference #1073)

March 20, 1861, 00:16 UTC, Argentina, San Luis, San Vicenti, Lujan, Mendoza, reached Santiago in Chile, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

March 21, 1861, Mendoza, Argentina, 18,000 dead. (reference #1002)

April 1863, Dengchuan,, Yunnan Province, 26 N, magnitude 5.5, intensity VII.

City walls and houses were damaged; some people were killed; shocks went on till the end of the year.

Dali: Most city walls and civilian houses at Shangguan were destroyed. Countless inhabitants were killed.

The shock also hit Baiyanjing.

The earthquake also struck Fengyi and Yao'an in the same year.

(above from reference #3939)

locationName: EL SALVADOR:  SANTA TOMAS, SAN VICENTE
comments:
1873, March 4. Only 15 houses remained standing. Epicenter presumably near Santa Tomas. (Reference #1554).

1873, March 4. San Salvador, Santo Tomas, Soyapango, Tonacatepeque, San Martin, Apopa, Mejicanos, Aculhuaca, Paleca, San Sebastian Texincal. Partial destruction of the capital and almost complete of the other populations mentioned. (reference #1196)

1873, March 5. Salvador, San Salvador, St. Vincent. Intensity II which corresponds to buildings may be unroofed or shattered and some may fall, the ground may be badly cracked in places and small landslips occur. (reference #1055)

1878, April 19. Sapanca. At 21h there was a locally destructive earthquake in the district of Lake Sapanca in northwestern Turkey. The region of heavy damage included Izmit, where most stone-masonry houses were damaged and some collapsed, together with four mosques. Labinia and Esme were destroyed; 40 people were killed and 500 injured. In Sapanca many houses collapsed, with casualties, and in Adapazari and Akyazi a few houses were destroyed and some lives were lost. The total losses in Izmit alone were estimated at 400,000 british pounds. Slight damage extended to Bursa, Geyve and Iznik. The shock was felt in Istanbul and was perceptible in Thrace.

Ships of the British fleet at anchor in the Gulf of Izmit experienced a series of powerful shocks that caused great concern, and the sea in their neighbourhood became agitated. There is no evidence of a seismic sea wave. In other parts of the Gulf of Izmit further west, the shock set up a sea wave, which propagated into the Sea of Marmara, where the earthquake was also felt onboard ships.

Aftershocks continued until 16 May.

(above from reference #9116)

1878, April 19, 09h. 40.8N, 29 E, intensity IX, magnitude 6.7. A disastrous shock in the Marmara region, the town Izmit (Esme) was destroyed, 40 victims, at lzmit several stone-built houses were destroyed, the others were damaged, 4 mosques collapsed, houses were thrown down also at Sapanca, felt at Bursa and also on the European side of the Bosporus, rather strong tsunami at Izmit; damage in the region of Bursa-Izmit and Sapanca, houses fissured in Istanbul, felt over all the Marmara region. (reference #1099)

1878, April 19. Asia Minor, Ismid, Esme, Sapardjia. Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

1878, April 19, 09h. 40.8N, 29E, intensity IX. (reference #1149)

1882, Sept. 7, about 3:00 [local time]. There was an earthquake at Panama, stronger than any previously known. Undulating oscillations lasted 40-45 sec; their intensity gradually increased, and then just as gradually decreased. All homes in the capital were more or less destroyed. Thick walls cracked, and some collapsed. Heavy tiles fell down from roofs and the streets were full of rubble. The cathedral was heavily damaged; a crack appeared from top to bottom in the facade; the bell towers collapsed; one of the naves was completely destroyed; the roof sagged dangerously. At the town hall, the facade collapsed and people were killed. The Panama-Colon Railway was damaged. The underwater cable to Jamaica was broken. A loud underground rumbling was heard at Gamboa. Barbacoas Port on the Chagres River, Gatun, Chagres, Cruses1 and other settlements in the interior as far as Colon, suffered damage. At Colon (Aspinwall), the railway depot was destroyed; cracks appeared in the ground; there were dead and injured.

In Venezuela, at Riosucio in the valley of the Atrato River, sand and mud volcanoes appeared. A thermal spring appeared on one of the streets at Turbo and almost flooded the city. The populace of these cities fled their homes in panic. The earthquake extended to San Juan del Norte (Nicaragua), Guayaquil (Ecuador), Maracaibo and Caracas (Venezuela), that is, it was felt along the entire northwestern coast of South America.

It was accompanied by numerous aftershocks.

Fuchs (ref #2226) adds that the earthquake was felt strongly on the islands in the Gulf of Panama. ...the "Honduras", situated in a road 3.5 km (2 miles) from Panama, felt a seaquake, preceded by a rumbling. Although no visible waves appeared on the surface, the sea began to move rapidly. The vessel began to move, as if at full speed, and ran aground on a pebble bed.

Destruction in the city of Panama, several deaths. Also felt on the islands and a tsunami. Cable breaks. Damage suffered the landward towns, even Colon. Felt in Nicaragua to Greytown, North Colombia and Venezuela to Caracas. Seismic wave down to Guayaquil. Numerous, partly final aftershock to 1883. (ref #1576).

Iida (ref #79) surmises, without much evidence, that two earthquakes occurred: one in Panama and Nicaragua, the other in Colombia.

(above from ref #415)

1882, Sept. 7, 07:50UTC. 7.298 N, 77.815 W, depth 40 km, magnitude 8.2 MS, intensity IX. (ref #1219)

1882, Sept. 7. Central America, Panama, Aspinwall, Caracas, Nicaragua, Rivas, Greytown, Colombia, Buenaventura and Cartagena, Ecuador, Guayaquil to Maracaibo. Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (ref #1055)

1882, Oct, [should be Sept.] 7, 1882, 09:20 UTC. 9N, 82 W. Great Panama earthquake felt Ecuador to Nicaragua with intensity VIII plus at Panama and eruption at Atrato duration 60 sec. Cable between Aspinwall and Jamaica broken about 50 miles from isthmus. Felt in Rivas and Greytown. (ref #1199)

From our analysis of the historical data, we conclude that an epicentral location northeast of Colon is more likely. Furthermore, the intensity data indicate that the event may have been a shallow underthrusting earthquake resulting from plate convergence and that its magnitude was significantly greater than 7... The generation of a significant tsunami by the 7 Sept. 1882 earthquake would suggest that a Modified Mercalli intensity of XI was attained in the epicentral area. This would correspond to a magnitude of 8.3, estimated from the maximum observed MM intensity (Io)... (reference #1575)

locationName: SPAIN:  ARENAS DEL REY, VEGA, ALHAMA, MALAGA
comments:
1884, Dec 25, 21:08 UTC, 36 deg 57 min N, 3 deg 59 min W, intensity IX, Arenas del Rey. The destructive earthquake felt in Spain ocurred in the evening of December 25th, 1884, in a region south-east of the city of Granada, causing widespread material and personal damage in villages and towns of the provinces of Granada and Malaga. Total number of casualties for the 1884 earthquake is estimated at 745 dead and 1475 wounded. Damage to buildings extended to 4399 houses totally destroyed and 6316 partially damaged. (reference #1124)

1884, Dec. 25, 20h55m, 37 N, 4 W, intensity X-XI. An earthquake catastrophe in Andalusia, mostly affected were Alhania (973 houses destroyed, 307 victims), Albunuelas (362 h., 102 v.), Arenas (160 h., 135 v.), Tayensa (100 h., 10 v.), Loja (47 v.), Zafarraya (371 h., 50 v.), Murchas (805 h.), at Malaga all churches were fissured, Granada VI?, Madrid V, at Sevilla a part of the monastery collapsed, near Alhama and Guerifar lanslides, large cracks in the ground, horizontal movements in the region of Periana, in total 17,178 houses destroyed or damaged in the provinces Granada and Malaga, felt in Morocco. (reference #1099)

1884, Dec. 25. Intensity XI. Catastrophic earthquake in the region of the Vega, between Granada and Malaga, where more than 40 localities have been destroyed in whole or in part. Total collapsed houses: 4339; severely damaged: 12,779. People killed: 745. Arenas del Rey was razed to the ground. The town of Alhama has lost 75% of its houses and 400 people on its 10,000 inhabitants. In Malaga: 300 homes and severely damaged 15 million of damage. In Granada: many houses cracked, but very little has suffered Alhamabra. (reference #1093)

1884-1885. Spanish peninsula, which began on December 26, 1884, and continued with irregular interruptions until the middle of April, 1885. The greatest destruction of life and property was in Andalusia. Altogether 745 persons were killed and 1,485 injured, and 17,000 buildings were more or less damaged, 4,400 of the number being completely wrecked. Widespread destruction and suffering resulted from this visitation. Towards the close of November there was a renewal of the disturbances, which extended also to the adjacent African coast. (reference #1073)

1884, Dec. 25-27, Spain (Malaga and Granada), Alhama, Malaga, Seville; 40-50 towns damaged. Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

1884, Dec. 25, 21:08:09 UTC, Arenas del Rey, 36 deg 57 min N, 3 deg 59 min W, magnitude 6.7, intensity X. (reference #1193)

1884, Dec. 25. Malaga, Spain. (reference #1002)

Generally referred to as August 31, 1886, as the earthquake occurred at 9:51 pm local time. Eight minutes later there was a severe aftershock. This was the most damaging earthquake to occur in the southeastern U.S. and one of the largest historic shocks in eastern North America. Structural damage was reported within several hundred kilometers from Charleston, and long-period effects were observed at distances exceeding 1,000 kilometers.

Mw 7.02, Intensity X(above from reference #542)

Mw 7.3 (reference #12415 and #12416)

1890, December 12. Intensity VII. Pati: Central Java - this quake also felt at Juwana; caused many houses to fall. Several people killed and injured. (reference #1188)

1890, December 12. 7h 50m a.m. Java, Djoewana in Japara and over great part of Java. Intensity II which corresponds to buildings may be unroofed or shattered and some may fall, the ground may be badly cracked in places and small landslips occur. (reference #1055)

April 17, 1891, Jiexiu and Xiaoyi, Shanxi Province, 37.1 N, 111.9 E, magnitude 5.75, intensity VII.

Jiexiu: Some storehouses, prisons, city walls and battlements collapsed or sunk. Official and civilian buildings in the city and villages were still inhabitable despite of suffering from relatively heavy wall collapsing. But the case was different with Jintun, Changle, Xizhan and Quannanzhuang villages in the southern and westsouthern part of the city,where whole rooms even whole houses toppled down. 5 persons were killed and more than 30 injured. (In addition, according to an investigation made in recent years, 18 cave dwellings in Zhenxing Village fell in, killing 18 persons)

Xiaoyi: Losses were generally similar to those suffered in Jiexiu. 8 persons were killed, 35 injured.

Yitang (southwest of Jiexiu): The top of a tower fell under shaking. Cave dwellings collapsed.

Lingshi: Some houses cracked, others collapsed.

The quake also hit Fenyang, Pingyao, Changzhi, Yonghe of Shanxi Province; Suide, Jiaxian of Shaanxi Province.

(above from reference #3939)

1893 Nov 17. South Quchan. Preceded by a strong shock on 20 Oct, an earthquake in the evening of the 8 Jumada I, 1311 devastated Quchan, particularly affecting the populous upper Atrak valley and the sparsely inhabited district of Sar Vilayat. The town of Quchan, already ruined in 1871 and subsequently rebuilt, was utterly destroyed. All public buildings, including the telegraph office, the bazaar with its 1100 shops, part of the mosque and its minarets, the madraseh, caravanserai, and the palace of the Ilkhan, collapsed. All houses and the remnants of the walls of the town were destroyed and at least 5000 people were killed. The dome of the Imamzadeh of Sultan Ibrahim and a few houses rebuilt with timber bracing after the 1871 earthquake, were the only structures left standing. In the town and its surroundings qanat galleries caved in, producing crevices in the ground 5 to 8 metres deep that added to the destruction. In the Atrak valley all the villages between Yazdanabad, Kalbalasi, Kalukhi and Jartudeh were almost totally destroyed, with an estimated 10000 casualties and the loss of more than 30000 animals. Damage was equally serious in the mountainous region of Kuh-i Muhammad Beg and in the dihistan of Sar Vllayat, as far south as Chakaneh Ulya and Saqi Beg. The number of people killed in this region is not known but the damage was so heavy that a few villages were abandoned. Also, there is some evidence to show that the direct routes to Sabzavar via Chakaneh Sufla and particularly the summer track via Bar had to be abandoned for a year or so... The shock was felt all over Turkmenistan and as far as Tehran 640 km away from the epicentral region. It was followed by aftershocks that continued for almost 6 months. On 18 Nov, at night, an aftershock caused serious damage at Katlar and Gabrabad where the mosque collapsed. At dawn on the 19th an even stronger shock... caused great damage to Katlar, Kalukhi and Gabrabad. (ref 1117)

1893, Nov 17. A severe shock was felt on Fri night in the town of Kashan (in fact - Quchan) two thirds of which was destroyed. Mild earthquake shocks continued to be felt in Mashhad and town of (Quchan not Kashan) is reported to be totally wrecked. There has been great lose of life and property, and the supply of food and water is exhausted. Most of the survivors have fled to the mountains. A correspondent who has visited Quchan telegraphs as follows: "Quchan is a heap of ruins, not a house remains standing. Bodies are still being recovered. It is established that the loss of life has been in the proportion of two deaths to every house. The sanitary condition of the place is very bad. Earthquake shocks, preceded by loud reports in the hills to west, continue to be felt only in the town and in the immediate vicinity. The neighboring villages escaped with little damage. Communications are suspended for the time, and the prospects are not encouraging. There is some talk of building a new town to the eastward. A violent earthquake occurred in Khorasan. Two thirds of Bojnurd was completely destroyed and there was a very high mortality with 15,000 dead. A severe snow fall followed exceeding half metre in depth. Muay'yed-od Dovlah a personal representative of the Shah, arrived to take charge of relief measures. The city of Mashhad suffered slight damage. This evidence was recorded by Sani'ud Dovlah Dovlah under "Jamadi-al-avval 08, 131 1 A.H.L. (= Nov 20, 1893)". (ref #1217)

1893, Nov 17, 15:06 GMT. 37.2 N, 58.4 E, magnitude 6.6, intensity IX-X, 18000 killed, Kuchan I. (reference #3437)

1893, Nov 17, 15:06 GMT, 37.2 N, 58.4 E, depth 7-17 km, magnitude 6.6, intensity IX-X, Kuchan and vicinity destroyed; 18,000 dead. (ref #223)

1893, Nov 17, 8h 23m a.m. [p.m.?] Russian Turkestan, Kassan, Samarkand, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (ref #1055)
On 12 Jan 1894, in the evening, another aftershock [of 17 Nov 1893 earthquake] caused the collapse of ruins in Quchan with loss of life. (reference #1117)

Reference #1198 lists epicenter April 27, 1894, 19:42 UTC, intensity XI, some deaths.

Reference #1099 lists epicenter April 27, 1894, 19:42 UTC, 38.7 N, 23.1 E, magnitude 6.9, intensity XI-XII. Continuation of the activity in Lokris, a cumulative effect along a fault trace of 55 km, 1-4 m wide, 0.3- 1.5 m jump, tension cracks up to 7 km, left hand strikeslip movement?, many landslides, changes in wells, tsunami of 3 m between Atalhndi and Agios Konstantinos, main disaster between Agib Konstantinos and Arkitsa up to Xiparissia, both shocks destroyed 3783 houses at 69 localities, 255 persons were killed [listed with April 2, 1894 event], by a 1-2 m subsidence in the basin of' Atalhndi the Nesos Patroklou (Gaidarion) peninsula became an island, 4250 aftershocks till May 6.

Reference #1093 lists earthquake on April 20 and 27, 1894. Catastrophic earthquake in Locride.
3,858 houses destroyed. 726 deaths. 2,148 burnt houses by shock. Weak tsunami at Kisagata. (reference #150)

1894, November 16, 18h52m. Calabrian Arc, Calabria, the shore of the Tyrrhenian Sea. A destructive earthquake occurred. Changes in the composition and level of spring water took place in many places. Fissures appeared, and the ground caved in here and there. Some fishermen in boats near Pellaro thought their boats struck against an underwater rock. To fishermen in another boat it seemed that a shark had passed under them. Some of the fishermen had the impression that dynamite was being exploded under their vessel to stun fish. People in the mail -boat navigating fiom the Lipari Islands felt a strong shock. The earthquake was accompanied by tsunami on the shore from Tropea to Cannitello. (reference #2130)

Reference #1093 lists earthquake on Nov 16, 1894, in the province of Reggio at Palmi and S. Cristina, intensity X, 101 deaths.

Reference #1099 lists earthquake on Nov 16, 1894, 17:48 UTC, 38.3 N, 15.8 E, intensity X. A disastrous shock in the western part of the province of Reggio, particularly at Palmi and S. Cristina, 96-101 victims, destructive also at Seminara, S. Procopio, Bagnara and Castellaci d'Oppido, etc., felt at Salerno, Cotronei, Palermo.

Reference #1055 lists earthquake on May 13 or 14, 1895, 22:42 UTC, in Paramythia, Dragani, Albania, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts.

Reference #1109 lists earthquake on May 13, 1895, 23h local time, intensity X in Himara, Albania.

Reference #1093 lists earthquake on May 13, 1895, in Paramythia, Dragani, and Philiatos, many deaths.

1896, April 18. Intensity Vii-VIII. Timor Island: The quake was also felt at Alor Island; 250 people killed and most o the settlement damaged. (reference #1188)

1896, April 18. Duth East Indies, Alor in Timor. Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

Reference #1068 lists earthquake on August 31, 1896, 40 N, 141 E, 206 deaths, 5,911 houses destroyed, at Senhoku, Ugo.

Reference #1097 lists earthquake on August 31, 1896, at Rikutyu and Ugo with 60 km of 1m subsidence and upheaval.

Reference #1055 lists earthquake on August 31, 1896, at Ugo, Rokugo, intensity II which corresponds to buildings may be unroofed or shattered and some may fall, the ground may be badly cracked in places and small landslips occur.

September 22, 1898, Daixian, Shanxi Province, 39.1 N, 113 E, magnitude 5.5, intensity VII. A violent earthquake suddenly struck the Prefecture, causing particularly heavy loss to the prefecture seat. More than 570 rooms in the city collapsed. Many cells in the prison fell, a number of persons were injured. Half of the Jingbian Tower fell, killing 12 persons. (reference #3939)

February 15, 1901, Dengchuan, Yunnan Province, 26 N, 100.1 E, magnitude 6, intensity VIII.

Almost all tile-roofed houses by the east and west lakes of Dengchuan collapsed. Low earth banks between fields cracked, black water gushed out from fissures. Stone archways in county seat collapsed. The roof of the Confucian temple fell down, smashing all tiles. 30-40% of the mud walls collapsed, the rest all cracked. A few wood house-frames were broken or disjointed. Countless people and domestic animals were killed.

Eryuan: More than 100 houses (abont 10% of the total) collapsed. A part of the houses in Niujie Street fell, another 30% were tilted. Some persons were killed.

Jianchuan: The mud walls of a few houses collapsed.

The shock was felt in Dali.

(above from reference #3939)

Reference #223 lists earthquake on Feb 13, 1902, 09:39:30 utc,  40.7 N, 48.6 E, depth 15 km, magnitude 6.9, intensity 8-9; 3496 buildings out of 9084 were destroyed in the surrounding vi11ages; 3943 were damaged; 86 were killed and 60 injured.

Reference #1138 lists earthquake on Sept 25, 1903, 01:20 UTC, 35.2 N, 58.2 E, magnitude 6.5, 350 deaths.

Reference #12864 lists >350 deaths and 25 villages destroyed, Turshiz destroyed/damaged.

On April 19, 1907, 05 local time [April 18 20:59:48 UTC] a destructive earthquake (intensity IX) in Camarines Province, which, within an area of 200 km in length and 60 in width, wrecked many masonry buildings, produced great fissures in the ground and landslides in the mountains. Only two cases of death and a few of injuries received have been recorded. (reference #1072)

Reference #1058 lists two earthquake on April 18, 1907:
20:59:48 UTC, 14 N, 123 E, magnitude 7.6
23:52:04 UTC, 13.5 N, 123 E, magnitude 7.4

Oct 21, 1907, 04:23:20 UTC, 38.5 N, 67.9 E, depth 35 km, magnitude 7.4 MS, intensity IX.
Oct 21, 1907, 04:44 UTC, 38.7 N, 68.1 E, depth 24 km, magnitude 7.3 MS.
According to the reports "...A grandiose misfortune encompassed. .. the whole region on the southern slope of the Gissar Range .... The misfortune resulted from a series of average earthquakes. In terms of the size of the affected area, the extent of damage, and in the number of victims. The region of greatest destruction primarily encompassed the southern slope of the Gissar Range.

... The earthquake hit the mountains, destroying all the mountain kishlaks (villages in Central Asia). . . . Besides Karatag, almost destroyed by the earthquake, several other kishlaks in the Gissar and Denau regions also were heavily damaged--some to an even greater extent. The earthquake inflicted human losses and killed domestic stock. Topographic changes...occurred in many places in the macroseismic zone. They were limited mainly to landslides of steep forested river banks, ravines, and steep slopes of high hills . . . Slides of rooted rock were also noted in several places."

Two tremors are clearly isolated on the seismograms of the European stations, providing a separate definition of the M (an independent determination of the MLH was made by Professor M. Bath for the two tremors). Macroseismic information for the two tremors is difficult to separate. According to N. V. Shebalin, the first tremor may be linked with the meridian fracture, and the second with the latitudinal fracture.

(above from reference #223)

Oct 21, 1907, magnitude 8.0, intensity X, Tajikistan (Karatag), 12000 deaths. (reference #1173)

Oct 21, 1907, Uzbekistan, 12000 deaths. (reference #1250)

Aug 14, 1909, 35.5 N, 137 E, 976 houses destroyed, 41 deaths, near Anegawa, Oomi, [no tsunami listed]. (reference #1068)

Aug 14, 1909, 06:30 UTC, 35.4 N, 136.3 E, shallow depth, magnitude 6.9, 41 deaths, 976 houses destroyed. Tsunami height 1.8 m generated by subsidence of Biwa Lake side. (reference #150)

1911, June 15, 23:26 [local time]. 29 N, 129 E, depth 160 km, magnitude 8.7 MS. There was a strong earthquake which affected all the Ryukyu Islands and the south of Taiwan Island, The length of the zone in which the earthquake was felt was 1300 km. Kikaigashima Island suffered especially. There, 400 homes were totally destroyed and one person died. Five homes were destroyed and five persons died on Tokunoshima Island. On Ishigaki Island, the destruction was also rather heavy and there were human victims. At Ojima (Kamikoshiki Island), Kagoshima Prefecture, there was minor destruction. In Miyazaki Prefecture, chimneys fell, walls collapsed or cracked, etc. The earthquake was felt strongly in Fukuoka Prefecture. There are reports that at Chinzei (Kakeroma Island) on the evening of the same day, a tsunami was observed which washed away more than half of the homes. At Agina (Amami-o-shima Island), a fisherman also noted a change in sea level following a strong shock. The assumed travel time of the tsunami to Aburatsu was 65 minutes.

Reference #88:

1911, June 15, 14:26:00 UTC. 29 N, 129 E, depth 160 km, magnitude 8.7 MS.

Reference #130:

1911, June 15, 14:26 UTC. 29 N, 129 E, magnitude 8.2 MS.

Reference #1006:

1911, June 15. 29 N, 129 E, depth 160 km, magnitude 8.7 MS.
