Kamalini Kanda, 50, died of heart attack out of fear during the tremor at Kamalpur in Dhalai district in Tripura, an official of the Tripura Disaster Management Centre said. Five other people were injured in different parts of the state during the quake. (reference #12080)

An earthquake measuring 5.1 on the Richter scale has hit Iran's southern city of Khonj in Fars Province, killing four people and injuring four others. As a result of the earthquake, which occurred at 6 a.m. local time on Friday, the walls of old buildings crumbled and the local power grid was shut down. (reference #11733)

Two people were killed and 36 others injured due to wall collapse of a residential quarter after an earthquake struck Taikkyi, Myanmar's Yangon region Monday, China's Xinhua news agency reported a health official as saying on Tuesday. The two victims are a 58-year-old military officer and a six-year-old child. All the injured were hospitalized and 31 of them already discharged, Dr Than Myint, Deputy Director of the Directorate of Township People's Health, told Xinhua.

The moderate earthquake of 5.8 magnitude hit the Yangon region Monday night with Taikkyi township being the nearest to the epicenter.

The quake damaged some religious buildings in Taikkyi while some residential quarters of township police station and civilian houses also collapsed, according to the initial report. The quake struck at 8.49 pm local time with an epicenter of 35.4 km northwest of Yangon and 8.04 km southwest of Taikkyi township, outskirt of Yangon region.The quake was also felt in some townships including Insein, Hlaingtharyar, South Dagon and Bahan of Yangon region and in Maubin township of Ayeyawaddy region. An earthquake yesterday rocked China's western Xinjiang region, killing eight people and injuring 23 as more than 1,500 homes crumbled, state media reported. The Xinjiang Earthquake Administration said 23 people had been injured, including one seriously, and more than 180 houses had collapsed in the lightly populated area. Most houses in the area were made of wood and mudbricks or rock, it said. Some people were buried after their adobe homes collapsed, said Wang Fuyou, Chinese Communist Party chief of Taxkorgan County, according to Xinhua. Rescuers were searching for people trapped in the rubble in Quzgun, the worst-hit village, which has a population of 449, Wang said. More than 1,500 homes collapsed in Quzgun, Xinhua said. More than 9,000 people were relocated in the region, while 1,000 soldiers and 1,500 civilians were participating in rescue efforts, it said. (reference #11811)

A woman police officer died from shock on Thursday and 18 students were admitted to hospital following an afternoon tremor that hit the northwest region of Mwanza.The minor tremor that occurred at 12.56 p.m. lasting for 10 seconds caused the death of the woman police of Misungwi police station, said Ahmed Msangi, Mwanza Regional Police Commander. Two people killed, more than 120 injured; extensive damage, including main port; roads cracked on Kos. At least 360 people injured and walls cracked in Bodrum, Turkey. (ref #1350)

A powerful overnight earthquake shook holiday resorts in Greece and Turkey, injuring nearly 500 people and leaving two tourists dead on the Greek island of Kos, where revelers at a bar were crushed in a building collapse. Some of the injuries were caused as tourists and local residents scrambled out of buildings and even leapt from balconies after the 6.5-magnitude quake struck at about 1:30 am local time. Several hundred thousand vacationers and locals in the two countries were kept awake by dozens of aftershocks that followed the main quake, with many sleeping outdoors on sunbeds or slumped on cafe tables. Authorities on Kos said the two dead tourists were from Sweden and Turkey. Thirteen others injured were airlifter to other Greek hospitals, include a foreign national who had to have a leg amputated and another with life-threatening head injuries. In neighboring Turkey, authorities said some 350 people were hurt, most with light injuries as they fled buildings. Seismologists said the shallow depth of the quake was to blame for the damage and a 60 cm sea swell that scattered cars, boats, and trash bins across shorelines in the east Aegean Sea. (ref #11848)

The earthquake happened in Gokova Bay on July 21, 2017 at 01:31 local time (22:31 UTC) at 36.9620N 27.4053E (KOERI), with the moment magnitude of Mw=6.6 (Ml= 6.2) at a depth of 5km. The epicenter is about 12km ENE of Kos, Greece and 8 km SSW of Bodrum, Turkey. The earthquake was highly felt in Southwestern Aegean Region, especially in Mugla Province. The fault mechanism calculations reveal that the earthquake occurred with a normal faulting (ref #11858)

The epicentral region is an active seismic zone due to the presence of three main tectonic plate borders: African, Arabian, and Anatolian plates. To the south of the epicenter, the Hellenic subduction zone is subducting beneath the Anatolian microplate; to the east, the Anatolian microplate is in strike-slip motions along its northeast and southeast boundaries with the Eurasian and Arabian plates, respectively. As shown in Fig. 1, the 2017 Mw 6.6 event occurred as an intraplate earthquake in the Aegean Sea region within the Anatolian microplate which is part of the Eurasian Plate. According to Kurt et al. (1999), the epicentral area is under a N-S extensional tectonic regime (35-40 mm/year according to Ebeling et al. 2012) which is most probably attributed to the westerly escape of the Anatolian plate in response to the collision of the African, Eurasian, and Arab plates. (ref #12056)

The earthquake Mw6.6 (macroseismic intensity VIII, ESI-07 scale) that occurred on July 20, 2017 at 22:31 UTC (01:31 local time) in Gokova Bay, SE Aegean Sea, induced minor damages to contemporary structures at the island of Kos, Greece, while severe damages were reported on Venetian and Ottoman-era constructions, causing two deaths. Focusing on the island of Kos, secondary effects were reported in the eastern part, including liquefaction- related phenomena and tsunami[...]Liquefaction-induced lateral spreading caused severe structural damages at the waterfront area of the city of Kos[...]The majority of the documented liquefaction related failures was located at the waterfront area of the city of Kos. In particular, the new port and the custom buildings were strongly affected, resulting to the loss of their functionality. At the main pier, a subsidence of up to 35 cm and tilting of the lighthouse were documented. Cracks parallels to the seashore were reported in the old harbor of the city behind the quay wall with horizontal displacement up to 10 cm and up to 35 cm vertical offset. Liquefaction manifestations were reported in cape Louros, an area covered by Holocene age coastal deposits. (ref #12410)

A strong earthquake of magnitude 6 on the Richter scale scared the Arequipans this afternoon, which led to the release of rocks in the Panamericana Sur. The tremor leaves so far one mortal victim and several people injured. The regional governor of Arequipa, Yamila Osorio, reported the first victim and sent her condolences to the relatives. "One person is reported dead from a collapse on Secocha - Urasqui road (Camaná), and two were injured, and my condolences to the affected families," the regional authority wrote on his Twitter account. At least 25 people have been killed in a powerful 6.7-magnitude aftershock that struck the remote highlands of earthquake-rattled Papua New Guinea. The fatalities raise PNG's total death toll to more than 100 since last week's quake. The tremor was the most severe in a series over 100 aftershocks in recent days.

It struck overnight close to the epicentre of last week's magnitude-7.5 quake in the border region of Hela and Southern Highland provinces, 600km from the capital Port Moresby.

"At least 18 people were killed in Como district and two were killed in another district in the overnight earthquake," William Bando, Hela Province administrator, told dpa on Wednesday.

In neighbouring Southern Highlands, five people were killed.

"Unfortunately, in Lalibu district, a building fell and we lost five lives," Thomas Eluh, an administrator of Southern Highlands Province, told dpa.

(reference #12052)

Monday's major earthquake in western Japan left 4 people dead and more than 370 injured.

9-year-old Rina Miyake was killed when a wall collapsed while she was on her way to school. 80-year-old Minoru Yasui was also hit by a falling wall in a different area. He was on his way to do volunteer work for a local school. 85-year-old Motochika Goto was killed after a bookshelf fell on him. Many of the injured have been taken to hospital with the biggest number of injuries reported in the prefecture of Osaka.

Authorities are also dealing with damage. Firefighters have put out three house fires in northern Osaka. Pipes have cracked underneath some roads and ceiling tiles fell in city halls in Osaka, Hyogo and Nara Prefectures as well as at the terminal building of Osaka airport. Around 1,300 people have fled to evacuation centers set up across Osaka. 100,000 homes are without gas and water outages are being reported in the northern half of Osaka.

(all above from reference #12168)

People in Osaka are counting the cost of Monday's major earthquake and bracing for more. Tremors believed to be aftershocks have been rattling the prefecture. And the death toll has risen to 5. The magnitude-6.1 quake left a huge crack in a school ground in northern Osaka Prefecture. Officials say at least 470 buildings have been damaged across 4 prefectures. The quake has left 5 people dead, including a 9-year-old girl. More than 380 others have been injured. More than 1,000 people are staying in temporary shelters. (reference #12169)

USD 7 billion in overall losses (reference #12634)

A 63-year-old man from Rawang village in Batang Barus district, Solok regency, West Sumatra, was killed in an earthquake that hit the area on Saturday. "Bustami [the victim], affectionately known as Buyuang Jenggo, was resting at home after washing his garlic harvest, with his wife and child, when the earthquake struck and he was crushed by a collapsed wall," said village head Syamsul Azwar. Local administration has reported no other casualties so far, although many buildings are presumed damaged. Meanwhile, in neighboring Danau Kembar district, two residents were injured, 10 houses were heavily damaged and two houses burned down. (reference #12183)

The earthquake caused the fall of the front of the central police station of Port-de-Paix, which did not make a victim among the occupants. The rest of the building did not suffer visible damage. No major damage has so far been reported with regard to road, port, airport, health, education, sports and telecommunication infrastructures, with the exception of a cultural center that collapsed in Gros-Morne, in the Artibonite. (reference #12247)

The earthquake caused the death of 17 people - 9 in Port-de-Paix, 1 in Saint-Louis du Nord (North-West) and 7 in Gros Morne (Artibonite). At least 333 people are injured, most of them in hospitals in the North West, Artibonite and North departments. Hundreds of homes are destroyed or damaged. According to initial assessments, 7,783 families are in need of urgent humanitarian assistance in the North West, Artibonite and North departments due to the partial or total destruction of their homes. The first evaluations of the teams deployed in the field reported 353 houses destroyed and 7,430 heavily or slightly damaged, some of which have cracks. Most of the damage was recorded in Port-de-Paix (North-West) and Gros-Morne (Artibonite). Infrastructure assessments are beginning to become clearer as sector teams are deployed. Some service infrastructures have suffered damage. In the Artibonite, 42 institutional buildings, schools, churches and other service institutions are heavily or slightly damaged in Gros Morne. Four national and private schools are destroyed in Pilate in the North.

The Directorate of Civil Protection (DPC) in its latest revised balance sheet of Thursday, October 11, indicates that the earthquake of October 6 killed 18 people and 580 wounded . According to the latest evaluations, 11,497 houses (7,430 previous balance sheet) were either destroyed or damaged, 90% of them in the communes of Bassin-Bleu, Port-de-Paix, Saint-Louis (North-West) and Gros-Morne (Artibonite). The most affected commune in the north is Pilate where 15 people are injured and 533 homes affected. (reference # 12257)

7783 families are in urgent need of assistance, due to the partial or total collapse of their house. Damage is mainly concentrated at Port-de-Paix (Nord-Ouest) and Gros-Morne (Artibonite) with 353 collapsed houses and 7430 severely to lightly damaged houses, including some cracks. Some health and education infrastructure have been damaged. In the department of Artibonite, 42 institutional buildings (schools, churches and other) are either severely or lightly damaged at Gros Morne. Four national and private schools collapsed at Pilate in the Nord department. (reference #12299)

Tectonic Summary

The March 1, 2019, M 7.0 Peru earthquake near Lake Titicaca, occurred as the result of normal faulting at an intermediate depth, approximately 260 km beneath southeastern Peru within the lithosphere of the subducted Nazca plate. Focal mechanism solutions indicate that rupture occurred on either a steeply dipping normal fault striking westward, or on a shallowly dipping normal fault striking to the southeast. Slip on a fault of either orientation would accommodate the down-dip extension of the Nazca slab. At the location of the earthquake, the oceanic Nazca plate moves east-northeast relative to the South America plate at a rate of about 71 mm/yr, subducting at the Peru-Chile Trench west of the Peruvian coast and sinking into the mantle beneath South America. Like most western South America earthquakes, this event was caused by strains generated by the ongoing subduction process.

Earthquakes like this event, with focal depths between 70 and 300 km, are commonly termed intermediate-depth earthquakes. Intermediate-depth earthquakes represent deformation within subducted slabs rather than at the shallow plate interface between subducting and overriding tectonic plates. They typically cause less damage on the ground surface above their foci than is the case with similar-magnitude shallow-focus earthquakes, but large intermediate-depth earthquakes may be felt at great distance from their epicenters. Deep-focus earthquakes, those with focal depths greater than 300 km, also occur in the subducted Nazca plate farther east from the Peru-Chile Trench, beneath western Brazil and central Argentina. Earthquakes have been reliably located to depths of about 650 km in this region.

The Peru-Chile Trench is an area that hosts large earthquakes quite regularly. Within 500 km of the February 22nd earthquake, there have been 10 other intermediate depth earthquakes with magnitudes of 6.5+ over the preceding century. Today's earthquake is the largest of these; another M 7.0 event occurred about 280 km to the northwest in July 1991, at a depth of about 100 km. That event caused some damage in Cuzco.

(all above from reference #1053)

In the Goyeneche Hospital: one person was admitted to the emergency service for cardiac arrest, his current situation is deceased. At Hospital Honorio Delgado one person from Socabaya district entered the emergency service due to fall and is currently under observation. (reference #12387)

Based on data collected by East Lombok BPBD, the impact of the earthquake caused 2 deaths, 44 people were injured, 32 houses collapsed and 499 houses were moderately damaged and lightly damaged. 2 people died were tourists from Malaysia who were crushed by avalanche material due to an earthquake in the area of ​​Tiu Kelep Waterfall, North Lombok Regency which is under the foot of Mount Rinjani. One victim has been identified in the name of Tommy (14 years) a Malaysian citizen, while the other has not been identified. In East Lombok, 8 villages are highly affected in Montong Gading sub-district, where 843 houses are severely damaged, 1,594 are moderately damaged and 2,019 houses are lightly damaged in these villages. A 6.1-magnitude earthquake jolted Taiwan on Thursday, the US Geological Survey said, disrupting traffic and injuring 17 people. An official at the Hualien county fire department told AFP that two people were injured by falling rocks. The National Fire Agency said one, a Malaysian male tourist, had been rushed to hospital in a critical condition after suffering a cardiac arrest, a leg fracture and head injuries. The agency added that there were also 15 injuries reported around Taipei and that two buildings in the city were temporarily evacuated due to structural damages after the tremor. (reference #12417)

Sad news to report this morning after it was confirmed that the Malaysian citizen injured in a 6.1 magnitude earthquake in Taiwan's Taroko Gorge National Park on April 18, has now died. Forty-year-old Choo Yip Chean was hiking the Lushui Trail at the national park in Hualien when the quake occurred. He was injured when hit by falling rocks caused by the shaking. (reference #12418)

Two (2) moderate-sized earthquakes with Magnitude 5.4 and 5.9 occurred on 27 July 2019 , 4:16 AM and 7:37 AM respectively , with epicenters located northeast of ltbayat , Batanes at shallow focal depths . A total of 266 damaged houses (81 - partially, 185 totally) were reported due to the earthquake in ltbayat, Batanes. A total of two (2) schools, two (2) health facilities, and ten (10) road sections were reported to have sustained damages due to series of earthquakes. A powerful 5.8 magnitude earthquake struck northeast Pakistan on Tuesday, badly damaging scores of homes and shops and killing at least 22 people and injuring over 700, officials said.

The quake badly damaged a key road leading to the town of Mirpur in the Pakistan-administered part of Kashmir and adjoining villages, where most of the damage was located. Mushtaf Minhas, information minister in Pakistan-held Kashmir, said 22 people, including women and children, were killed in the quake, mostly due to collapsing roofs and walls.

An Associated Press reporter saw dozens of partially damaged homes along a road leading to Mirpur, where doctors were treating quake victims at open areas outside the city's main government-run hospital due to a shortage of beds.

TV footage also showed cracked roads, damaged homes, shops and vehicles in Mirpur, where a breach at a main canal was submerging villages.

Tuesday's earthquake levelled homes and shops and split open roads in an area between the towns of Jhelum and Mirpur to the north, part of which is in Pakistan's portion of the disputed territory of Kashmir.

The chronogramic value of 'tughyani-e-behad' is 1094 H which gives the corresponding year of 1683 AD. Ref #1053:

Tectonic Summary

The December 29, 2020 earthquake near Petrinja, Croatia, occurred as a result of shallow strike-slip faulting within the Eurasia Plate. Focal mechanism solutions for the event indicate that rupture occurred on a nearly vertical fault striking either to the southeast or southwest. The location and depth of the event indicate that this was an intraplate earthquake occurring within the Eurasia plate as opposed to along a major tectonic boundary.

Tectonics of the Mediterranean Sea, in the convergent boundary region between Africa and Eurasia, are complex, and involve the motions of numerous microplates and regional-scale structures. The Adriatic block immediately west of today's earthquake is thought to move somewhat independently to Eurasia and Africa, driving surrounding faulting in Italy and along the eastern Adriatic coast from Croatia to Albania.

This is the largest earthquake to occur in Croatia since the advent of modern seismic instrumentation. It was preceded by two sizeable foreshocks, a magnitude 4.7 and a magnitude 5.2 on December 28. About one in twenty earthquakes have foreshocks. An earthquake of similar size to the recent M6.4 occurred in 1880 near Zagreb and there have been three magnitude 6 and larger earthquakes within 200 km of the December 29, 2020 earthquake since 1900. Recently a M5.6 earthquake occurred on November 27, 1990, 175 km to the southeast which injured 10 people.

Tectonic Summary
The May 21, 2021 M6.1 earthquake in south-central China near the cities of Dali and Lijiang occurred as the result of strike-slip faulting at relatively shallow depths. The earthquake occurred on either a southeast striking right-lateral fault, or on a southwest striking left-lateral fault. The regional geologic context is consistent with right-lateral strike slip motion. The earthquake occurred within a broad zone of strike-slip faults that demark, in part, the boundary between the Eurasia and India plates. These seismically active strike-slip faults and smaller faults in their vicinity produce frequent, yet often moderate (smaller than M7.0) earthquakes. In the past century, 24 earthquakes of M6.0 or greater have occurred within 250 km of the May 21 earthquake, with one of those earthquakes (May 29, 1976) being M7.0. The most recent moderate magnitude earthquake in this region occurred on August 30, 2008 (M6.0). The August 2008 M6.0 earthquake led to extensive regional damage and at least 43 fatalities. Other earthquakes in this region with similar magnitudes have led to tens to hundreds of fatalities. The steep regional topography can also lead to earthquake shaking-induced landslides and liquefaction (ground failure). 
Generally, strike-slip faults and earthquakes in south-central China result from the southeastward motion of the Earth's crust that is driven by the collision of the Indian and Eurasian continental plates beneath the Himalaya Mountains and the Tibetan Plateau farther to the west. The Tibetan Plateau exhibits east-west oriented extension, as evidenced by faults, earthquake normal faulting mechanisms, and geodetic observations. The extension of the Tibetan Plateau is further accommodated by extrusion of crustal material southward in south-central China along the strike-slip faults where the May 21 earthquake occurred.

(all above from ref #1053)

Ref #1053:
Tectonic Summary 
The August 14, 2021 M 7.2 Haiti earthquake occurred as the result of oblique reverse motion along the Enriquillo-Plantain Garden fault zone, ~125 km west of the Haitian capital Port-au-Prince. The earthquake occurred at shallow depths on either a reverse fault striking west and dipping to the north with a component of left-lateral slip, or a fault striking southeast and dipping to the southwest with a component of right-lateral slip. At the location of the earthquake, the local plate boundary is dominated by left-lateral strike slip motion and compression. The plate boundary in this location accommodates eastward, left-lateral motion of the Caribbean plate relative to the North America plate. Within this context, the earthquake likely occurred on the east-west striking, north dipping fault plane with a component of left-lateral slip [...]
The location and focal mechanism solutions of the August 2021 earthquake are consistent with the event resulting from primarily reverse faulting with a component of left-lateral strike slip faulting on the Enriquillo-Plantain Garden fault zone (EPGFZ). Overall, the EPGFZ accommodates about 7 mm/yr of motion, nearly half the total oblique convergence between the Caribbean and North America plates (~20 mm/yr). Haiti occupies the western part of the island of Hispaniola, one of the Greater Antilles Islands, situated between Puerto Rico and Cuba. At the location of the August 2021 earthquake, motion between the Caribbean and North America plates is partitioned between two major east-west-trending, strike slip fault systems—the Septentrional fault system in northern Haiti and the EPGFZ in southern Haiti. 
The EPGFZ had produced a series of major earthquakes in both instrumental and historical time periods. In addition to the 2010 M 7 earthquake that devastated Port-au-Prince, the EPGFZ is the likely source of historical large earthquakes in 1860, 1770, and 1751, though none of these has been confirmed in the field as associated with this fault.

551. Schisma, Boeotia. During 551, 3 separate earthquakes struck Boeotia, involving the areas around the Maliac and Crissean Gulfs in central Greece. Eight cities were destroyed, the worst hit--Patrae, Naupactus, Chaeronea and Coronea, which were destroyed, with loss of life.

Procopius's contemporary and only account of these events in 551 says that at this time a (series) earthquakes occurred throughout Greece, affecting both Boeotia and Achaea and the country around the Crisean Gulf, as a result of which many towns and 8 cities, which are not named, were leveled to the ground, among which were Chaeronea, Coronea, Patrae and all of Naupactuc where there was also great loss of life... It goes on to say that, at Echinus and at Scarphea in Boeotia in the Gulf between Thessaly and Boetia, there was a sudden inlux of the sea, which leveled both towns. The sea flooded the mainland for a long time, so that for a very considerable period it was possible for men to walk to the islands, which are inside this gulf, since the sea had abandoned its proper place and spread over the land as far as the mountains. When the sea returned to its proper place, fish were left on the ground.

It is important to recognize that Procopius places earthquakes in the plural, in the context of more than one earthquake in more than one place... he clearly refers to more than one, probably three, distinct earthquakes in central Greece, that is (1) a destructive shock in Boeotia that caused great loss of life in Schisma and destroyed Coronea and Chaeronea, probably damaging Corinth; (2) a destructive sea wave at Echinus and Scarpheia, which was probably associated with a second earthquake about 70 km away in the Maliakos Gulf between Thessaly and Boettia; and (3) a damaging shock more than 100 km to the west of Schisma in the Gulf of Corinth and in Achaea, which heavily damaged Nafpaktos and Patra.

856, December 22. 36.2 N, 54.3 E, magnitude 7.9. On Tuesday, 18 Sha'ban 242, there was a catastrophic earthquake in the eastern Alburz which devastated the district of Qumis and the region of western Khurasan dependent on Nishapur. Along a fertile tract of land running for 350 km between the Alburz and the Dasht-i Kavir, from Khuvar to beyond Bustam and in parts of Tabaristan and Gurgan, 200,000 people were killed and practically all villages were ruined. In the district of Qumis, the earthquake was worst at Damaghan, which was half destroyed with 45096 casualties. In the mountain regions there were extensive ground deformations, including probably surface faulting. The old city of Shahr-i Qumis, former capital of the province, was also destroyed and was probably finally abandoned after the earthquake. One third of Bustam collapsed and the region between this town and Damghan still showed the effects of the earthquake two generations later. Tabaristan and Gurgan were also affected by the shock, which had a disastrous effect on the water supplies of the district of Qumis, either causing the drying up of springs and qanats, or triggering landslides which dammed the streams flowing down to the plain. Outside the meizoseismal region, Nishapur to the east and the Jibal province to the west and southwest of Qumis were also strongly shaken, the earthquake being felt in Ray, Qum, and as far as Isfahan, where it caused great concern. Aftershocks continued for some years, probably causing damage in western Khurasan. (reference #1117)

From the preceding notes which cover the years 853 A.D. to 856 A.D. we may conclude that this was a period of severely damaging earthquake activity, mostly confined to well defined areas in which we may reasonably ascribe epicentral areas as at Ray and farther east another at Kumash (or Qumes) including Damaghan. To the south we identify a third epicentral region in Kashan and farther south a center in Fars province and this latter is difficult to localize within the large area of the province. Hamadan also having been much affected in this period may be considered as an epicenter or more likely was involved as an extension from events centered at Ray or Kashan. (reference #1217)

A severe earthquake caused heavy damage in Valdivia, Angol, Nueva Imperial, and damaged the surrounding areas approximately from Villarica to Osorno. The number of deaths were comparatively small (21), because the force of the tremors increased gradually and the inhabitants had time to flee from their homes. The tremors continued for a period of forty days. Sizeable cracks appeared in the ground and landslides were also recorded, a river flowing from Lake Riniue became blocked in its upper reaches. The dam lasted until April of the following year, when after prolonged rains the water level in the lake rose considerably, causing the dam to burst and resulting in much devastation farther downstream; more than 1200 Indians perished and many cattle were lost as well.

The earthquake caused a powerful tsunami in the area of Valdivia, located on a river of the same name about 25 km upstream from its mouth.
(above from Reference #415)

Reference #1206 lists epicenter 39.8S 73.2W, magnitude 8.5, intensity X.

March 13, 1577, Tengchong, Yunnan Province, 25 N, 98.6 E, magnitude 6.5, intensity VIII. More than 1,300 rooms in temples, offices, prisons, and 70% of the civilian houses collapsed. Landslides and ejection of water occurred. More than 170 people were buried. More than 20 shocks occurred on the previous day (March 12). (reference #3939)

February, 19 [14?], 1619 at 11:30 [local time]. Earthquake in northern Peru, which razed to its foundations the city of Trujillo, the destruction extending to the towns of Saña and Santa. In Trujillo some 350 people died. The movement spread about 200 km from north to south and 330 km from east to west. The ground trembled for more than fifteen days. Feijoo relates that the earthquake not only demolished buildings in the plains and in the adjacent mountains, but cracked the earth in various parts ejecting from its bosom a viscous and pestilent material consisting of muddy water which formed streams which flowed through the fields so that the waters of the river from the town of Santa, between Barranca and others, were stained with that malign inundation. (reference #1111)

February 14, 1619. Strong in Lima, but slight damage. Trujillo and Piura almost destroyed. (reference #1102)

February 14, 1619, 16:30 UTC, 8.9 S, 79.3 W, magnitude 7.7, intensity IX, depth 50 km, casualties. (reference #1208)

February 14, 1619, 16:30 UTC, 7.941 S, 79.038 W, magnitude 8.6, intensity VIII, depth 40 km. (reference #1221)

locationName: PHILIPPINES:  N LUZON:  ILOCOS PROV,ZAGAIAN PROV

comments:
1633, November 5, 37.7 N, 20.8 E, magnitude 7. Zante, >20 deaths. (reference #4408)

1633, November 5, intensity 10.5. Very disastrous earthquake in Zante. Many houses overthrown, many victims. Landslides, crevasses and tidal waves. Felt in Mantua and Verona. (reference #1093)

1633, November 5. An earthquake in Zante caused the collapse of houses. The town of Zante was damaged by three consecutive shocks as a result of which a portion of high land jutting out into the Gulf of Lagana collapsed, turning the tip of the promontory of Agios Sostis into an islet and causing the sea to swell, though no damage resulted. In other places on the island mountains were shattered and the ground opened up. This event is recorded by Girardi, who dates it to 5 November 1633 (Julian calendar). It is clear for reasons of distance that this cannot have been the same earthquake as was felt in northern Italy). A similar account(without mention of northern Italy) is given by the seventeenth-century writer Riccioli. (reference #9116)

1647, May 13. The great Santiago earthquake occurred on May 13 (Monday) at 10:30 p.m. [Local time]. Santiago contained about 300 houses at the time. The number of victims was estimated at "about a thousand", or one to every five inhabitants. All descriptions point to an epicenter within 50 miles of Santiago. The estimated magnitude is 8.5. (reference #252)

1647, 10:30 p.m., Santiago, magnitude 8.5, 1000 deaths. (reference #1170)

1647, May 13. Santiago, Chile, magnitude 8.5, 1,000 deaths. (reference #1002)

1647, May 14, 02:30 UTC. Epicenter 33.4S, 70.6W, intensity XI. (reference #1206)

2000 deaths. (reference #1051)

The great 1647 Santiago earthquake, a critical event for the assessment of hazard in the capital, remains poorly understood. Santiago had a population of around 5,000 at the time and the countryside was sparsely settled.[...]The shock was sudden and violent, without warning; the strong motion lasted "the time to say three Credos", about 90 to 100 seconds. (The Credo or profession of faith was recited in Latin for divine protection, especially in articulo mortis, i.e., in the expectation of death)[...]Reports from beyond Santiago are scant and unreliable because of the low population density. (reference #12425)

In 1647, Santiago was a village containing about 300 houses, most of which collapsed. About 20 per cent of the population was killed in the earthquake[...]the great Santiago earthquak eof 1647 should probably be assigned to the coastal or offshore subduction zone, asin the Central Chilean earthquakes of 1730, 1822, 1906, 1965, and 1971. The magnitude of the 1647 earthquake may have been similar to that of the 1730 event,estimated at 83/4 by Lomnitz (1970). (reference #12760)

July 13, 1652, Midu, Yunnan Province, 25.4 N, 100.5 E, magnitude 6.75, intensity IX.

Official buildings and civilian houses were razed. Rocks rolled down. The ground cracked with emission of stinking mud. Rivers dried up. More than 3,000 (others said 1,000) people were killed, including numerous travellers and merchants.

Menghua (Weishan): Battlements were destroyed completely. Half of the civilian houses tilted. More than 10 persons were killed. People tented outside.

Chuxiong: Battlements were destroyed. Bricks and rocks flew in all directions.

Dingbian (south of Yongjian): Outside the south and west city gates, the ground was cracked with emission of red water and black sand. Most of the temples, city walls and buildings collapsed. Numerous people were killed, the rest climbed up the hills and tented outside.

Dingyuan (Muding): The Confucian Temple was destroyed.

Fengyi: Several persons were killed.

The shock also struck Wuding.

Shocks already occurred on July l2. After that, shocks occurred several times a day or once every other day, and lasted till 1655.

Note: The Zhaozhou Prefecture Annals, compiled during the reign of Emperor Yongzheng, recorded:
"During 6th month of 1670 year in Midu, earth quaked violently with noise. The city walls collapsed, civilian houses were destroyed. Many people and domestic animals were killed."

(above from reference #3939)
1653, Asia Minor, Smyrna, 2000 to 3000 killed. (reference #1055)

July 21, 1654, Tianshui, Gansu Province, 34.3 N, 105.5 E, magnitude 8, intensity XI.

Meizoseismal region: Around Luojiabao, Qishiyu and Mumengli of Tianshui (at the junction of Tianshui, Xihe and Lixian Counties), hills collapsed, rivers were dammed into pools. Two hills went together and buried villages in a region of 5 km in length. Shocks lasted for more than one year.

Tianshui: City walls and official buildings were almost razed. More than 3,600 rooms collapsed by shaking, numerous cave dwellings and stockades. fell down. The Yuanzbu Temple at Lujiapo collapsed. More than 7,400 people were killed.

Gangu: Houses collapsed, landslide occurred, and the ground cracked. More than 3,000 people were killed.

Wushan: Villages and forts were razed. Numerous people were killed.

Liangdang: The ground fissured with emission of black water. Cave dwellings and houses collapsed. Numerous people and domestic animals were killed.

Heshui: Many houses collapsed.

Lixian, Xihe and Qing'an: City walls and battlements fell completely. Numerous people were killed or wounded.

Tongwei: Houses were tilted or collapsed. People and domestic animals were killed or injured. (Others said: "More than 90 km' of waste land and the field which were buried by shaking, as well as 5471 people who fled from earthquake or injured, were exempted from taxation.")

Fengxian: City walls fell for more than 100 m long.

Zhuanglang: Landslide occurred and river water overflowed. Many people were killed or injured.

Jingning: Houses collapsed and all battlements were destroyed. Many people and domestic animals were killed.

Chengxian: Landslide occurred and the ground cracked.

Huixian: Houses and city walls collapsed. Numerous people and domestic animals were killed.

Qingyang: City walls and houses were devastated completely.

Huining: Houses collapsed.

Dlngxi: Houses were tilted or fell. Some people were killed.

Lanzhou, Lingtao, Pingliang and Longxi: Civilian houses were destroyed. Some people were killed.

Huating: A cracked pagoda built in the Tang Dynasty (618-906) got closed by shaking. (The original record said that the pagoda was cracked by shaking and closed again by shaking after some thirty years.)

Chongxin: Cities, forts, cave dwellings and villages were destroyed. Many people were killed or injured.

Ningxian: Walls and houses fell completely, cave dwellings collapsed. Many people were killed.

Huanxian: City walls and houses collapsed.

Baoji: Houses were destroyed, people were killed.

Lueyang: The south watch tower was shaken. The city walls at the southwestern part of the city fell for more than 130 m long.

Yangxian, Chenggu, Zhengba and Ningqiang: Tiles fell down, and walls tilted or collapsed.

Xixiang: City walls collapsed.

Lingtai: Forts, stockades and cave dwellings collapsed. Many people were killed or injured. Numerous watch towers and shanties collapsed.

Hanzhong: City walls fell for more than 130 m long.

Meixian: Many houses collapsed.

Fufeng: The Jinfu Palace (outside the north city gate} fell. Walls and temples collapsed. People and domestic animals were killed.

Mianxian: Tiles fell down and walls collapsed.

Lingyou: Cave dwellings and temples collapsed. People and domestic animals were killed.

Wenxian: Walls fell by shaking. 3 persons were injured.

Xiongyi: An old pagoda formerly inclined to the east, resumed its upright position after the earthquake.

Shangxian: Many houses were destroyed.

(above from reference #3939)

locationName: PHILIPPINES:  S LUZON:  MANILA, SANTA CRUZ

comments:
July 25, 1668, Between Juxian and Tancheng, Shandong Province, 35.3 N, 118.6 E, magnitude 8.5, intensity XII.

The shock hit Shandong, Hebel, Zhejiang, Jiangsu, Henan, Shanxi, Shaanxi, Jiangxi, Fujian, Hubei and Hunan provinces. Tancheng, Juzhou and Lingyi in Shandong Province suffered most seriously.

Juxian: Official and civilian houses, schools, temples, storehouses, memorial archways and city walls collapsed completely. No house was left in the area with a diameter of more than 50km. The hill avalanched everywhere at Mashi. Half of the hills at Wulugu, Yanjiagu, Shifengdo, Keluodo and Maqi slid. Ground fissures, 0.3-1 m in width and tens to hundreds meters in length, occurred all around city and countryside. A fissure, 1m in width, 7.5 km in length (from Guangzhuang to Gehu), occurred on the cliff east of the Shuhe River, with emission of dust, sand and yellow water. Water gushed out with a height of more than one meter from 3 wells in the northeast of the city and the North Gate Street. More than 20,000 people were killed.
Tancheng: Watch tower, crenelations, storehouses, official buildings, civilian houses, villages and temples were all razed, several hundred thousand rooms collapsed in the whole county. Some ground fissures were so wide that they could not be stridden over, the bottoms of some fissures could not be seen. The ground caved into the shape of a stair. Spring water gushed to a height of about 10m. More than 8,700 people were killed.
Linyi: City walls, huildings and temples were devastated in a short while, no house remained in good condition. Landslides occurred and the ground fissured. Well water gushed out to a height of 1-2m. A pool, 15-20 m in width and 9 m in depth, occurred 0.5 km to the north of the north city gate, with black water in it. More than 6,900 registered residents and numerous families were killed.
Ganyu: City walls collapsed, official buildings and civilian houses were razed. Ground fissures, several meters in width, opened then closed again. Well water gushed into the air to a height of 6-7 m. All rivers flooded, but sea water receded for 15 km. Numerous people and domestic animals were killed.
Changyi: Numerous people were killed or injured.
Anqiu: Hundreds of people were killed.
Zhucheng: More than 2,700 registered residents were killed.
Shuyang: Numerous people were killed.
Mongyin: More than 1,000 people were killed.
Laiwu: Most of the people and domestic animals were killed.
Jiaoxian: More than 90 people were killed in the city proper and suburbs.
Feixian: Numerous people were killed. Water gushed into the air to a height of about 1 m. Hills were shaken. Roaring wave occurred.
Shouguang: Many people and domestic animals were killed.
Yidu: Many people and domestic animals were killed or injured.
Gaomi: Numerous people were killed.
Weifang: More than 470 people were killed.
Yixian: Many people were killed.
Yishui: 1,725 people were killed.
Suining: Numerous people were killed or injured.
Suqian: Caijialou was flooded.
Tongshan (Xuzhou): Numerous people around this area were killed.
Jimo: 653 people were killed.
Linqu: Numerous people were killed.
Caoxian: Numerous people and domestic animals were killed.
Huantai: Many people and domestic animals were killed.
Chengwu: Numerous people and domestic animals were killed.
Dezhou: Many people and domestic animals were killed.
Zouxian: More than 100 people were killed.
Yutai: 140 people were killed.
Wenshang: Some people were killed.
Sishui: More than one hundred people were killed.

Another shock on Dec. 21st, 1670.

(above from ref #3939)

September 2, 1679, Sanhe and Pinggu, Hebei Province, 40.0 N, 117 E, magnitude 8, intensity XI.

The earthquake-stricken area extended from Shengyang of Liaoning Province in the east, to Anyang of Henan Province in the west, covering several thousand kilometres with Sanhe and Pinggu suffering the most.

Sanhe: Few city walls and buildings remained, only fifty-five and a half rooms were left. In Liuhetun, about 15 km to the west of the county seat, the ground cracked and sank about 1 m; in Dongwnli to the northwest the southeastern side sank about 2 m; in Pangezhuang to the north the southern side sank more than 3 m. In the whole region ground fissures occurred everywhere with ejection of black water. 2,677 people were killed. Aftershocks occurred several times a month or once every other day, for 9 months up to the recording date.

Pinggu: The city walls, villages, buildings, pagodas and temples were completely razed. To the east of the county seat, mountains avalanched and sank at many places. The areas from Shuiynzhuang to Haizi and from Xinkaiyn to Panshan ofJizen in the southeast of Pinggu County avalanched and sank most seriously. A brick well was titled, in the south of Daxinzhai, 3.5 km to the northwest of the county seat. The ground fissured about 3 m with ejection of black sand and water. Only 30-40% of the people survived.

Tongxian: More than 10,000 people were killed.

Jixian: Many people and domestic animals were killed.

Wuqing: Many people were killed.

Beijing: Official buildings, civilian houses, palaces, temples and guild halls were hit with 12,793 rooms of houses ruined and 18,028 damaged. The ground cracked open for dozens of meters. Beneath Deshengmen Gate a big ditch opened with water springing out. The death toll was 485.

Zhuoxian: A great number of people died.

(above from reference #3939)

January 1688, intensity 10 or 10.5. Disastrous earthquake at Pisticcio, between Potenza and the Gulf of Tarante, 2000 victims. (reference #1093)

1688, Pisticci, intensity X, 40 deg 23 min N, 16 deg 33 min E. (reference #1075)

January 1688. Italy, Pisticci in (Basilicata) intensity II which corresponds to buildings may be unroofed or shattered and some may fall, the ground may be badly cracked in places and small landslips occur. (reference #1055)

January 1688, Province of Basilicata in the kingdom of Naples. Violent shocks for three hours. Pisticcio was rined and 200 of its inhabitants killed. (reference #1879)

June 5, 1688, intensity 11.5. Catastrophic earthquake in the region of Benevent, to the N.E of Naples. Apice, Paduli, Pontelandolfo and 6 other boroughs or villages were shaken to the ground, burying 1750 people. In Benevent: partial collapse of the city and 1561 victims. Great ruin in Naples. (reference #1093)

June 5, 1688, 13:15 UTC, intensity X, Benevento, 41 deg 10 min N, 14 deg 45 min E. (reference #1075)

June 5, 1688. Italy, Benevento (Avellino), Salerno, campolbasso (Foggie, Lecce and Basilicata). Intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

June 5 to 8, 1688. At Naples and many other places along the Apenines as far as Matese to the north, and Mirabella and Benevento to the south. Also felt at the same time at some places in Romagna, at Venice, and even at Smyrna. Many shocks. The first, which were very violent, occurred on the 5th at 21h and lasted a Miserere. They were very great at Benevento. The shocks did not entirely cease for 2 months. Chasms opened int he ground in many places. (reference #1879)

The date of April 6 is from the Julian calendar. This would be April 16 on the Gregorian calendar, which wasn't adopted in the region until later. Earthquake encompassed a large mesoseismal area (Dorel, 1981, who estimates a magnitude Ms 8+). Oldmixon (1741) says, "The earth opened 9 feet in many places on St. Kitts, and buried solid timber, sugar mills..." The earthquake resulted in the earliest record of a tsunami affecting any present U.S. territory. Olsen (1988) quotes a letter from the governor of St. Thomas in 1690 that stated, "Last Sunday, which was April 6, this island has been hit by a terrible earthquake lasting one-half of a quarter-of-an-hour, so that people feared their houses would come down. Some hours after that the sea receded so much that one could walk about 9 to 10 fathoms into the sea and pick out fishes on dry land."

1690, April 5. 17.5 N, 61.5 W, magnitude 8.0 MS. (reference #1500)

June 19, 1718, S of Tongwei, Gansu Province, 35 N, 105.2 E, magnitude 7.5, intensity X.

Tongwei: The fiat ground warped and fissured northwest of the town, yellow sand and black mud gushed out, especially so in Nanxiang Village. All government offices, the Confucian school, temples and the National Altar were destroyed, and all official and civilian houses collapsed. Only a corner of the northeastern brick city walls remained. Officials and civilians moved to Xiguan. A peak of Mt. Bijia north of the town slid, and most earth hills broke. More than 40,000 people were killed in the city and the villages.

Ganyu: The north hills moved southward burying several thousand civilian houses in Dazhenghuan Village of Yongning, most houses in Lixin (northwest of the town) and all houses in the villages northwest of the town. More than thirty thousand people were killed or injured.

Jingning: All gate towers, battlements, Sshools, official buildings and civilian houses collapsed. The front of Mt, Nanwutai broke, a landslide at Zhipingchuan (35 km south of the Prefecture) dammed the river, several thousand people were killed.

Zhuanglang: The southern part of the city wall collapsed. Anzi Hill in the southwest slid, killing more than a thousand people, and rivers were blocked up.

Qin'an: All gate towers, pavilions and battlements collapsed. Walls, halls and rooms in the Confucian Temple and a social-morals memorial arch were destroyed.

Tianshui: Houses and halls in the Confucian Temple collapsed. Hills slumped and ground fissured. People were killed or injured.

Huining: The gate towers collapsed, battlements fell down, and walls were razed to the ground.

Xihe: Altars in the Confucian Temple toppled down. Stricken families were exempted from taxes.

Longde: Many people were killed.

Minxian and Lanzhou: Some people were killed or injured.

Huxian and Zhouzhi: Some people and livestock were killed.

In addition: The shock also struck Lintao, Longxi, Pingliang, Qingyang, Yinchuan, Qingshui in Gansu Province; Chengcheng, Fengxiang, Meixian, Xixiang, Zhen, ha, Wugong, Zhen'an in Shaanxl Province; Yicheng and Jiangxian; Wanquan in Shanxi Province; Changyuan in Henan Province.

(above from reference #3939)

June 19, 1718, Kansu Province, 35 N, 105.2 E, magnitude 7.5, intensity X. (reference #1052)

1735, February 2, 18h, 2.5 N, 76.5 W, depth 20 km, magnitude 4.5 MS, fatalities. (reference #1219)

1735, February 2. Colombia, Popayan, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

1735, 2 fevrier. - Popayan, Colombie du sud. III. (reference #1908)

1735, February 2. In Popayan, a furious shaking that took place most of the houses were overthrown. (reference #1532)

1736 [probably 1735], February 2, 14h, 2.5 N, 76.5 W, magnitude 6, intensity VIII, damage. (reference #1205)

November 21-22, 1748, N of Guyuan, Ningxia Autonomous Region, 36.40 N, 106.1 E, magnitude 5.5, intensity VIII.

In and around Baizuizi and Heichengzi (town), altogether more than 130 civilian houses and cave dwellings collapsed in more than 20 villages. More than 40 people and more than 20 cows and donkeys were killed.

Guyuan: An earth city wall outside Nanguan collapsed.

The earthquake also occurred at Lingtai, Jingning, Pingliang, Jingchuan, Huanxian in Ningxia and Tongchuan of Shaanxi Province.

Note: The present Heicheng Town north of Guyuan was probably Helchengai. The site of Baizuizi was uncertain.

(above from reference #3939)

January 27, 1755, E of Yimen, Yunnan Province, 24.7 N, 102.2 E, magnitude 6.5, intensity VIII.

Yimen: City walls, government offices, pavilions. and temples were destroyed. In the city and villages, more than 2,840 rooms in tile-roofed houses. and more than 1,200 thatched cottages collapsed. At Zhongpubei 7.5 km south of the town, all walls and civilian houses collapsed. Dalongquan spring dried up for two days. More than 270 people were killed, and more than 80 injured.

Kunming: City walls, government offices, pavilions and temples were damaged.

(above from reference #3939)

November 3, 1761, Yuxi, Yunnan Province, 24.4 N, ,102.5 E, magnitude 6, intensity VII.

The brick prefecture city walls were destroyed again. In the city and villages, more than 770 rooms in tile-roofed houses and more than 190 of thatched cottages collapsed. More than 800 families suffered losses. More than 50 people were killed and more than 30 injured.

Jiangchuan: More than 20 rooms in tile-roofed houses and more than 10 of thatched cottages in Pumiao Township collapsed. More than 100 families were hit with more than 20 people killed and as many injured.

Hexi: In Baishun and other villages, 6 rooms in tileroofed houses and 3 of thatched cottages collapsed. 4 people were killed and one person injured. 9 families were affected.

Huaning: Most civilian houses collapsed. In Wachang and other villages, one room and 26 thatched cottages were destroyed. Two person were killed and another two injured.

The shock also struck Kunming and Chengjiang.

(above from reference #3939)
1766, March 8, 41 N, 141 E, Hirosaki, 1335 deaths, 7192 houses destroyed. (reference #1068)

January 8, 1780, Iran, 38.2N, 46E, magnitude 7.7. Preceded by a strong foreshock, a catastrophic earthquake on the night of Friday to Saturday 29 Dhu 'l-Hijja 1193 to I Muharram 1194 (7-8 January 1780) in the region of Tabriz almost totally destroyed the city and devastated about 400 villages, including Marand, Tasuj and Iranaq. In Tabriz itself, all major buildings, weakened by previous shocks, were ruined and all private houses, as well as the fort and walls of the city were totally destroyed, the radius of destruction being variously given as 72 or 120 km from Tabriz. Outside this distance, in Khuy, Salmas, Urmiyeh and Gunayi (?), buildings were damaged but there was no loss of life. Vast numbers of people perished in this earthquake, estimates ranging to over 200,000. The number was probably somewhere around 50,000. Among these were the son of the ruler of Tabriz, Fazl'ali Beg Dunbuli, along with some 700 retainers who were killed when the palace collapsed. The earthquake was responsible for the destruction of all the historical buildings in Tabriz. Among those which were restored afterwards and still exist today (in greatly altered form) we may note the Friday mosque in the bazaar, work on which was begun by Ahmad Khan Dunbuli immediately after the earthquake. The Sahib alAmr mosque was restored in 1208/1794 by Ja'far Khan Dunbuli in a complex immediately north of the Mihran-rud, that includes the Thiqat al-Islam mosque. Both these complexes include other buildings named as having been severely affected by the earthquake, for example the Talibiyyeh madraseh adjoining the Friday mosque, which was originally a Safavid foundation (built in 1087/1676), and the Hasan Padshah mosque and madraseh adjoining the Sahib al-Amr (originally built by Uzun Hasan (d. 882/1478). The Sadiqiyyeh madraseh, also a Safavid foundation, still survives in the bazaar area, and the shrine and madraseh of Sayyid Hamza (d. 714/1314) are in the Surkhab quarter to the north. The mosque of 'Alishah is now reduced to the ruins known as the Arg, and the Ustadc-Shagird mosque and the Dal-o-Zal mosque have also survived to the present day. (reference #1117)

January 8, 1780, 38N, 46.2E, Tabriz, Iran, 200,000 deaths, severe damage. (reference #1217)

January 17, 1780, 22:15 UTC, 38.2N, 46.2E, depth 20 km, magnitude 6.7, intensity 9, much destruction and high death toll in Tebriz and Merendi. (reference #223)

February-March 3, 1780, Persia, Tabriz, intensity II which corresponds to buildings may be unroofed or shattered and some may fall, the ground may be badly cracked in places and small landslips occur. (reference #1055)

1780, Tabriz (Tauris), Iran, 100,000 deaths, severe damage. (references #1051)

1780, at Tauris; 15,000 houses thrown down and multitudes buried. (reference #1073)

May 13, 1784, Peru, Arequipa, the districts of Camana and Moquegua, intensity III which corresponds to an earthquake which destroyed towns and devastated districts. (reference #1055)

May 13, 1784, at 07:35. Earthquake which ruined the city of Arequipa and most of its churches. It caused the death of 54 persons and 500 injuries. It threw down the arch of the bridge and damaged the pavement of the streets. Towns within a radius of 100 km were also ruined. noteworthy for the number of aftershocks which followed the main movement. (reference #1111)

May 13, 1784, 12:36 UTC, 16.5 S, 72 W, depth 70 km, magnitude 7.8, intensity X, earthquake sound heard, casualties. (reference #1208)

May 13, 17784, 07:35 [local time], 16.5 S, 72 W, VIII-IX at Arequipa, intensity VIII at Camana, Moquegua, Tambo, Vitor, intensity VII-VIII at Tiabaya, intensity III-IV at Chivay, tsunami intensity I. (reference #1211)

May 13, 1784, 12:36 UTC, 16.5 S, 72 W, depth 27 km, magnitude 8, intensity IX. (references #1218 and #1221)

May 13, 1784 Intensity approximately IX degree of Mercalli Scale, radius of affected area 1000 km. Duration of the movements was more than 4 minutes. Total destruction of all kinds of buildings including churches among them the cathedral. Many persons dead. Among 2,609 houses only 72 remained standing but in very bad condition. Followed by aftershocks that occurred almost every day until it gradually died down. (reference #1102)

May 13, 1784, a terrible shock at Arequipa. The districts of Cumana and Maquiqua were devastated. Masses of soil were transported to great distances. (reference #496)

May 15. A succession of most terrible jolts, in less than five minutes, all of downtown Arequipa, where nothing remained on foot that the convent of Récollets. A stone bridge very firmly built is also completely destroyed. Several districts, which were more arid before, currently offer sources; water so abundant, that it is in the shape of the very navigable rivers. In spite of the excessive number of the buildings fallen in ruin ... people buried under the debris do not exceed 500. The districts of Cumana and Moquegua are completely destroyed. (reference #1532)

May 13, 1784. ... total number of deaths 383.

November 7, 1789, Tongguan, Shannxi Province, 34.6 N, 110.3 E, magnitude 5, intensity VI. Civilian houses were destroyed and some persons were killed. (reference #3939)
Reference #1052 lists November 7, 1789, Shensi Province, 34.6 N, 110.3 E, magnitude 5, intensity VI.

locationName: ALGERIA:  ORAN; SPAIN:  CARTAGENA, SANTA FE
comments:
On October 8-10, 1790 earthquakes occurred on the south coast of Spain and north of Africa, especially the country about Oran and on the Spanish coast at various points between Carthagena and Malaga; and in the interior as far as Santa Fe, west of Granada and also at Malta. Simultaneous shocks occurred on the opposite coast. At Oran twenty shocks were counted during the three days, and the earth shook repeatedly up to the 25th. At Malta but one slight shock was felt.

At Carthagena the sea was so much agitated that the persons employed on the wharfs were obliged to fly. At Oran great damage was done to the fortifications and city, and some lives were lost. At Santa Fe in Spain considerable destruction of property likewise ensued, several houses being thrown down.

(above from reference #496)

October 8, 1790 earthquake caused severe damage on the south coast of Spain and Northern Africa, at Oran, Carthagena, Malaga, Santa Fe and Malta. (reference #1055)

October 9, 1790, 01:15 UTC earthquake at Oran, Algeria, intensity 10. (Reference #1193)

September 9, 1790 [probably same earthquake described above], Oran, 3000 deaths. (reference #1051)

October 9, 1790, 35 deg 7 min N, 0 deg 7 min W, intensity X at Oran, 3,000 victims. (reference #1201)

October 9, 1790, Partial destruction of Oran, 766 deaths. (reference #1180)

Both the main shock and the aftershocks of the 9 October 1790 earthquake were felt in Morocco. Several documents confirm that the coast of Spain Almeria up to Carthage had suffered the impact of this quake (Marinas, op. cit., P.2, in El Mrabet, 2005) (reference #8635)

August 9, 1792, Jiayi, Taiwan Province, 23.6 N, 120.5 E, magnitude 6.75, intensity IX.

Some governmental and military offices, storehouses, arsenals and military camps were destroyed. 80% of the civilian houses around the north, east and west gates and 40% around the south gate were destroyed. Altogether more than 14,400 rooms in tile-roofed houses, 438 thatched cottages and 131 military camps collapsed. 252 people were killed and 432 injured. The villages near mountains suffered more seriously than those along the coast.

Water surged up tens of meters in Luermen. The ground sank in a room in Damaobeipu. The field warped forming a pool. In Meizikeng Hill, the ground fractured with one person falling in, and then closed again.

Zhanghua: 60% of the governmental and military offices, military camps and civilian houses collapsed. In the town and countrysides, 9,700 rooms in tile roofed houses, 507 thatched cottages and 178 rooms in military camps collapsed altogether. 358 people were killed and 349 injured.
Tainan: 54 rooms of civilian houses collapsed. A pavilion in Xinjle of Xixuanfang was destroyed. Some walls in the city and at Anping were damaged. 3 persons were killed or injured.
Gaoxiong: All the houses in the city and countrysides remained undamaged, except for 3 rooms in military camps and 2 shops in Agongdian. 8 thatched cottages in Aligang township collapsed, killing one person.
Penghu: Civilian houses collapsed killing some persons.
The earthquake also struck Danshui.

On March 30, 1796 at 6:45 a.m. [local time] the first Copiapo earthquake occurred. (Possibly there were two earlier undocumented destructive earthquakes between 1774-1796.) The earthquake destroyed Vallenar, Copiapo, Huasco and Coquimbo, and caused serious damage in La Serena. No tsunami has been reported. Comparison with the 1922 earthquake indicates that this event was smaller, perhaps in the magnitude range of 7.5 to 8. (reference #252)

30 March 1796. Magnitude 7.5. This earthquake destroyed Vallenar, Copiapo, Huasco, and Coquimbo. Damage in La Serena. The earthquake was slightly smaller than in 1922. There was a severe aftershock on 24 August 1796. Apparently there had been two earlier damaging earthquakes sometime in the period 1774-1796.

[Also see Chilean earthquakes on August 24, 1798; April 3, 1819; April 4, 1819; April 12, 1819.]

Most city walls, houses, gate towers and a school in Binchuan County collapsed. Lingxing archway collapsed. More than 200 people were killed.

Dayao: City walls were destroyed.

Yanfeng: Most of the city walls toppled down.

Yao'an: A bridge out of the east city gate fell down.

The earthquake also struck Nanhua, Mouding, Xinping, Eryuan, Dengchuan, Chuxiong, Kunming and Fengqing.

Fissures 10-30 km in length, 2.5-3 km in width and 33-67 meters in depth appeared everywhere on Hujirtai in Guzuoteha. Hills rose from the flat ground, with porous surface soil. Countless persons and domestic animals were killed on the north bank of the Konggesi River.

Note: Hujirtai was located south of the Kax Rivers or east of the present-day Suiding, The Konggesi River was to the southeast of Suiding.

Great damage was done at Algiers, and the town of Blida, eight miles to the S.W., was almost entirely ruined, 7000 (or according to others, 15,000) persons losing their lives. Near Blida also two hills are said to have been thrown together, and a village buried between them. (reference #497)

"A strong earthquake at Martinique (MMI IX] left Fort Royal (Fort-de-France) in ruins, sending up vast clouds of dust, and leaving 1 m of debris in the streets and 400 dead. At Castries, St. Luckia (MMI VIII] most buildings collapsed. Ships on the high sea at distance of 112 km felt the shock. The shock was felt at Barbadoes [MMI VII], Guadeloupe, St. Kitts, Surinam at 6:15 am, and Guyana." (Information as reported by O'Loughlin and Lander, 2003.)

locationName: TURKEY:  MT ARARAT, AGURI, ARALIKH; IRAN:  MAKU
comments:
1840 July 2 Maku-Ararat, 39.5 N, 43.5 E, magnitude 7.4. Late in the afternoon of 20 June (Old Style)/2 July 1840, a catastrophic earthquake hit the isolated region between the upper Euphrates and Mount Ararat, affecting a large area in Russia, Turkey and Iran. The main concentration of damage was in the districts of Avajik, Pambukh and Gailatu, where almost all villages were destroyed with great loss of life. In Dogubayazit all houses, including the castle, were ruined with the exception of the mosque. Kazl-gol and Masun were also destroyed. In the region of the upper Euphrates many settlements were severely damaged, and in Bazargan and Maku few houses survived intact.

Further away in Kagizman, Kulp and Igdir, as well as in the plain of the Araxes, from the district of Sharur to Nakhichevan and Urdubad, the shock was less severe but it did cause widespread damage to those villages situated in the low-lying parts of the plain. Here, the ground is marshy and as a result of the earthquake numerous areas to the west of the Araxes between the Qareh-su and the Arpa-chai rivers were intensely fractured. Liquefied sand was ejected from fissures in the ground and on all spots where the banks of the Araxes and Qareh-su are high. Landslides and slumping of the ground added to the damage. Landslides triggered by aftershocks overwhelmed the village of Qareh Khajilu and elsewhere the flow of the Araxes was temporarily dammed, the river over-topping its banks and flooding the surroundings. In the low-lying parts of the Sharur and Nakhichevan districts in Russian territory, the earthquake and its aftershocks ruined 7821 houses, 24 churches and mosques, 107 water mills and killed 49 people, injuring about 30.

The earthquake triggered a colossal slide from above the snow-line of the northeastern side of Mount Ararat. A mass of shattered rock, ice and snow moved down the mountain so fast that a violent air blast was sent out in front of it. Before it was arrested by a natural darn about 900 m above the valley floor, the slide overwhelmed Arguri, the only village in Ararat, killing all its inhabitants (about 1000 in all) and destroying the small monastery of St James (St Jacob), 3 km above, burying all the monks and destroying also the holy well of St James. At nine in the morning of 24 June (Old Style)/6 July, the natural dam burst and within minutes the slide debris spread out into the plain below in a 12 km-wide front, destroying, Aralik and three other villages 20 km away. It blocked the Qareh-su river which was forced to change its course.

Rockfalls and slides were reported from other parts of the meizoseismal region, notably from Pambukh and Chingal, where they killed people and herds of sheep. As a result of the earthquake, the flow in many of the streams and springs in the upper Euphrates and in the Sharur district increased, while in the region of Nakhichevan many springs dried up for some time.

The earthquake caused minor damage at Edjmiadsin, Erivan and Gar'ni and it was strongly felt in Alexandropol (Leninakan), Tiflis, in the Karabagh, at Shusha, in Tabriz and in Van. The shock was also felt at Linkuran, in the Talish district on the coast of the Caspian, as well as on the eastern shores of the Black Sea. Aftershocks continued for some time, causing additional damage, particularly in the plain of the Araxes and around Maku and Kazl-gcl. They did not stop until early in 1841.

(above from referrence #1117)

1840 June 20 - July 28 (old style) 6h45m P.N. at Tiflis, at 7h10m (P.R.?) at Erivan at 7h30m. The whole district of mount Ararat in Armenia. A series of violent earthquakes. (reference #1217)

July 2, 1840, 16:00 UTC, 39.7 N, 44.4 E, magnitude 6.7, intensity VIII-IX, 1000 people killed. (reference #3437)

1849, November (December, mistakenly June) 17 or 18, 16:10. At Coquimbo and La Serena there was a brief "terrible" rumble followed by an extremely strong earthquake lasting 85 seconds. There was no damage. The earthquake was also felt at Santiago (rather strongly) and Valparaiso. From 8:00 to 21:00 [local time], another 19 subterranean shocks were registered. The earthquake generated a tsunami.
Reference #252
1849, November 17 at 6 a.m. Poorly documented Central Chilean earthquake. From the few available descriptions the epicenter may have been offshore NW of Coquimbo. A tsunami 10 minutes after the earthquake caused damage in Coquimbo; the sea reportedly rose 16 feet above the high-water mark. In Santiago the intensity was about 6 on the Modified Mercalli Scale. The estimated magnitude of this earthquake is 7.5.
Reference #1055
1849, December 17. Chile, Coquimbo, Santiago and Valparaiso; sea waves. Intensity I which corresponds to an earthquake of intensity sufficient to crack walls, break chimneys, to shatter old buildings or to produce cracks in the ground.
Reference #1206

1849, December 17, 10:00 UTC. 29.95 S, 71.37 W, magnitude 7.5 Ms, intensity VIII, casualties.

Reference #3843
1849, November 28. Great quake in La Serena and tsunami in Coquimbo. Letter from the Mayor of La Serena, Mr. Juan Melgarejo, to the Minister of the Interior. In La Serena, strong and prolonged tremor. It destroyed the copper smelter of Mr. Carlos Lambert and a channel that was running for this establishment. The tsunami began from the mouth of the river, and grew to the port until it was 18 feet high. There were no victims. From 8 to 21, there were 19 tremors. It was strong in the department of Coquimbo, but almost did not feel in the one of Elqui. Report of don Juan Caballero, subdelegado maritime of Coquimbo, to the Intendant. On the 18th, at VI. A.M. tremor. Half an hour later, the sea set in motion; refluxing at some distance, with eddies. Two ships threatened to lie down. The sea returned with violent rapidity, taking two wooden piers from the Lambert smelter, and flooding the 8 furnaces, of which 5 burst with great noise. Two customs buildings and a part of the Lambert house were destroyed. The sea damaged the fiscal pier and the water took part of the dock of don Joaquin Edwards. The population was flooded three blocks beyond the point reached by the highest tides.
(El Araucano, n. 1024. Santiago. Nov 29, 1849. Communicado por don Nicanor Molinare).

Having produced the tsunami half an hour after the earthquake, the focus has had to be in the sea.
(El Araucano, n. 1169. Dec 7, 1850. Communicado por don Nicanor Molinare).

Semi-earthquake of Santiago. Santiago. Violent jolt. It lasted more than 1 min. Of two violent jolts, of 6 sec and of 10 to 12 sec respectively. Vibratory. Some shingles have fallen, the stucco has been broken from one exterior to another, and small fractures have been broken in some walls of private houses. Public buildings also suffered from detriment. In the Cathedral, in the flat arc of one of the windows that give the Secretary, the two stones of the middle of said arch, yielded some lines to the weight they hold. From the Prison and the old Government House, almost all the knobs that served as decoration to the upper part of the building were detached, and one of them caused the death of a boy from twelve to thirteen years old. An hour and a half later he trembled feebly again.

1854, Dec 23 [Nov 4, 9 am, Ansei 1 (Japanese calendar)]. 34 N, 137.9 E, magnitude 8.3, tsunami magnitude 3, validity 4.

Reference #414:

There was a very strong earthquake in the Tokai area. It was felt over a large area, including the prefectures of Tochigi, Kanagawa, Yamanashi, Shizouka, Nagano, Aichi, Gifu, Mie, Shiga, Fukui and Nara. The zone of greatest destruction had a length of 260 km and a width of 120 km. The zone where the earthquake was especially strong and where the majority of majority of cities and villages were destroyed, represented a strip 120 km long, extending from the northwestern tip of the Izu Peninsula over the coast of Suruga Gulf to the mouth of the Tenryu River (Shizuoka with an area of 1800 km2. Many regions suffered from fires which broke out. An intensification in the discharge of some springs was observed before the earthquake.

The earthquake of December 23 was evidently weaker than the earthquake of December 24. The length of the zone of maximal intensity of the earthquake of December 23 was half as much, while the total area affected by the earthquake was 3.5 times smaller than the earthquake of December 24. The damage and destruction of structures during the latter was greater; the total number of destroyed homes on December 24 was three times greater and the number of victims 5 times greater than on December 23. The epicenters of the earthquakes, judging by macroseismic data, were 380 km from each other.

Lists the epicenter as 34.1 N, 137.8 E. 300 people died in the earthquake and about the same number died in the tsunami. Total fatalities for the Dec 23 and 24, 1854 events: 3,000 and total houses destroyed: 60,000.

1855, Nov 11, 22:00 local time, 35.8 N, 139.8 E, magnitude 6.9. There was a strong earthquake in the vicinity of Tokyo. It destroyed many homes and 54 or 57 temples and killed 3,000 people in the eastern half of Saitama Prefecture, the northeastern part of Kanagawa Prefecture, the central and western parts of Chiba Prefecture and in several places in the southwestern part of Ibaraki Prefecture. The ground opened up at many places and swallowed whole quarters. There was a damaging earthquake, preceded by foreshocks, in the Gulf of Keramos (Kerme) and the Mentese district in Asia Minor. The earthquake took place at 19h 55m and almost totally destroyed Ula, with loss of three lives. The town was split in the middle by a ground fracture, which extended westwards to the sea. Mugla was also heavily damaged and almost half of it destroyed. Damage extended to Marmaris, where cracks opened in the ground and most houses were ruined. (reference #9116)

1880, Aug 15, 8:48 [local time]. 31 S, 71.5 W, mag 7. A strong earthquake occurred with source north of Santiago.

At Illapel, a loud rumbling was heard from the north. It rapidly intensified for 10 sec, after which what seemed like an explosion was heard and the ground shook violently for a minute. Two of these shocks were especially strong. All the public buildings, homes, blast furnaces and stone quarries were almost completely destroyed. 600 families were left homeless with no means of subsistence. Since it was a holiday, all the people were in the streets, as a result of which there were only two casualties. Ground waves were observed. The regime of subterranean waters and springs changed (VIII degrees, on the M. scale). Aftershocks continued at least until the first days of Oct.

Several walls collapsed at Ovalle; a number of buildings were severely damaged (VIII). Extensive physical damage was done at Salamanca (VIII). At Petorca there were strong tremors lasting 1 min, preceded by a loud rumble. Public buildings were heavily damaged. The majority of homes were rendered unfit for habitation, and some of them collapsed completely.

There was slight damage at San Felipe. A cathedral was destroyed at Quillota. One church tower collapsed, and another sank to one side at Vina del Mar. The roof of one home collapsed at Limache. At Valparaiso, cornices collapsed and walls cracked here and there. At Santiago, there were strong prolonged tremors, causing slight damage: cornices collapsed here and there, walls cracked, statues tumbled. The bells rang at Rancagua. There were strong tremors at Talca. Several dilapidated walls crumbled at Concepcion, and underground rumbling was heard from the north.

The earthquake was stronger at La Serena than at Los Vilos; one or two ranch houses sank to one side. There were strong, prolonged tremors at Copiapo. The earthquake was noted at Mendosa, La Rioja and San Juan.

There were strong tremors at Coquimbo. Large columns of water arose at sea, as a result of which the anchor chain snapped in one ship. The underwater cable across the mouth of the Limari River was broken at a depth of 1.8 km.

(above from ref #415)

1880, August 15, at 8:48 a.m. lllapel earthquake. Two persons were killed and many buildings destroyed in Illapel; Petorca was also seriously damaged... All railroad stations of the Santiago-Valparaiso line reported damage. The submarine cable was broken at a depth of 1800 meters off the estuary of the Limari River. Several landslides occurred in the Illapel-Petorca area. The epicenter of this earthquake could have been offshore; the epicentral area (VII) is more than one degree long. There are no reports from the sparsely settled coast except for Los Vilos, a locality on firm ground which shows consistently low intensities. The argument of Montessus de Ballore for an inland epicenter is not conclusive. The cable break near the mouth of the Limari River could indicate in epicenter in this vicinity. The magnitude was probably 7.5 to 8. (ref #252)

1880, Aug 15. Chile, Aconcagua, Illapel, Valparaiso, Quillola and to Coquimbo, intensity I which corresponds to an earthquake of intensity sufficient to crack walls, break chimneys, to shatter old buildings or to produce cracks in the ground. (ref #1055)

1885-A series of shocks began in the Vale of Cashmere on May 13, and continued at irregular intervals until the middle of August. The city of Serinagur and numerous villages were almost completely destroyed, thousands of lives were lost, and great destitution resulted from the killing of cattle and destruction of crops. May 30, 1885. There was another very severe shock on 30 May 1885 felt over an area of 11,000 sq. miles; the epicentre being a few miles west of Srinagar. About 3000 lives were lost. (reference #1095)

May 30, 1885. 34.54 N, 74.68 E. The magnitude of the earthquake has been estimated from these intensity data as 6.3 < Mw < 6.6, a relatively modest earthquake for its considerable damage. (reference #12927)

Among the great earthquakes of the world, the Assam earthquake [June 12, 1897] holds, and must always hold, a very prominent place. Though it occurred in an unstable region, in one of the most unstable provinces of India, no earlier Assam earthquake has possessed a disturbed area of more than a few hundred thousand sq. miles.

The earthquake occurred at about 5.15 pm., local time, and, as most persons were then out of doors, the death-roll for so great an earthquake was comparatively small. The total number of persons killed was only 1,542, about 600 of these by landslips at and near Cherrapunji, 117 at Cheyla, and 17 in the coal-mines of Cherrapunji.

The damage to property must have been very great, for, within an area of 30,000 sq. miles, all brick and stone buildings were practically destroyed, and in this area were to be found all the principal towns of the province-shillong, Sylhet, Gauhati, Goalpara, Dhubri and Turaf.

A great part of the area in which the earthquake was felt is a wild thinly populated country. Brick and stone buildings are rare and widely scattered. Thus, a detailed scale, such as the Rossi-Fore1 scale, was useless, and the following simple scale was devised by Mr. Oldham for the purpose:

  • The destruction of brick and stone buildings was practically universal.
  • The damage to masonry or brick buildings was universal, often serious, amounting in some cases to destruction.
  • All or nearly all brick buildings were damaged.
  • The earthquake was universally felt, severely enough to disturb furniture and loose objects, but not to cause damage, except in a few instances, to brick buildings. The shock was strong enough to be generally noticed, but not to cause any damage. The earthquake was only noticed by a small proportion of people who were sitting or lying down or were otherwise favorably placed for observing it.

Roughly, these degrees may be taken to correspond with the following degrees of the Rossi-Forel scale: 1O, 9, 8, 7-6, 5-4 and 3-2.

The number of after-shocks was very great, and they originated in many different centres scattered over a very wide area.
