Meizoseismal area: This area covered Karajul, Ahu, Songtake, Artux, Small Artux and Tijiankule, All earth-timber structure houses collapsed. About 500 people and a large number of domestic animals were killed or injured. Tents were distorted under shaking. The dome of Mazha Tomb in Songtake half collapsed. Artux Hill was offset 20 m in the body, loosening huge rocks that slid down the hillside. River banks slumped, damming roads and streams. Groups of ground fissures in form of belt or net occurred in flood and marshy land. The largest fissure reached 1 km in length, several meters in width and about 3 m in depth. There were people, domestic animals and trees falling into fissures. In Ahu, Songtake and Tijiankule ejection of water and sand occurred at many places. New earthquake springs are still flowing out. O.5-l m wide, 100 m-long ground fissures occurred in and around Wuqia, Kashi, Shule and Jiashi. Many old springs dried up, at the same time new ones emerged. Trees swayed so violently that their tips touched the ground. Some were even broken or uprooted. About one half of the houses collapsed. Many persons and domestic animals were killed or injured.

Fissures occurred at the north gate and its vicinity of Kashi City. Some walls at the north city gate and a tower (upper part) in a mosque collapsed. Historic sites such as Xiangfei Tomb partly collapsed or cracked. A number of civilian houses toppled. About 50 persons were killed or injured.

1 m wide ground fissures occurred in and around Kansu, Yengisar and from Bachu to Akqi. Huge rocks fell in mountain areas. About a quarter of civilian houses collapsed. The city walls of Yengisar collapsed for 1.5 m long.

Rocks fell in the mountains at Taxkorgan and Baicheng, Livestock sheds collapsed.

Reference #414:

1906, Sept 14, 16:04.3 UTC [Sept 14 01:30 local time]. 7 S, 149 E, magnitude 8.1. There was an earthquake near the Huon Peninsula. It was registered over the globe. It began with light oscillations, which rapidly intensified and lasted a minute. The main earthquake was followed by weaker shocks, occurring at intervals of a few minutes. It was especially strong in the coastal mountains from Cape Hardenberghuk in the north to the Lugaueng Mountains in the south and for 20 km inland, and also on the W coast of New Britain. Here, frequent yawning cracks opened up everywhere in the ground; numerous and extensive slumps, landslides and rock falls occurred, which changed the appearance of the locale from [Cape?] Festunghuk to [Mount?] Sattelberg, and especially in the valley of the Bussim River. Several (from 10 -20 to 100) local inhabitants were buried. Their custom of settling on the steep slopes as being the safest places in the frequent sudden attacks by their enemies, contributed to the fatalities.

All channels were buried under piles of earth for weeks. Torrential rains washed them out, and an enormous amount of forest was carried out to sea. The force of tremors was 9 degrees at Wareo, all the structures here suffered serious destruction, and a just completed home was ripped from its piles and shifted 90 cm; all the stoves were destroyed, and reservoirs filled with water were torn from their foundations and flattened. The tremors had a force of 10 degrees at Sattelberg and Lugaueng. At Sattelberg, a very old home with weak foundations was torn from its piles and displaced 2 m, and the church sank so much to one side that it had to be pulled down. At Lugaueng, trees were broken. The oscillations were only a little weaker in the region of Finschhafen bay. On Madang Island, two old dilapidated homes were ripped from rotten piles and displaced 1-2 m. At Pola, objects fell to the ground in the homes, palm trees were bent to the ground, and people were unable to move. Similar effects - collapse of stoves, the tilting of homes, the falling of cupboards and shelves - were reported from all coastal points.

The pleistoseismic zone of the earthquake extended from Cape King William to Cape Cretin; on land, its boundary passed between Sattelberg and Nanson Mountain. Changes in relief occurred on the W coast of New Britain; a landslide was seen on the slopes of Mount Hunstein which destroyed the underlying village.

At Bulesoma, Deinzerhoe and on Cape Arcona, the force of tremors was 5 degrees. A landslide was reported at the mouth of the Markham River between Cape Arcona and Huon Gulf (the Preusen Reede). On Tami Island, the tremors had a force of about 4 degrees, while they were weaker on the Siassi Islands and Umboi Island. At the same time, the earthquake was strong in Astrolabe Bay and was noticed at Potsdamhafen.

Tidal waves were observed along the entire coast from Heldsbuch on the north to Busega in Huon Gulf, and also on the islands of Tami, Siassi and Umboi.

Hall (1907) reports a witness who recalled that the "great earthquake" of Kingston "came without any warning, and in the space of 20 seconds, Kingston Town was shaken into a mass of shapeless ruins." Hall placed the epicenter 5 km south of the Palisadoes, between Plumb Point Lighthouse and Harbour Head; and the second focus lay between Buff Bay and Enfield, formed below the geological fault in the St. George district. The only seismograph was broken by the earthquake. The seismometer, when restored to operation, recorded aftershock traces revealing the two foci. The first bearing cut through Harbor Head, and the second cut the north shore between Annotto and Buff Bays.

About 1,000 and injured another 1,000, many of whom later died; 90,000 were left homeless. The earthquake damaged much of the surrounding area, including a suspension bridge at Port Maria. Buff Bay was destroyed. Tsunami effects were recorded.

Reference #2130:

1908, 12/28. Earthquake and tsunami in Messina. Focus was located in the Strait of Messina; mag 7. Geodetic measurements pre and post-quake showed graben - like subsidence of the Strait of Messina. Earthquake damaged 2 of 7 telephone cables that connected Italy and Sicily along the Strait of Messina. Calabrian coast suffered rockfalls and landslides.

Preceding shocks in 1905 and 1907 caused little destruction. The 12/28 quake destroyed Messina in Sicily with a population of 150,000, Reggio di Calabria and most settlements along both coasts. Over 80,000 people, including almost 60,000 from Messina, were killed ; the buildings were constructed of stone with poor mortar.

Reference #5096:

Messina and Reggio Calabria, < 10 km apart on the two facing shores of the straits, were destroyed, and buildings were severely damaged over an area > 6,000 sq km. Of the population, 140,000 of Messina and 45,000 of Reggio Calabria, many died. Estimates of total victims range from 60,000 to more than 100,000. Guidoboni et al. contend that 80,000 people were killed by the quake, including 2,000 who died from tsunami.

Reference #10994:

The tsunami generated by coseismic displacement during the 1908 Messina earthquake has been simulated with an E-dipping fault plane source with parameters described by Capuano et al. that best account for the geodetic benchmarks. The simulated earthquake-generated tsunami does not account for the measured runup and arrival times. Billi et al. proposed that the source of the 1908 tsunami was a large (c.a. 20 km3) landslide with a crown area offshore Giardini. We propose that the 1908 tsunami was generated by a composite source: coseismic seafloor displacement and landslides of a few cubic km (1-5 km3) suddenly triggered by the earthquake.

On June 4, 1909 at 1:41 [local time, June 3, 1909 18 40.8 UTC] there was a strong earthquake with source in the vicinity of Kerintji, off the western coast of Sumatra Island. The lighthouse at Pulu Pandiang buzzed, the tower clock rang out, and oil spilled out of the reservoir. At Banko, this was the strongest earthquake in living memory. At Ipu, the tremors lasted a minute. Strong shocks were registered at Padangpandjang; at Bua, where the wooden barracks creaked people were rocked and a lamp on a cord 1.5 m long oscillated with the same amplitude; and at Taluk where homes and trees swayed, and boats in the river felt a strong shaking. Rather strong shocks, accompanied by a roar, were felt at Djambi and Bajunglentjir, where shutters rattled strongly, lamps swayed and furniture vibrated, and at Rengat and Talu. The earthquake was felt at Pajakumbuh, Pakanbaru, Djebus, Tandjungpinang and Palembang. At Singapore, some sleepers were awakened by strong unpleasant vibrations and the creaking of furniture, doors and windows; here and there, residents rushed to the sreets in panic and some heard a rumble. A number of considerable aftershocks were felt. A tidal wave, which may have done damage, occurred near the focal zone (at Tandjung, Pau, Muti and other places). Large movements of the water were observed at Kambang.

A destructive earthquake at night on April 18, 1911, 18;14 UTC, 31.23 N, 57.03 E, magnitude 6.7, in the dihistan of Ravar, preceded by a strong foreshock, killed about 700 people. The small villages of Abdirjan, Maki and Deh Lakarkuh in the sparsely populated area east of Ravar were totally destroyed with many casualties. Almost all the houses in Ravar and its adjoining settlements were ruined. In the town itself, which had a population of 6000 at the time of the earthquake, several of the carpet-weaving factories and the masjid-i ami' collapsed, killing fifty people. Ravar remained in ruins for a long time, its public buildings only being rebuilt thirty years later.

The main shock and its aftershocks triggered many rockfalls from the northeast face of Lakarkuh, and it is very probable that the shock was associated with faulting west of Abdirjan, extending for a few kilometres in a south-southeasterly direction. However, when parts of this region were visited some years ago there was no discernible evidence of very recent faulting, except that the alignment pointed out to us as having been activated in 1911 happens to belong to a thrust zone bearing 160o E.

Minor damage extended to a number of villages, and the shock was strongly felt in Kirman, Deh Zu'iyeh and Kuhbanan. It was also felt in Birjand, Nasratabad and Duzdab. Aftershocks continued for the next three months, many of them being felt as far as Kinnan. They persisted with long intermissions for some years.

1912, August 9, 03h30m. Zone of the Sea of Marmara. A catastrophic earthquake occurred with its centre at the base of the Gallipoli Peninsula. According to field observations and to interpreted satellite photographs, a right-hand shear fault took place over 3 m in size along the diagonal fault extending from the apex of the Gulf of Saros at an azimuth of 65" through the base of the Gallipoli Peninsula towards the point of Gazikoy (Ganos - ref) on the coast of the Sea of Marmara and farther, apparently, continuing on the sea -bottom. The length of the ground part of the fault is 50 km. Certain vertical movements also took place: the south-eastern block with the mountain ridge of Tekirdag rose a little, the north-western block sank. A complex system of ruptures was formed at the earth's surface in the zone of the fault the width of which amounted to 5 km. Numerous rockfalls, screes, collapses, changes in the conditions of ground and underground water, cracking of the earth, the dilution of coastal marine and lacustrine sediments. Mud with oil was thrown out of some fissures, bitumen was extruded and so on. The earthquake lasted 40 s within the focal zone, and over 1 min far away fiom it. 2,800 inhabitants were killed, 7,000 inhabitants were wounded, 12,600 houses were destroyed completely in more than 300 settlements, and 12,100 houses were damaged beyond repair; a further 15,400 houses were seriously damaged. 241 mosques and 72 churches were also destroyed. The cities of Istanbul, Edirne, Adapazari, Bursa, Edremit and others suffered. Minarets, mosques, orphanages, hospitals, government buildings were damaged in Istanbul; all the chimneys and part of the city walls collapsed. The effects of the earthquake in Edime were similar. The buildings with long periods of natural oscillations were the most vulnerable far away from the earthquake focus. The constructions more accurately projected and built suffered little even within the focal zone. This earthquake was the strongest in Europe (M = 7.4) at the beginning of the 20th century and was accompanied by numerous aftershocks (the strongest shock was of M = 6.6 a month later).

After the earthquake, the sea receded a certain distance from the shore along the coast of the Sea of Marmara near Tekirdug and in the straits, and then it came back with force, but did no damage. The waves were especially powerful in the southern part of the Sea of Marmara.

(above from reference #2130)

The movement, of a few seconds duration, knocked all the buildings out of line and caused slides on the sides of the valley, claiming several victims. All the villages of the Mejes Valley were affected, particularly Chuquimbamba (2921 m a.s.l.) where besides throwing down the Matriz church, it damaged houses. The vibrations caused cracking of the church of the village of Calloma (4354 m a.s.l.), in the peaks of the Cordillera Occidental. In the coastal zone the villages of Ocona and Atico suffered. In the city of Arequipa several buildings were slightly damaged. On the basis of the destructive effects of the shock, Umlauf (1913) estimated an epicentral area of 30,000 km2, bounded by the Intensity X MM isoseist, while he limited the intensity VII to an elliptical area of 58,000 km2. The movement was felt as far as Iquique (Chile) and La Paz (Bolivia). The observatories at Lima and La Paz, at average distances of 550 and 620 km, reported an approximate epicentral zone situated in the ocean, off the coast. There was an earthquake with source, according to the Wiechert seismograph at Djakarta (Batavia), southeast of Bali Island. On Bali Island, there were very strong regular horizontal oscillations, here and there accompanied by vertical shocks, which lasted 50 minutes [seconds?]. The force of tremors depended very much on ground conditions, but on the whole decreased markedly from the south coast of the island to the north coast. Bamboo huts on loose grounds on the south of the island collapsed; stone houses cracked and partly collapsed. A magnitude 7.1 Mw (Ref #10476) earthquake, at 10:14 Local Time in the Mona Passage, west of Puerto Rico, was caused by displacement along four segments of a normal fault, oriented N-S in the Mona Canyon (Ref #267). Ref #1914 and 9910 list 7.3 Mw (MMI VIII). The map in Ref #1078 lists a MMI intensity IX at Punta Borinquen, closest dry land to the epicenter. Immediately following the shock a tsunami broke upon the shore, drowning many persons and destroying many native dwellings.

Earthquake Damage (from Reference #1128):

Most extensive property damage reports were received from Aguada and Anasco, both located on alluvium in western Puerto Rico. In Aguada, masonry buildings were largely demolished. Some walls, badly cracked by the main shock were thrown down by the aftershock of October 24. The church, built prior to 1867, was entirely destroyed. Some concrete walls and foundations without reinforcement were wrecked. A one-story reinforced concrete school was practically undamaged, and frame buildings were not damaged appreciably.

At Anasco, all brick buildings were destroyed or condemned. Several concrete structures with very little reinforcmenet were generally wrecked during aftershocks, but those which were well reinforced sustained little damage. Wood frame buildings were not damaged except where timbers had rotted.

At Aguadilla, most of the buildings on alluvium were badly damaged or destroyed. As a rule, masonry structures were badly cracked.

At Mayaguez, south of Anasco, the brick Catholic Church had to be razed, but the brick Presbyterian Church was only slightly damaged. Several persons were killed in the collapse of a two-story, poorly built, concrete cigar factory.

Many bridges were damaged; railroad tracks were bent and displaced; pipelines and flumes were wrecked; and tall brick chimneys were thrown down. Two cable links were broken in Mona Pasage.

Tsunami Damage (from Reference #1182):

Before the tsunami arrived, the ocean withdrew and exposed reefs and stretches of seafloor never visible during low tide. A tsunami with runup heights reaching 6 m followed the earthquake, causing extensive damage along the western and northern coasts of Puerto Rico, especially to those villages established in a flood plain.

Deaths and Total Damage:

The official death toll attributed to both earthquake and tsunami was 116 persons according to Reference #1078. Reference #1492 said, "Since more than 100 perished at Mayaguez, plus 4 at Ponce, plus 40 tsunami deaths at northwestern Puerto Rico, the tally would have been more than 116. The greatest number of fatalities was said to be due to the tsunami." Reference #1591 reported 91 killed by the tsunami in northwestern Puerto Rico.

References #1128 and #1492 list $4 million damage in Puerto Rico; Reference #1250 lists $29 million damage.

In Mayaguez most stone buildings either fell or were very badly damaged. Many streets were made impassable with debris. The Science building of the Agricultural College was destroyed by fire. More than one hundred deaths occurred in Mayaguez. In Ponce many buildings were seriously damaged, including the theatre and the Cathedral. Four were killed. Most of the towns of the island reported some damage to buildings. A tidal wave following the earthquake caused thirty deaths in Aguadilla. Damage to property in Puerto Rico exceeded $4,000,000 (ref #364)

August 14, 1921, Ethiopia. An earthquake with an epicenter offshore from Massawa, followed by an aftershock of almost equal magnitude, caused considerable damage to the harbour and to the town, where a small number of people were killed. At Ras Murdur houses became uninhabitable. The shock was strongly felt as far as Asmara and Decamere. A large number of dead fish were found floating between Jizan and al-Hudaida. (reference #3845)

1921. During the whole year of 1921, earth tremors originating in the Massawa Channel jolted the Province of Eritrea. The shocks were particularly severe on 14 August and 21 September when two shocks reached magnitude class "d," that is, between 5.3 and 5.9. Reports of tremors came from all over the province. Massawa was the site that suffered most; it was so badly damaged that all buildings still standing were ordered to be demolished as a security measure. Eritreans remember 1921 in their folklore as Zemene delekeleke, the era of the earthquakes. Gutenberg and Richter (1954) placed the epicentre of the main shock on 14 August U.T. 13:15:28, at N 15.5, E 40.5 in the Red Sea southeast of Dahlak Island. ISS located it on the mainland, at N 15.5, E 39.0, 50 km WSW of Massawa, almost 35 km due south of Asmara, near Decamere. (reference #1134)

1928, April 14 and 18. On April 14 and 18, 1928, earthquakes of magnitude 6.75 originated in southern Bulgaria, resulting in what has been called the most serious earthquake calamity in the history of that country. The epicenter of the earlier shock was near Chirpan, where there was great destruction; that of the latter was somewhat farther west near Popovitsa (Papazli). Faults were produced with maximum throw of 3 to 4 meters. (refe #1006)

1928, April 14 to 18 [effects listed with April 14 event]. Intensity XI. Destruction of the towns of Plovdiv, Borisovgrad and Tchirpan and 240 villages. 105 killed, 74,750 houses destroyed, 264000 inhabitants without shelter (of a population of 488,000). Cracks in the ground, rails twisted. According to G. Bontcheff, the earthquake was local; its main cause lies in the instability of the masses which are at the base of the valley. (ref #1093)

1928, April 18, 19:22:48 UTC. 42.1 N, 25 E, magnitude 7.0, S. Bulgaria, intensity X (Philippoupole). The earthquake was preceded by foreshocks the largest of which occurred on 14 April (09:30, 42.15° N, 25.28° E, M = 6.8) and it was also destructive. It was followed by many aftershocks the largest of which occurred on 25 April (09:25:, M = 5.7). These earthquakes caused large destructions in Philippoupole, Tsipran and Papasli. In Philippoupole 8,000 houses collapsed. Totally 74,570 houses were overturned in 240 cities and villages. 127 people were killed and 1,735 were injured. During the generation of the earthquake of 14 April (M =6.8), two parallel normal faults were created in the ground with an east-west direction, a distance between them equal to about 15 km and a fall to the south side of the north fault and to the north side of the south fault by about 50 cm. The length of the north fault was equal to 38 km and of the south equal to 42 km. During the generation of the main shock (M = 7.0), the ground rupture was extended more to the west and turned to the northwest. The total length of the rupture which was caused by the main shock was about 60 km while the northeast side of the fault was sunk by more than 3m near the village Popovitsa. In Komotine the earthquake caused the collapse of a house and fissures in walls. In Thessaloniki, it caused panic and fissures in the walls of some houses and of some building in the beach. In the area of Kapoutzidi two houses collapsed. The inhabitants got out of the houses and many of them spent the night in the open air. In Eleutheroupole, the police station collapsed. It was felt in several places of Greece. Some days before the earthquake the mineral springs around Philippoupole overflowed and the water that came out was very warm (Newspaper of Balkans, 19.4.1928; AOA, 1932; Sieberg, 1932b; Montandon, 1953; Richter, 1958). Isoseismals for the largest foreshock, for the main shock and for its largest aftershock are cited in the atlas of UNESCO (Shebalin et al., 1974b) and by Papazachos et al. (1997b). (ref #4408)

October 30, 1930. The province of Ancona and Pesaro was hit from a strong jolt, that manifested particularly in Senigallia, where it caught up grade the IX. The majority of the rooms in the city were rendered inhabitable. 14 died in Senigallia and 4 in Ancona. (reference #1063)

1931, February 3 10:47 (local time). 39.5 N, 177 E. There was an earthquake [intensity IX] with source in Hawke Bay, which almost completely destroyed Napier and Hastings, and was felt over a considerable area. In the central region, the quake consisted of two shocks, the second being significantly stronger. Vibrations quickly intensified and continued for 2.5 minutes, making it difficult to stand upright. This earthquake turned out to be more severe than all previous quakes in New Zealand. More than 250 people perished in the quake and numerous aftershocks continued for more than a month.

Subsequent geological investigation revealed that the earthquake was apparently caused by a thrust in an easterly direction along a fault or system of faults having a northeastern attitude. The shore in the area of Napier lifted up 1.8 m, and 18 km farther north the lift diminished and in the area of Wairoa there was no uplift at all. The coast south of Napier sank 1/4 to 1 m. Subsequent depth sounding revealed that the uplift had also affected the bottom of the bay adjacent to Napier. The navigation channel in Napier became shallower by 1.8 m. Along the coast of Hawke Bay many cave-ins and landslides occurred.
(above from reference #415)

256 killed, $25 million damage. (reference #1250)

The Hawke's Bay earthquake of 3 February 1931 came like a 'bolt from the blue', a sudden catastrophe unpredicted by the science of the day... It seared itself indelibly into the memories of the 70,000-odd men, women and children living in Hawke's Bay that fateful summer... The toll was finally settled officially at 256--although, despite an outstanding effort, two people were never accounted for. Over 400 were hospitalized with serious injuries. At least 2500 were cut, bruised, scratched, and shocked, a toll never fully evaluated because few bothered to report trivial injuries to the authorities... The event is called the 'Napier' or 'Hawkes Bay' earthquake but it actually affected the whole depression-era New Zealand. The shock brought down buildings between Gisborne and Waipawa. It topped chimneys from Taupo to Wellington. (reference #9338)

Occurring at 10.47 a.m. [Note: this is Summer Time] on Tuesday, February 3rd, 1931, the Hawke's Bay earthquake is recorded as having caused the largest loss of life and the most extensive damage ever recorded in New Zealand. The effects of the earthquake were greatest in the towns of Napier and Hastings, but other towns in Hawke's Bay also suffered major damage. The death toll has recently been reassessed at 261, with 121 in Napier and 97 in Hastings. The earthquake was followed by fires in the business areas of both Napier and Hastings, the fires becoming uncontrollable as the water pressure dwindled because of broken water mains. (reference #11746)

Extensive damage, hitherto unreported, along the coast between Napier and Wairoa, and on the [?]arming and Crown lands between those two centres, was revealed to the "Star" correspondent in the course of a trip by air over that country. Fissures, rifts, landslides, holes and other curious malformation are to be seen by the score. (reference #12534)

1932, Sept 26. Aegean Sea, northern Greece. A catastrophic (I=XI) earthquake occurred with its focus possibly in the region of the Gulf of Ierissos. Landslides took place. Faults up to 12 km long were formed. 5 villages including Ierissos were razed to the ground in the region of the Mt Athos. 3,000 houses were destroyed; 341 people were killed. Numerous new shocks took place including some that caused victims within the region of Thessaloniki. 10,000 people lost their dwellings. The damage in the region of the Mt Athos was estimated at 5 million drachmae. Many houses crumbled in Dhrama, Kavala, and other settlements to the north of the focal area. The operator of a seagoing dredge anchored in the River Strimonas 1 km from its estuary was disturbed from his sleep. A temporary automatic tide gauge installed near the estuary of the River Stritnonas in the Gulf of Orfani recorded the tidal wave 1 m high. It did not cause any damage. (reference #2130)

1932, Sept 26, 19:20:42 UTC. 40.45 N, 23.76 E, magnitude 7.0. Intensity X (Hierissos). The first of the two largest aftershocks occurred in the same day with the main shock (21:26, M =6.0) and the other on 11 March 1933, that is, about eight months later. Another strong shock occurred on 29 September (03:57, 40.97 N, 23.23 E, M = 6.2) but its epicenter was in Mygdonia basin (Sochos), that is, clearly out of the rupture zone of the main shock. Also, an earthquake which occurred on 20 October (M =5.0) had its epicenter in Asprovalta, that is, out of the rupture zone of the main shock. Hierissos and Stratoni were destroyed. Simultaneously with the main shock an instant shine was observed in the sky. In Hierissos, 650 houses were entirely collapsed, 85 people were killed and 175 were injured. In Stratoni, only 41 people were killed and 99 were injured and this is due to the good street-plan and to the large width of the streets. Large damage there suffered the villages Gomati, Megale Panaghia, Arnaia, Nea Roda, Stagira, Palaeochorio and Sideropotamos. In Aghio Oros only the monasteries Philotheou and Karakallou standed. The monastery Stauroniketa suffered terrible and not repairable damage and the monastery Koutloumousiou suffered serious damage and a dangerous subsidence at its north side. Monks were injured and fire occurred in the monastery Kastamonitou. Totally, 4,106 houses were destroyed and 3,218 were seriously damaged, 161 persons were killed and 669 were injured. December 25, 1932, 10:04:27 local time, Changma, Yumen, Gansu Province, 39.7 N, 96.7 E, magnitude 7.6, intensity X.

Meizoseismal region: Zhujia Gobi in the southern part of the Changma Basin, Yumen County, the northern slope of Xiangmao Hill and Erdaochuan, Hongyazi and Xishuixiagou. According to incomplete statistics, 1,167 houses (86.5% of the total) collapsed in the Changma region. The ground ruptured or deformed intermittently for 116 km in length, and extending from Maizigou Hill, West Lake, Changma in the west, to the mouth of the Xishui Gorge on the eastern side of the Baiyang River in the east. There occurred swelling of earthen banks, forming steep ridges, sinking, fissuring, landsliding, and falling of a lot of rocks. Ground fissures wider than 1 m were seen in most places. On the mountains, fissures cut crisscross through the summits. Water gushed out from fissures in flat ground. Springs and wells dried up. The Shule River also dried up for several days. All of the 800 families were devastated, 270 people were killed and more than 300 injured in the Changmapu Township. The stricken region, about 500 km in length and about 155 km in width, included the whole Changrna Basin and the west part of the Hexi Corridor.

Jiuquan: Battlements and gate towers fell down under shaking, shabby houses collapsed, and wooden cabins fissured. Ground fissures, 20-30 cm in width, occurred in the wet land. Some large trees were torn up. Landslides occurred widespread around Binggou and Langwei hills. There were many fixsures, generally 1-1.5 m in width, the widest up to 3 m.

Yumen: Battlements collapsed by shaking, rooftiles of gate towers fell, and over 10 houses were destroyed.

Dunhuang: About 100 old civilian houses collapsed.

Anxi: 25 civilian houses and city walls at 5 locations were destroyed with loss of some dozen head of livestock.

Gaotai: City walls fell. Offices of the county government collapsed, and many civilian houses were damaged. 3 persons were killed, over 20 injured, and more than 100 head of livestock were killed.

Jinta: The city wall collapsed about 14 m in length, most civilian houses were also destroyed. 2 persons were killed.

Dingxin: Most city walls and houses collapsed under shaking. Several head of livestock were killed.

Qingshuipu: Battlements collapsed under shaking, part of the city walls collapsed, and some enclosing walls of a manor were destroyed.

Linze: Houses by the city gate suffered negligible

The event magnitude ranges between 6.43 and 6.70, depending on the magnitude scale used. The epicentral location falls around the geographical coordinates 36.80 N/27.30 E, with some deviating determinations in the various catalogues.

In addition, a local report (Koumentos 2000)[...]The above documents offer a wealth of information about the 1933 earthquake effects mainly in Kos, Nissyros and other islands. Slight damage was also caused in the area of Bodrum peninsula, SW Turkey (Fig. 1).

[...]about 90% of the houses in the city of Kos collapsed, while only a few administrative buildings remained standing. However, this happened in the historical center of the city. On the contrary, in the new city only about 50% of the houses were destroyed.

[...]in Pyli serious damage occurred and three victims were reported. In Antimachia nearly all the houses collapsed. The village of Kardamena was almost entirely destroyed, while the Cathedral and other four small churches suffered damage and needed repair. In Asfendiou moderate damage was reported. In Kefalos, at the westernmost side of the island, little damage was reported but the St. George church also needed repair after the earthquake.

From a collection of press reports (Aggelis 2003) it results that damage was also caused in the villages Emporio, Pali, Mandraki and Nikia at Nissyros Isl. (Fig. 4), while a local report (Koumentos 2000) mentioned repairable damage at the Panagia (Virgin Mary) Monastery situated to the east of Pali, at the north side of the island. No damage was reported in the islands of Rhodes and Kalymnos (Fig. 1). Slight damage in houses was reported from Bodrum, SW Turkey.

As regards the level of mortality caused by the 1933 earthquake there is a remarkable variability in the several documents examined. According to Mourikis (1934), 200 persons were killed and 600 injured. Papazachos and Papazachou (1997, 2003) adopted these figures from Mourikis (1934) although the last is not a quite reliable author for the reason that his earthquake catalog does not provide information sources [...]In the Album of Kos (Manousis 1934), various estimates can be found with the number of casualties ranging from 200 or 300 and up to several hundreds, but only 122 names of people killed were listed. The estimated number of injuries varies from 600 up to a few thousands[...]collection and evaluation of various press reports, however, Aggelis (2003) estimated that in Kos 149 persons perished and more than 600 were injured. A careful examination of official archives by Chatzivasiliou (1990) showed that in Kos city the total number of victims reached 178[...]Therefore, we adopted that the total number of victims caused by the 1933 earthquake reached 181, while a realistic estimate of the total number of injuries would be around 600.

August 25, 1933, 15:50:30, 31.9 N, 103.4 E, magnitude 7.5, intensity X.

The whole city of Diexl and the surrounding 60 odd towns and villages collapsed completely. Landslides occurred extensively in all hills. Guanyinyan and Yinpingyan caved in. Large scale collapses occurred at the platform of Diexi and Jiaoehangba damming the Minjiang River to form four earthquake lakes. Forty-five days after the great earthquake, lake dykes burst, causing floods in the lower reaches. Everywhere, collapses produced "flight of steps", with emission of black mud flow ,and the landforms changed because of Iandslides and earth slumps. People and livestock suffered casualties, no body in the meizoseismic region escaped, more than 6,800 people were killed and over 2,500 people were washed away, and the injured were countless.

Maoxian: Rocks broke down, a stone tower fell, brick-and-stone memorial archways were split by shaking, and city walls collapsed about 4 m long. Brick houses and chimneys collapsed partly, more than 20 shabby houses and about 50-60% of the walls collapsed, 2 persons were killed and more than 10 injured in the vicinity of the city gate. City walls collapsed, one third of houses were damaged or collapsed around Shitaiguan and Feihongqiao, landslides ar d ground fissures occurred extensively, and 60-70% of the population were killed or injured. All houses and temples collapsed, rocks broke down, and the mud banks were topplld around Shaba and Ohibusu.

Wenchuan: A few houses collapsed, others were shaken out of joints, and roof ridges fell. Stone pillars broke off, and 30% of the stone walls were broken and collapsed. Earth hills collapsed dozens of meters long, and a lot of landslides and ground fissures occurred.

Songpan: City walls collapsed 7-10 m in length, gate towers fell under shaking, 30% of the houses collapsed and one fifth were tilted by shaking. Rocks fell in large quantities, breaking bridges and blocking paths and ditches. The ground fissures, up to dozens of meters in length, occurred at the hillside and the ridge of a hill. Many people and plenty of livestock were killed or injured. Near Zhangle, some walls fell, earth banks collapsed and landslides and ground fissures occurred.

Lixian: 20-30% of the houses collapsed in the whole county, 50% of the stone walls cracked, and the stone walls at a lamasery collapsed. Half of a thirty-odd-storey pagoda toppled down. Landslides and ground fissures occurred, trees were uprooted, and people and livestock suffered casualties.

Heishui: Landslides and ground fissures occurred, houses and earthen blockhouses fell, and people and livestock were killed or injured. All the houses and watchtowers were devastated, landslides and ground fissures, 1-3 m in width, occurred, leading to heavy casualties around Sergu and Heirguazt.

Chengdu: The belfry top of the church fell down. City walls collapsed at various parts, and a few civilian houses were shaken out of joints. More than one hundred people were killed or injured.

Mianzhu: The roof tip of the Hu-Guang Guild Hall fell down under shaking, that of the Shaanxi Guild Hall was tilted. In the latter hall roof tiles fell, Deyang: Ridges of old houses broke down, some beams of a stage were broken by shaking, and some frame tenons were loosened from mortises.

(above from reference #3939)

February 7, 1936, 16:56:27 local time, Southwest of Kangle, Gansu Province, 35.4 N, 103.4 E, depth 12km, magnitude 6.75, intensity IX.

Kangle: Cliffs cracked. 1,150 tile-roofed, adobe or thatched houses and 14 cave dwellings collapsed. 372 families were hit. 35 people were injured, 11 people and numerous domestic animals were killed.

In the light of the investigation in 1975, in and around Huawan and Ouomatan in the southwestern part of the county, rocks split with a width up to 6-10 m and extending a few Ian in length. In and around Baishishan landslides occurred, producing wide rifts that could not be jumped over. Houses in and around Qianchewan totally collapsed. The ground cracked in mountainous regions, fissures happened in flat land with ejection of water. Rocks rolled down the hillside, blocking a river. More than 2/3 of the houses collapsed in Jielaigou. A rift on an earth hill was 1.5 m wide and more than 30 m long. An earth cliff fell and rocks rolled down. In Shangjiagou, part of the houses were damaged Or collapsed, and the flood land fissured. Rocks rolled down.

Heaheng: More than 8,500 houses and cave dwellings collapsed, 6 people and more than 150 domestic animals were killed. (It was also said that many walls and houses collapsed all over the county. Many people were killed. In Nanxiang 13 people were killed).

In the light of investlgations of 1975, in the southeastern part of the counry--Mts. Huanghualine (Mts, Weita), Mts. Chuang'er and Huayashan - serious landslides occurred. Around Tutaizi, at the foot of Mt. Chuang'er, the ground cracked 1-1.5 m wide and more than 33 m long, and a number of landslides occurred. In Xlnshang, zhuang and Langtuquan walls collapsed, killing a few people. In the county seat, roof-tiles fell and fissures occurred on old walls. Clods fell off city walls. In rooms small pieces of furniture upset.

Lintao : Battlements, houses and walls collapsed. A great many people were killed in the villages. Some house walls fell down under shaking in Huichuan.

Linxia: Civilian houses collapsed. Roof-tiles fell in Shazang, Yintan and Tumenguan. The earthen cliff on the river bank crumbled.

Lanzhou: Many shabby houses collapsed.

Lintan: Worse affected places were Shangzhai, Gaozhuang, Chigou and Yeliguan. Many shabby houses and mud walls collapsed under shaking. Walls generally fissured and tiles fell. Small fissures occurred on flood lands.

Zhuoni: Roof-tiles fell and slabstones slid in Shuimochuan, Duozang, Shangjialing, Shi'erba and other places. Huge rocks rolled down in Shangjjaling. Fissures occurred on the flood lands of Shuimochuan.

Xiahe: Huge rocks (about 20 m in diameter) rolled down Mt. Weidang, crushing houses. Some trees were uprooted in Gasugou.

Weiyuan: Some houses collapsed, walls fell, roof-tiles fell and soil cliffs collapsed in Tuojiashan, Jinjiaquan and Xiacheng.

The shock was felt in Tianshui, Jingning, Dingxi Longde, Pmghang In Gansu Province, Xining; in Qinghai Province; Wugong (a telephone pole toppled down) in Shaanxi Province.

(above from reference #3939)

1937, August 20. There was a strong earthquake with source apparently near Alabat Island. On this island the force of tremors was 7-8 degrees (VIII-IX Rossi-Forel). Almost all the homes tilted or suffered light damage. Thirty-seven people were injured. The earthquake caused damage to various structures at Polillo, Iloubnn (the shore dike was damaged), Atimonan, Gumaca, Lucban, Tayabas, TAuseiia, Santa Cruz, Paete, Siniloan, Cavinti, Pililla, Tanay, Taytay, Yasig, Hanila, Antipolo, Caloocan, Cavite, San Miguel and Naga. Hundreds of people were injured. At Manila, the tremors continued for 4 minutes, and the strongest ones ones lasted 40 seconds. The earthquake was noticeable as far as Laoag, Iloilo, and according to dubious sources, the north of Mindanao Island. It was accompanied by numerous recurrent shocks.

The earthquake affected the sea. There were reports of a rise in water level at Quezon, on the south of Alabat Island and at the top of Calauag Ray. At Calauag, the level rose from the ebb tide mark to the flood tide mark in 10 minutes. Some rafts, on which several people were traveling up the Calauog River, were picked up by a strong flood current.

Nanqiao: House roofs cracked and pillars tilted in a Burmese temple. The top of a white pagoda fell. Many landsiides occurred, burying Dongluan Town about 35 km west of Nanaqiao. Fissures occurred in pond banks. Some persons were killed.

Lancang: Some house walls and old shabby houses collapsed. Walls in temples split and part of mud walls collapsed. The mountain ridges fractured, rocks fell down, slumps and sinkings occurred and roads cracked. 6 persons were killed.

Mengman: Some of the bamboo houses and earth walls collapsed. The enclosing walls in a Burmese temple were wrenched apart, and the columns tilted. The ground fissured with ejection of sandy water. A fish pond overflowed after the shock.

Fohai: The top of a white pagoda fell and walls with columns split.

Lincang: The enclosing walls of the stadium of the People's Educational Center collapsed for some 7 m in length. Some civilian dwellings collapsed.

The shock was also felt in Simao County.

The three strong shocks of 24, 25 and 26 April 1957 caused widespread damage in the eastern part of the island of Rhodes, where 16 houses were entirely destroyed, 186 partially destroyed, 1,318 seriously damaged; there were 11 injured and the damage amounted to $276,000; Galanopoulos published photographs of characteristic destruction (Seismological Institute Bullerin, 1957). Among the areas which suffered were Istrios, Monolithos and Rhodes. In Turkey, along the mast near the focus, damage was particularly severe, being due in the main to the strongest shock, that of 25 April at 02.25 h : 80 per cent of the buildings were damaged or destroyed in the little port of Fethiye, where the casualties were 18 killed and 70 injured; other damage was reported at Golenye (40 per cent of houses), at Dalaman (30 per cent), at Marmaris (20 per cent), where 43 buildings collapsed (Pinar). The press reported the collapse of a mosque at Antalya, causing 7 injured, as well as the destruction of houses, and 4 injured at Milos. In all, 3,000 houses were made uninhabitable, and 5,000 slightly damaged.

On May 22, 1960, a Mw 9.5 earthquake, the largest earthquake ever instrumentally recorded, occurred in southern Chile. The series of earthquakes that followed ravaged southern Chile and ruptured over a period of days a 1,000 km section of the fault, one of the longest ruptures ever reported. The number of fatalities associated with both the earthquake and tsunami has been estimated to be between 490 and 5,700. Reportedly there were 3,000 injured, and initially there were 717 missing in Chile. The Chilean government estimated 2,000,000 people were left homeless and 58,622 houses were completely destroyed. Damage (including tsunami damage) was more than $500 million U.S. dollars.

The main shock generated a tsunami that was not only destructive along the coast of Chile, but also caused numerous casualties and extensive property damage in Hawaii and Japan, and was noticeable along shorelines throughout the Pacific Ocean area. There were several other geologic phenomena besides tsunamis associated with this event. Subsidence caused by the earthquake produced local flooding and permanently altered the shorelines of much of the area in Chile impacted by the earthquake rendering all marine navigational charts of the affected areas obsolete. Landslides were common on Chilean hillsides. The Puyehue volcano erupted forty-seven hours after the main shock.

The Makarska earthquake is one of the most important seismic sequences in Croatia in the last 50 years. The main shock occurred between the main land and the islands of Hvar and Brač, at a depth between 5 and 20 km. The earthquake caused a vertical sea-bottom displacement of 15 cm and a sea-floor deformation on the order of 10 km (Herak et al. 2001). Several newspapers reported that the earthquake was also felt at sea. At 7:15 am the ship Vladimir Nazor which runs regularly between Ploče and Split, sailed into the Makarska port. At the time of the earthquake the boat was somewhat more than one (nautical) mile away from the coast, in the direction of Igrane. All the crew has declared that they felt a bump, as if the boat had stranded in full speed against an underwater ridge. All those that were sleeping at the time in their cabins or in the parlour, were awaken by the strength of the shock. According to the first engine-man Josip Bergam, at the time of the earthquake the steam ship (Budva) was just coming into the port of Igrane. They were about 100 m away from the quay. They felt a strong shock, which was twice as strong as the one they felt at sea on Sunday.-I was in the engine-room, Josip Bergam told us-and the first thing of what I thought was that we had run in full speed into underwater cliffs and that the ship is mounting onto the coast' (Vjesnik 1962). In another report we read The earthquake was also felt at sea, so cap. Juraj Boric´, the captain of m/b Gusar, helmsman Josip Vela and the sailors, were thrown out of their beds while the ship was at the quay in Podgora  On board ship Takovo, which was at the time at sea between Sumartin and Split, 150 passengers felt a strong shock and the sea became disturbed. Also the passengers, who happened to be yesterday morning on board ship Vuk Karadic´, felt the shock from the earthquake, while the ship was passing through the strait of Splitska Vrata' (Slobodna Dalmacija 1962, of 12/01). Strong shaking was also felt in the island of Brač: The sea also trembled like water in a saucepan. The sailors from the ship Takovo, which was at the time of the earthquake in the port of Sumartin on the island of Brač, say that the earthquake was also felt at sea-they call it maremoto-the sea was trembling like water in a saucepan, they say' (Slobodna Dalmacija 1962, of 14/01).

(above reference #11164)

It began on 7 January 1962 with a foreshock of ML 5.9. The mainshock occurred four days later, on 11 January at 05:05. It had a magnitude ML 6.1, and the largest estimated intensity was VIII. The greatest damage was observed in villages and towns on and beneath the Biokovo Mt. in the Makarska municipality, on the central Adriatic islands (Hvar, Brac, Korcula, Lastovo) and on the Peljesac peninsula. The whole epicentral area was evacuated after the mainshock. The contemporary reports (e.g., Bozicevic, 1962) state that 2290 houses were left destroyed to the level of being unsuitable for living in, 78 schools and other public buildings were damaged, as well as 6 km of roads. Over 100 earthquakes were felt in the shaken area in the first week alone. (reference #2862)

The two largest events of 7 January and 11 January had magnitudes of M = 5.9 and M = 6.1, and were felt with intensities of 8 and 8-9 MCS, respectively. The earthquakes caused large damage in the Biokovo area, and practically define the earthquake hazard there. (reference #11686)

Note: Damages from the earthquake on 07 January 1962, in the same region, are combined with this listing.

February 21, 1963, Libya. The earthquake affected an area in Cyrenaica situated on an alluvial plain lying between two northeasterly trending, fault-controllcd escarpments, in which Barce (Al Marj) is situated. Barce (population 13,000) and farming settlements in a strip 20 km long were badly damaged and many houses collapsed, killing about 300 and injuring 375 people. In all, 12,000 people were made homeless; maximum damage occurred in Maddalena, about 12 km northeast of Barce, where all farmhouses were demolished. The shock was not particularly large and its maximum effects were confined within an area of 6 km radius. It was perceptible in Benghazi, about 100 km to the southwest, and much of the damage was due to the very poor quality of construction. Small magnitude aftershocks continued for two days. (reference #3845)

The Skopje earthquake will rank among the most destructive: 1,070 dead, 3,300 injured of whom 1,200 seriously, material damage amounting to 374 thousand million dinars ($500 million), i.e., 82.5% of the total wealth of the town, not counting the complete destruction of many monuments of historic or artistic value (press reports). (reference #1040)

A magnitude 5.4 earthquake took place in the early morning hours of July 26, 1963, with an epicenter near Skopje, capital of Macedonia in Yugoslavia. The earthquake was characterized by an extremely high destructiveness to poorly designed but recently built office buildings, hotels, and apartment houses in the center of the city. Over 1,000 persons were killed, and 80% of the city of 200,000 were left homeless. This unduly high degree of damage can be attributed to the complete disregard of aseismic design criteria, which led to the collapse of many multistory brick bearing-wall structures, intensity of VIII (Modified Mercalli 1931) was the highest noted; the seismic ground effects common to intensities higher than VIII were absent. Skopje is located on the flood plain of the Vardar River, within the highly active Vardar Tectonic Zone, which has a we11 documented history of destructive earthquakes. Since soil conditions of the terraces of the Vardar River are superior to those of the flood plain, the amount of damage to structures on the terraces was limited. The damage was mostly confined to the relatively small area of the lowest level of the flood plain. (reference #1224)

On 26 July 1963 a relatively small earthquake occurred beneath Skopje, Yugoslavia, a city of 200,000 inhabitants. 80% of the buildings in the city were destroyed or severely damaged, and 1,100 people were killed. The total cost of reconstruction has been estimated at $200 million, the total economic loss inflicted on the region at $1,000 million. (reference #3689)

The intensity of the Skopje earthquake in the heart of the city has been rated differently by different observers. Many reports indicate the maximum maximum intensity to be IX or X (MCS). We appraise the intensity at VIII (MM). The number of fatalities was in the neighborhood of 1,200. 10% of the buildings collapsed, and an additional 65% of the buildings were damaged beyond economical repair. (reference #3750)

On 5 February 1966 a strong earthquake of magnitude 6.3 occurred in Evritania; it was preceded by a series of slight tremors. The principal shock (Feb 5) caused serious damage in a dozen mountain villages, particularly at Fournas, Alestia, Kleisto and Vracha; 450 houses were destroyed, 1,200 seriously damaged. There was 1 death and 60 injured, 4 of whom seriously; numerous landslides and ground fractures were noticed.

The Greek seismological service published the following in its bulletin of February 1966:
An exceptionally long sequence of small local shocks with exponentially increasing frequency preceded the principal shock. The sequence started after the damming of the Akheloos River and the impounding of the artificial Lake Kremasta. It was found that the numbers of the foreshocks could be correlated with increasing of reservoir loading. There seem, therefore, to be good reasons for believing that the tectonic equilibrium in the area of Kremasta was sufficiently ripe to be disturbed by this comparatively minor additional unilateral load. The weight of the water in the new lake is of the order of 4.7 x 109 tons.

Evritania is a seismic region, but from 1951 to 1965 the epicentres were localized in the lower Akheloos valley, about 40 km downstream from the dam. This dam, built across the Akheloos near the Kremasta thermal springs, started filling with water on 21 July 1965. From November 1965, the level of the lake rose rapidly; the first tremors were felt in January 1966 and the principal shock occurred on 5 February when the lake had almost reached its maximum height: the depth of the water was then about 120 metres. Numerous aftershocks (more than 160) were felt or recorded; they were localized either near the lake or in the mountainous area to the north-east of the dam; at least 5 of the aftershocks were of magnitude greater than 5: 5 February, 8 March, 3 April, 4 May, and 11 June.

The lake rests on eocene-oligocene flysch; however, about 11 km to the north of the dam, the lake covers an area of large faults at the contact between the flysch and the Jurassic limestone of Gavrovon: it is in this latter area that the premonitory tremors and the strongest aftershocks occurred. A further violent tremor occurred on 29 October, 1966.

(above from reference #1039)

September 1, 1966, 14.23 UTC, 37.5 N, 22.1 E, magnitude 5.3 mb, 5.9 MS, depth 17 km. In the Megalopolis district, already devastated on 5 April 1965, further damage was caused by another earthquake on 1 September 1966: felt over an area of 250,000 km2, the tremor reached intensity VIII along the pleistocene fault-line, lying NNW-SSE several kilometres east of Megalopolis; 180 houses were destroyed, 1,500 rendered inhabitable. Happily there were few victims (25 injured) owing to the fact that most of the inhabitants were outside their houses and had been warned by a long rumbling. Among the places most affected were Megalopolis, Trilophos, Tripotamos, Plaka, Orestion, Yefikaria. While the 1965 earthquake occurred on the fault along the west of the Megalopolis rift-valley, the 1966 movement occurred on the fault forming the eastern edge of the graben. (reference #1039)

An earthquake on July 29, 1967, near the coast of Venezuela about 30 miles west of Caracas, caused 240 fatalities, 1,536 injuries, and $50 million property damage. Damage was extensive in the Altamira and Los Palos Grandes sections of Caracas. Four apartment buildings, 1 to 12 stories high, collapsed and several additional structures may have to be razed and rebuilt. Unusual features of this earthquake were little damage to low buildings; no evidence of surface faulting; no landslides; and no interruption of utilities. (reference #45)

29 July 1967, 10.6N 67.3W, magnitude 6.5. The earthquake of 29 July 1967 (No. 554) caused severe losses in the region of Caracas: 240 dead and missing, 1,536 injured, very severe damage evaluated at $50 million. The loss of life was mainly due to the collapse of four large buildings of 10-12 storeys, constructed between 1962 and 1966. In fact, the earthquake was of relatively minor intensity (magnitude6.5), and of the 808 high-rise buildings in Caracas, only 161 showed signs of damage: 10 had to be demolished. It is notable that the damage to large modern buildings was more severe than that suffered by the small, poorly constructed houses in the less prosperous parts of the city. There was no superficial faulting. There was also severe damage on the coast near Caracas; several hotels were affected, more or less severely according to the nature of the foundations and subsoil. (reference #1039)

The event has a reported magnitude of MW 6.6, causing more than 270 fatalities and 1500 injuries. (reference #12788)

August, 1968, 10.47 UTC, 34 N. 58.7 E, magnitude 6.0 mb, 7.4 Ms, depth 13 km. Known as the Dasht-e Biiyiiz earthquake, this shock was of disastrous proportions in Khorasan; many villages were reduced to heaps of rubble; a zone of 4,000 km2 was severely affected; more than 10,000 people were killed (official statistics published on 3 September spoke of 10,488 dead and several thousand missing), 17,000 injured, 12,000 houses destroyed, 70,000 people rendered homeless. Among the places which suffered most was Dasht-e Bayaz, where there were 3,000 dead out of a total population of 3,500. At Kakhk, a small town of 4,400 inhabitants, almost all the houses in adobe (sunbaked brick) were destroyed, with the exception of a group of about sixty houses; 3,000 persons were buried under the ruins. At Ferdows, already damaged by the first shock, the greatest destruction was caused by the aftershock on 1 September, whose epicentre was very close to the town; 1,500 houses out of a total of 2,300 were totally destroyed and at least 700 persons were killed. More or less severe damage was reported at Gonabad, Qayen and Birjand, where public buildings in masonry stood up to the earthquake but where many houses collapsed, as did two mosques dating from the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. There were many casualties. (reference #1039)

July 18, 1969, 13:24:50 (Beijing local time), 38.2 N, 119.4 E, Bohai Sea, magnitude 7.4, depth 35 km.

A large part of Kenli County and part of Lijin and Zhanhua counties were badly hit.

Kenli: Of the 600 odd brick-tile houses in Xinan Commune, 22 were destroyed and more than 300 suffered damage. A 100-m long single-brickwalled stable in the army horse-breeding farm collapsed. A ground fissure, about 1 km in length and 30-40 cm in width, occurred on Gudao Island; the northern end of the island subsided 30 cm. Many ground fissures occurred on Dagudao Island. Lots of fissures occurred on the dike of the Production Dike north of Xinan Village; the dyke slumped, one section sank 1-2 m. The ground sank; water and sand gushed out. In Xiazhen Commune, most adobe and thatched cottages suffered damage; among them one-third were destroyed, a few collapsed. A fissure belt, about 0.5 m wide and O.5-2 km long, occurred.
On the Single-opening arch concrete bridge in Shuanghe Village, Minfeng Commune, a fissure stretched from the middle of the bridge across the surface to reach the arch rib. The earth split 1.5 km along the ancient river course with ejection of water and sand. Of the 1,500 houses, 18 caved in, about 100 were destroyed, and nearly 200 cracked.
Lijin: A fissure belt cut through the Huanghe River dike in Luhe Comnlune, a 200 m section of which subsided 5-15 cm. Of the 180 houses in Bijiazui Village, 17 collapsed, 125 were destroyed, and 27 damaged. 13 of the 16 houses in Guanghe Village collapsed. 11 of the 30 houses in Weishantou Village collapsed.
Zhaoyuan: Walls were cracked everywhere; chimneys and a few walls collapsed. A 1 cm wide fissure, occurred at the dam of the Oujiaqi Reservoir in Luoshan Commune.
Penglai: 127 houses were damaged in the whole county, the majority with walls collapsed and a few with roofs fallen in. More than 3,000 enclosing walls, gateway larches and chimneys collapsed.
Changyi: Serious damage occurred in Longchi, Liutuan, Dongzhong and Bozhuang communes. In 13 communes 89 houses and 300 odd gables, enclosing walls of the yard, back walls and partitions collapsed; 32 arches over the gateways fell down.
Pingdu: Serious damage occurred in Datian, Jiudian and Qingyang communes in the north of Pingdu County. About 42%of the walls collapsed and the remainder were cracked mostly in Datian Commune. Four landslips occurred at the dam in the Huangshan Reservoir.
Binxian: 10 houses collapsed; 350 walls were cracked or deformed at Dengjia Village, Shangdian Commune.
Laixi: 55 houses, about 300 walls and more than 30 chimneys collapsed in the whole county.
Changdao: Fissures occurred in houses; eaves tiles fell; a few walls collapsed. Landslide occurred at a steep slope of loess. Cement slabs of a mole were cracked at the junctions.
Shouguang: Serious damage occurred in every commune along the coast in the north of the county. Ground fissures occurred on both banks of the Xiaoqing River and the west bank of the Mihe River with ejection of sand and water.

(above selections from ref #3939)

July 18, 1969, 05:24:48 UTC, 38.3 N, 119.4 E, magnitude 7.3, heavy damage reported in China. (ref #45)

The Bohai Sea earthquake of Ms 7.4 on July 18, 1969, had epicenter intensity of IX; the area with intensity greater than or equal to VI reached 29,736 km2. This earthquake killed 10 people, injured 353 people, killed three head of livestock, destroyed 15,190 houses, damaged 24,810 houses, and damaged one reservoir and one bridge. In addition, the seawall stone protection seam of Yellow River dike of 65 km from Lijin to Liuhe generally had cracks and embankment had subsidence. The estimated economic loss was 50 million RMB. (ref #12988)

July 26, 1969, 06:49:43 (Beijing local time), Yangjiang, Guangdong Province, 22 deg 19 min N, 111 deg 48 min E, magnitude 6.4, intensity VIII, depth 5 km.

Disaster areas were mainly within the boundaries of Yangjiang County, the most afflicted being a tract 19 km from east to west and 10 km from north to south, west of the County seat, where were located more than ten brigades including Xitou, Zhigong, Chengcun and Pinggang communes. 10,762 houses collapsed, 35,965, were seriously struck, and 90,840 damaged in the whole county. Embankments were seriously destroyed at 58, cracked at 26, and collapsed at 2 localities. Along the coast and the rivers north of the Beijin Port occurred a large quantity of fissures with ejection of sand and water. Rocks burst and fell, for as much as 225 cubic meters at one place, in Longguanshan, Bungkengshan and other regions.

Xinyi: The earthquake produced heavy explosive sounds. More than ten houses collapsed and 1,200 odd houses collapsed partly in the whole county.

Fengkai: People felt dizzy, walls slightly tilted, roof-tiles rattled, and bamboo fences vibrated.

Huaiji: Ground shaking was felt in the streets; doors, windows and beds shook and rattled.

Xinzhong: Shaking was felt and wall clocks rocked.

Deqing: The earthquake gave forth sound as if a motor car was passing. Doors, windows and roof-tiles rattled, and water was disturbed in basins.

Zhaoqing: Many people felt the two shakings, the second stronger than the first. Lamps swung, windows rattled; earlier wall cracks in 6 houses were widened.

Yunan: People felt rocking in E-W direction, roof-tiles rattled, mortar fell. More than 30 roof-tiles slid off an old ancestral temple at Hekou Village.

Zengcheng: People felt up-and-down jolts, and people upstairs felt as if a motor car was passing.

Gaohe: The shock was generally felt. Glass windows rattled, and poles in tile fields rocked slightly.

Panyu: Houses, trees rocked and wires swayed.

1961, June 16. Buantar Kawung: Central Java - the shock was generally felt in western Central Java. The place worst hit was Buaran, about 6 km west of Bumiayu; further, in Bantar Kawung and Jipang, respectively some 12 and 17 km west of Bumiayu, most brick buildings suffered considerable damage. In the affected area 1377 buildings sustained damage; wooden houses generally resisted shaking but some poorly constructed buildings slanted toward east or west and some collapsed completely. Despite this only one person was reported killed and 6 injured. The damage might have been due to old structures made of brick which are not well cemented and are without reinforcing iron rods. The unconsolidated river deposits may largely be responsible. (reference #1188)

1975, October 31. 12.54 N, 125.993 E, magnitude 7.4 MS. This earthquake occurred at 4:28 PM on October 31, 1975. The epicenter was in the offshore area east of Samar Island. The nearest towns, about 70 km away from the epicenter, are rural municipalities of the provinces of Northern and Eastern Samar. Intensity reports of Intensity VI levels were received from much farther and more developed towns such as Borongan in Eastern Samar, Catbalogan in Western Samar province and Tacloban in the island province of Leyte. Their distances from the epicenter range from 120 to 180 kilometers. The quake was felt as far north as Manila and south as Masbate.

It may be noted that the main shock was preceded on the previous day by an earthquake of magnitude m: 5.7. comments: At least 14 people killed, 560 injured and 12,000 homeless from Chincha Alta to Acari. Over 4,000 houses damaged or destroyed (VIII) at Nazca. Felt (VII) in the Marcona area; (VI) at Ica and Palpa; (IV) at Arequipa and Camana; (III) at Lima and Tacna; (II) at Huancayo and Pucallpa. Felt by people in high-rise buildings at Guyaquil, Ecuador and La Paz, Bolivia. Tsunami generated with maximum recorded wave heights (peak-to-trough) of 25 cm a Callao, Peru; 35 cm at Arica and 21 cm at Caldera, Chile. This thrust earthquake is associated with the subduction of the Nazca Ridge (a major feature of the Nazca plate) beneath the South American plate. It originated hear the southern end of a seismic gap between the large Peruvian earthquakes of August 24, 1942 and October 3, 1974, with the aftershock sequence progressing southward into the zone of the 1942 event. (reference #1053)

locationName: MEXICO:  VILLA DE ALVAREZ, COLIMA, TECOMAN, JALISCO
comments:
At least 29 people killed, 300 injured, about 10,000 homeless, 2,005 houses destroyed and 6,615 damaged. Most of the deaths and damage occurred in the Villa de Alvarez-Colima area. Extensive damage (VIII) at Colima and Tecoman. Some deaths and damage occurred in Jalisco and Michoacan and a few buildings were damaged in Guanajuato and Morelos. Felt strongly (VI) in parts of Mexico City. Felt in central and southwestern Mexico from Nayarit and San Luis Potosi to Puebla and Tlaxcala. Also felt at Corpus Christi, Dallas, El Paso and by people in high-rise buildings at Houston, Texas. Landslides closed a segment of the Colima-Guadalajara Highway and the port at Manzanillo. Power and telephone outages occurred in Mexico City.

The following maximum accelerations were recorded on strong-motion instruments: .002g at Acapulco, .008g at Cuernavaca and .045g at a site in the lake bed area of Mexico City.

A local tsunami was generated with wave heights (peak-to-trough) of about 1.2 meters at Manzanillo, 70 cm at Zihuatanejo and 25 cm at Lazaro Cardenas. A seiche was observed on Lake Pontchartrain and sediment was stirred up in wells in Louisiana.

This shallow earthquake occurred in a seismically active zone near the coast of central Mexico. The earthquake occurred near the juncture of three tectonic plates: the North American Plate to the northeast, the Rivera Plate to the northwest, and the Cocos Plate to the south. Both the Rivera Plate and the Cocos Plate are being consumed beneath the North American Plate. The slower subducting Rivera Plate is moving northwest at about 2 cm per year relative to the North American Plate and the faster Cocos Plate is moving in a similar direction at a rate of about 4.5 cm per year.

(above from reference #1053)

447. Egypt. Syria, Constantinople, Antioch, Jerusalem, Alexandria, destructive, intensity VIII-IX. (ref #1222)

447, November 8. Constantinople; also felt in Thrace, the Chersonesus, the Troad, Bithynia, Phyrgia, and the Hellespont. Violent shocks. (ref #521)

447, December 8. 40.7 N, 29.3 E. Intensity VIII. At Istanbul and Izmit Bay. (ref #1071)

447, January 26. 40.9 N, 28.5 E, magnitude 7.3, intensity VIII (Constantinople). According to Ammianus, this great earthquake struck various places and many walls of the city collapsed together with 57 towers. Huge blocks of stone and a number of statues collapsed. Starvation and a noxious smell in the air killed many thousands of people and cattle. Many cities were reduced to ruins. Evagrios records that many towers in different parts of the imperial city were knocked down and the long wall of the Chersonese (Callipole) was reduced to ruins. The earth opened and swallowed up many villages and innumerable other calamities happened both by land and sea. Fountains became dry and large areas of water formed on the surface, where none had existed before. Entire trees were torn up by the roots and hurled into the air and mountains were suddenly formed by the accumulation of masses thrown up. The sea also cast up dead fish, many islands were submerged and ships were seen stranded by the retreat of the waters. At the same time Bithynia, the Hellespont and both Phrygias suffered severely. The calamity lasted for considerable time. Malalas writes that during the reign of Theodosios II Nicomedia suffered its fifth calamity and was razed to the ground and flooded by the sea. Theodosios built many buildings here including the public baths, the colonnades, the harbour, the public arenas, the martyrium of St. Anthimus and all the city's churches. During his reign Constantinople suffered for the first time. The Chronicon Paschale adds that fire had been seen in the heavens too. Nicephoros Callistos, a very late source, adds that earthquakes lasted for 6 months. (ref #4408)

447, January 26. Constantinople, Nicomedea. There was a destructive earthquake on Sunday night, 26 January 447, which affected a large area that included parts of the provinces of Bithynia, of the two Phyrgiae and of the Hellespont, where it is said that many towns were ruined, about which, however nothing is known in detail. In Constantinople, public buildings and houses collapsed, particularly in the region between the Toad Emvola (Forum Theodosii) and the Bronze Tetrapylon... The shock caused general panic and the people left the city and camped outside, the emperor praying with the people and the clergy remaining barefoot for many days. Many people and animals perished in the aftermath of the earthquake from famine and disease... The shock was possibly followed by a sea wave casting ships and fish onto the land, although this is not certain... With the army of Attila approaching, the walls of the city were rebuilt in a matter of two months, which suggests that the damage was not all that great, some of these repairs being recorded by extant inscriptions. The land walls were repaired all along their 5-km length from the Marmara coast to the coast of the Golden Horn in 60 days... Marcellinus Comes, although he gives the same AD 447, records a famine and plague after the earthquake, which killed thousands. Admittedly this is separate from the earthquake, and Marcellinus does not say that anyone was killed in the earthquake, although in view of the extent of the damage, it is hard to believe that there were no deaths... evidence points strongly to an earthquake on Sunday 26 January. The only year during Theodosius's reign in which the 26 January fell on a Sunday was AD4 447, which would indicate that this event was not a later event on 26 January AD 450... (ref #9116)

1303, Aug 8. Hellenic Arc. A large lower-crust earthquake, originating on the Hellenic Arc on 8 Aug 1303, caused widespread damage in the Eastern Mediterranean region that was in places quite serious. Almost all authors date the event during the first hour of the day on Thursday 8 Aug 1303, or on Thursday morning 23 Dhu'l-Hijja 702 a.H., which are consistent. The exceptions are 7 Aug 1303 and Pachymeris, who places the earthquake on 8 Posideon (Aug), but he does not mention the year explicitly, implying that this event happened during the 22nd year of Andronicos (11 Dec 1303 to 10 Dec 1304), which is a year too high... Damage was serious in the eastern part of the island [Crete], where fortified sites were ruined together with villages and towns, leading to the deaths of about 4000 people. (ref #9116)

Ambraseys (ref #15) and Antonopolous (ref #20 and #26) list two tsunamigenic earthquakes in the Mediterranean in 1303. One on Aug 8 with an epicentral area south-east of Cairo, and another in Dec centered in the Lybian sea. But Ambraseys (ref #9116) lists one earthquake on Aug 8, 1303.

Aug 8, 1303, earthquake generated a tsunami observed on Egyptian coasts, Syrian coasts (iv), Crete(?). (ref #15)

Dec 1303, earthquake generated a tsunami observed on Crete, Southwest coasts of Peloponnesus and Rhodes, Egyqtiann coasts and Adriatic Sea. (ref #15)

August (December) 8, 1303 or 1304, Eastern part of the Mediterranean sea, 36.3 N, 27.3 E, intensity XI, magnitude 8. A catastrophic earthquake. Many castles on the Island of Crete collapsed. The town of Rhodes on the island of the same name was destroyed almost completely. Akko suffered in Palestine, Damascus, Zefat (Safad)--in Syria (now Israel), one half of the latter was destroyed. All buildings without exception in Cairo were damaged; many houses and mosques collapsed. The cities of Coronea, Methone, and others on the Peloponnesus Peninsula suffered seriously. It was felt weakly in Constantinople and, possibly, in Venice. On the Island of Crete, the sea rushed toward Candia. (ref #2130)

Aug 8, 1303 (AH 702 Dhu'l-Hijja 23): Egypt and Syria were struck by a violent earthquake; many persons were buried under the ruins. The shocks lasted for 40 days and the sea advancing submerged half of the city of Alexandria. (ref #1098)

Reference #414:
January 5, 1843, 23:30-24:00, 1.5 N, 98 E, depth 70 km, magnitude 7.25, tsunami intensity 2. There was a destructive earthquake on Nias Island and adjacent areas of the coast of Sumatra Island. The oscillations, weak at first, rapidly intensified and lasted 9 minutes. Recurrent shocks continued almost without interruption until 4:30 on the 6th. Less frequent shocks were felt for many days. The fortifications and other stone structures on the hill near Gunungsitoli were almost completely destroyed. Trees were ripped up and broken; the ground cracked and mud flowed from the crevices. The earthquake apparently spread to Singapore and Penang Island. Before the earthquake, the sea off Nias Island was absolutely calm. Suddenly, at 0:30, a terrible wave advanced from the southeast with a terrifying noise. It affected the entire coast of the island and destroyed everything in its path. The large settlement of Kampong de Mego 2 km (1 mile) from Gunungsitoli, was completely washed away. The proas on the river were tossed on land 30-50 m (100-160 feet) from their moorage.

Reference #1188:
January 5, 1843. Gunung Sitoli and Baras: Nias Island - a strong earthquake struck Gunungsitoli and Baras. The shock was followed by a tsunami, causing damage to some boats. Ground-slump was observed too.
